Context

Algebraic Quantum Field Theory

algebraic quantum field theory (perturbative, on curved spacetimes, homotopical)

Concepts

  • quantum mechanical system, subsystem

  • quantum observable

    • operator algebra, C*-algebra, von Neumann algebra

  • local net of observables

    • causal locality

    • Haag-Kastler axioms

    • Wightman axioms

    • field net

    • conformal net

  • quantum states,

    • cyclic vector, separating vector

    • quasi-free state

    • vacuum state

    • Hadamard state

quantization

  • covariant phase space

  • Peierls-Poisson bracket, causal propagator

  • causal perturbation theory, perturbative AQFT

  • Wick algebra

    • microcausal functionals

    • normal ordered product

  • S-matrix, scattering amplitude

    • causal additivity

    • time-ordered product, Feynman propagator

    • Feynman diagram, Feynman perturbation series

  • interacting field algebra

Theorems

States and observables

  • Kochen-Specker theorem

  • Gleason's theorem

  • Wigner theorem

Operator algebra

  • GNS construction

  • modular theory

  • Fell's theorem

  • Stone-von Neumann theorem

  • Haag's theorem

Local QFT

  • Reeh-Schlieder theorem

  • Bisognano-Wichmann theorem

  • PCT theorem

  • spin-statistics theorem

  • DHR superselection theory

Perturbative QFT

  • main theorem of perturbative renormalization

Euclidean QFT

  • Osterwalder-Schrader theorem (Wick rotation)

this entry is going to be one chapter of geometry of physics

under construction

\,

A first idea of quantum field theory

  • Geometry
  • Spacetime
  • Fields
  • Field variations
  • Lagrangians
  • Symmetries
  • Observables
  • Phase space
  • Gauge symmetries
  • Reduced phase space
  • Gauge fixing
  • Quantization
  • Acknowledgement

\,

This chapter gives an expository but rigorous introduction to the basic concepts of relativistic quantum field theories, specifically those that arise as the perturbative quantization of a Lagrangian field theory ‚Äì such as quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and perturbative quantum gravity appearing in the standard model of particle physics.

First we consider classical field theory (or rather prequantum field theory) and then its deformation quantization via causal perturbation theory to perturbative quantum field theory. This mathematically rigorous (i.e. clear and precise) formulation of the traditional informal lore has come to be known as perturbative algebraic quantum field theory.

We aim to give a fully local discussion, where all structures arise on the ‚Äújet bundle over the field bundle‚Äù (introduced below ) and ‚Äútransgress‚Äù from there to the spaces of field histories over spacetime (discussed further below). This ‚ÄúHigher Prequantum Geometry‚Äù streamlines traditional constructions and serves the conceptualization in the theory.

In full beauty these concepts are extremely general and powerful; but the aim here is to give a first precise idea of the subject, not a fully general account. Therefore we begin in the following with the special case where spacetime is Minkowski spacetime, where the field bundle (def. 1 below) is an ordinary trivial vector bundle and hence the Lagrangian density (def. 9 below) is globally defined. Similarly, when considering gauge theory we consider just the special case that the gauge parameter-bundle is a trivial vector bundle and we concentrate on the case that the gauge symmetries are ‚Äúclosed irreducible‚Äù.

We do however consider the proper differential geometry of the resulting spaces of field histories in terms of ‚Äúcohesive functorial geometry‚Äù embodied by (formal) smooth sets (see below) and hence (which works verbatim the same way) super smooth sets. This seamlessly subsumes the case that there are fermionic fields in the theory (as in any realistic field theory). Notice that this does not mean that we consider ‚Äúsupersymmetry‚Äù (though of course we could): plain supergeometry is but the mathematical incarnation of the Pauli exclusion principle for fermions, a key aspect of the stability of matter in the observable universe.

This comparatively simple setup already subsumes what is considered in most traditional texts on the subject, it captures the established perturbative BRST-BV quantization of gauge fields coupled to fermions on curved spacetimes ‚Äì which is the state of the art. Further generalization, necessary for the discussion of global topological effects such as instanton configurations of gauge fields will be discussed elsewhere (see at homotopical algebraic quantum field theory).

Throughout we use the case of the real scalar field and of the electromagnetic field as simple illustrative running examples, which we develop alongside with the theory.

running examples

fieldfield bundleLagrangian densityequation of motiongauge fixingPoisson bracket
real scalar fieldexpl. 3expl. 10expl. 12noneexpl. 22
electromagnetic fieldexpl. 4expl. 11expl. 13expl. 39‚Ä¶

The discussion of other types of fields is postponed to their dedicated chapters below.

Geometry

We assume that the reader has a basic knowledge of differential geometry on finite-dimensional smooth manifolds ‚Äì or in fact just an understanding of differential geometry on Cartesian spaces ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n. As we uncover quantum field theory in the following we discover ever more general concepts of differential geometry (e. g. diffeological spaces, supergeometry and Lie algebroids), but we introduce these as we go along.

Here is what we need from basic differential geometry:

For vv a vector field on a smooth manifold XX, we write

Œπ v:Œ© ‚Ä¢(X)‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢‚àí1(X) \iota_v \;\colon\; \Omega^\bullet(X) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet-1}(X)

for the operation of evaluating differential forms on this vector field, normalized so that this becomes a derivation (of degree -1) on the wedge product algebra of differential forms.

We will have ample use of Cartan's homotopy formula, which says that if exp(tv):X‚ÜíX\exp(t v) \colon X \to X denotes the flow by diffeomorphisms along vv of parameter length tt, then the derivative of the pullback of differential forms along exp(tv)\exp(t v), hence the Lie derivative ‚Ñí v:Œ© ‚Ä¢(X)‚ÜíŒ© ‚Ä¢(X)\mathcal{L}_v \colon \Omega^\bullet(X) \to \Omega^\bullet(X) is given by the anticommutator of Œπ v\iota_v with the de Rham differential dd:

‚Ñí v ‚âîddtexp(tv) *œâ =Œπ vdœâ+dŒπ vœâ. \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_v &\coloneqq \frac{d}{d t } \exp(t v)^\ast \omega \\ & = \iota_v d \omega + d \iota_v \omega \,. \end{aligned}

We also consider integration of differential forms over Cartesian products U√óŒ£U \times \Sigma of ordinary smooth manifolds: if œâ‚ààŒ© n+dim(Œ£)(U√óŒ£)\omega \in \Omega^{n + dim(\Sigma)}(U \times \Sigma) and Œ£\Sigma is compact, then

‚à´ Œ£œâ‚ààŒ© n(U). \int_\Sigma \omega \; \in \Omega^{n}(U) \,.

For generalizations we note the following:

Proposition

(the three magic algebraic properties of differential geometry)

  1. embedding of smooth manifolds into formal duals of R-algebras

    The functor that sends a smooth manifold XX to its ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-algebra C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) of smooth functions with values in the real line is a fully faithful functor;

    C ‚àû(‚àí):SmthMfd‚Ü™‚ÑùAlg op. C^\infty(-) \;\colon\; SmthMfd \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R} Alg^{op} \,.

    This means that smooth functions f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y are in natural bijection with their induced algebra homomorphisms C ‚àû(X)‚ü∂f *C ‚àû(Y)C^\infty(X) \overset{f^\ast}{\longrightarrow} C^\infty(Y) so that one may equivalently handle smooth manifolds entirely via their algebras of smooth functions.

  2. embedding of smooth vector bundles into formal duals of R-algebra modules

    For a fixed smooth manifold XX the functor that sends a smooth vector bundle E‚ÜíXE \to X to its space of sections Œì X(E)\Gamma_X(E), regarded as a module over the algebra of smooth function C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) is a fully faithful functor

    Œì X(‚àí):VectBund X‚Ü™C ‚àû(X)Mod \Gamma_X(-) \;\colon\; VectBund_X \hookrightarrow C^\infty(X) Mod

    Its essential image consists of the finitely generated projective modules.

  3. vector fields are derivations of smooth functions.

The first magic algebraic property of differential geometry may be used to speak about infinitesimal spaces:

Example

(infinitesimal neighbourhood)

For x 0‚àà‚Ñù nx_0 \in \mathbb{R}^n a point and k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N}, then the order-kk infinitesimal neighbourhood ùîª x 0 k\mathbb{D}^k_{x_0} of x 0x_0 is defined to be the space whose algebra of functions is the polynomial algebra in the nn canonical coordinate functions, modulo the relation which regards a product of more than kk of these as being zero:

C ‚àû(ùîª x 0 k)‚âî‚Ñù[(x 1‚àíx 0 1),‚ãØ(x n‚àíx 0 n)]/((x 1‚àíx 0 1),‚ãØ(x n‚àíx 0 n)) k+1. C^\infty( \mathbb{D}^k_{x_0} ) \;\coloneqq\; \mathbb{R}[ (x^1 - x_0^1), \cdots (x^n - x_0^n) ]/( (x^1- x_0^1), \cdots (x^n - x_0^n) )^{k+1} \,.

Similarly the full infinitesimal neighbourhood ùîª x 0\mathbb{D}_{x_0} (without restriction on the order) is the the space whose algebra of functions is the formal power series algebra

C ‚àû(ùîª x 0)‚âî‚Ñù[[(x 1‚àíx 0 1),‚ãØ(x n‚àíx 0 n)]]. C^\infty( \mathbb{D}_{x_0} ) \;\coloneqq\; \mathbb{R}[ [ (x^1 - x_0^1), \cdots (x^n - x_0^n) ] ] \,.

\,

\,

\,

Spacetime

Relativistic field theory takes place in (or on) spacetime. We briefly set up some notations and conventions:

Throughout, let

p‚àà‚Ñï p \in \mathbb{N}

be a natural number and write

Œ£‚âî‚Ñù p,1‚âî(‚Ñù p+1,Œ∑) \Sigma \coloneqq \mathbb{R}^{p,1} \coloneqq (\mathbb{R}^{p+1}, \eta)

for Minkowski spacetime of dimension p+1p+1, hence for the smooth manifold which is the Cartesian space ‚Ñù p+1\mathbb{R}^{p+1} of dimension p+1p+1 equipped with the constant pseudo-Riemannian metric Œ∑\eta which at the origin is given by the standard quadratic form of signature

(‚àí,+,‚ãØ,+) (-, +, \cdots, +)

in terms of the canonical coordinate functions

x Œº:‚Ñù p+1‚ü∂‚Ñù x^\mu \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^{p+1} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}

which we index starting at zero: (x Œº) Œº=0 p(x^\mu)_{\mu = 0}^p.

We write

dvol Œ£‚âîdx 0‚àßdx 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßdx p‚ààŒ© p+1(‚Ñù p,1) dvol_\Sigma \;\coloneqq\; d x^0 \wedge d x^1 \wedge \cdots \wedge d x^p \in \Omega^{p+1}(\mathbb{R}^{p,1})

for the induced volume form.

We use the Einstein summation convention: Expressions with repeated indices indicate summation over the range of indices.

For example a differential 1-form Œ±‚ààŒ© 1(‚Ñù p,1)\alpha \in \Omega^1(\mathbb{R}^{p,1}) on Minkowski spacetime may be expanded as

Œ±=Œ± Œºdx Œº. \alpha = \alpha_\mu d x^\mu \,.

Moreover we use square brackets around indices to indicate skew-symmetrization. For example a differential 2-form Œ≤‚ààŒ© 2(‚Ñù p,1)\beta \in \Omega^2(\mathbb{R}^{p,1}) on Minkowski spacetime may be expanded as

Œ≤ =Œ≤ ŒºŒΩdx Œº‚àßdx ŒΩ =Œ≤ [ŒºŒΩ]dx Œº‚àßdx ŒΩ \begin{aligned} \beta & = \beta_{\mu \nu} d x^\mu \wedge d x^\nu \\ & = \beta_{[\mu \nu]} d x^\mu \wedge d x^\nu \end{aligned}

\,

Fields

A field trajectory (field history) on a given spacetime Œ£\Sigma is meant to be some kind of quantity assigned to each point of spacetime (each event), such that this assignment varies smoothly with spacetime points. For instance an electromagnetic field trajectory (or ‚Äúhistory‚Äù) is at each point of spacetime a collection of vectors that encode the direction in which a charged particle passing through that point will feel a force (the ‚ÄúLorentz force‚Äù, see example 4 below).

This is readily formalized (def. 1 below): If FF denotes the smooth set of ‚Äúvalues‚Äù that the given kind of field may take at any spacetime point, then a field configuration Œ¶\Phi is modeled as a smooth function from spacetime to this space of values:

Œ¶:Œ£‚ü∂F. \Phi \;\colon\; \Sigma \longrightarrow F \,.

It will be useful to unify spacetime and the space of field values (the field fiber) into a single manifold, the Cartesian product

E‚âîŒ£√óF E \;\coloneqq\; \Sigma \times F

and to think of this equipped with the projection map onto the first factor as a fiber bundle of spaces of field values over spacetime

E ‚âî Œ£√óF fb‚Üì ‚Üô pr 1 Œ£. \array{ E &\coloneqq& \Sigma \times F \\ {}^{\mathllap{fb}}\downarrow & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{pr_1}} \\ \Sigma } \,.

This is then called the field bundle, which specifies the kind of values that the given field species may take at any point of spacetime. Since the space FF of field values is the fiber of this fiber bundle, it is sometimes also called the field fiber.

Definition

(fields and field histories)

Given a spacetime Œ£\Sigma, then a type of fields on Œ£\Sigma is a smooth fiber bundle

E ‚Üì fb Œ£ \array{E \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{fb}} \\ \Sigma }

called the field bundle,

Given a type of fields on Œ£\Sigma this way, then a field history of that type on Œ£\Sigma is a smooth section of this bundle, namely a smooth function of the form

Œ¶:Œ£‚ü∂E \Phi \colon \Sigma \longrightarrow E

such that composed with the projection map it is the identity function, i.e. such that

fb‚àòŒ¶=idAAAAAAA E Œ¶‚Üó ‚Üì fb Œ£ = Œ£. fb \circ \Phi = id \phantom{AAAAAAA} \array{ && E \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\Phi}}\nearrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{fb}} \\ \Sigma & = & \Sigma } \,.

The set of such sections/field histories is to be denoted Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E).

More generally, let S‚Ü™Œ£S \hookrightarrow \Sigma be a submanifold of spacetime. We write N Œ£(S)‚Ü™Œ£N_\Sigma(S) \hookrightarrow \Sigma for its infinitesimal neighbourhood in Œ£\Sigma (def. 1).

If E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma is a field bundle then the set of field histories restricted to SS, to be denoted

(1)Œì S(E)‚âîŒì N Œ£(S)(E| N Œ£S)‚ààH \Gamma_{S}(E) \coloneqq \Gamma_{N_\Sigma(S)}( E\vert_{N_\Sigma S} ) \in \mathbf{H}

is the set of section of EE restricted to the infinitesimal neighbourhood N Œ£(S)N_\Sigma(S).

For the time being, not to get distracted from the basic idea of quantum field theory, we will focus on the following simple special case of field bundles:

Example

(trivial vector bundle as a field bundle)

In applications the field fiber FF is often a finite dimensional Euclidean space and equipped with the structure of a vector space. In this case the trivial field bundle with fiber FF is of course a trivial vector bundle.

Choosing any linear basis (œï a) a=1 s(\phi^a)_{a = 1}^s of the field fiber, then over Minkowski spacetime we have canonical coordinates on the total space of the field bundle

((x Œº),(œï a)), ( (x^\mu), ( \phi^a ) ) \,,

where the index Œº\mu ranges from 00 to pp, while the index aa ranges from 1 to ss.

If this trivial vector bundle is regarded as a field bundle according to def. 1, then a field configuration Œ¶\Phi is equivalently an ss-tuple of real-valued smooth functions Œ¶ a:Œ£‚Üí‚Ñù\Phi^a \colon \Sigma \to \mathbb{R} on spacetime:

Œ¶=(Œ¶ a) a=1 s. \Phi = ( \Phi^a )_{a = 1}^s \,.
Example

(field bundle for real scalar field)

If Œ£\Sigma is a spacetime and if the field fiber

F‚âî‚Ñù F \coloneqq \mathbb{R}

is simply the real line, then the corresponding trivial field bundle (def. 1)

Œ£√ó‚Ñù pr 1‚Üì Œ£ \array{ \Sigma \times \mathbb{R} \\ {}^{\mathllap{pr_1}}\downarrow \\ \Sigma }

is the trivial real line bundle (a special case of example 2) and the corresponding field type (def. 1) is called the real scalar field on Œ£\Sigma. A configuration of this field is simply a smooth function on Œ£\Sigma with values in the real numbers:

Œì Œ£(Œ£√ó‚Ñù)‚âÉC ‚àû(Œ£). \Gamma_\Sigma(\Sigma \times \mathbb{R}) \;\simeq\; C^\infty(\Sigma) \,.
Example

(field bundle for electromagnetic field)

On Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma, let the field bundle (def. 1) be given by the cotangent bundle

E‚âîT *Œ£. E \coloneqq T^\ast \Sigma \,.

This is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) with canonical field coordinates (a Œº)(a_\mu).

A section of this bundle, hence a field trajectory/history, is a differential 1-form

A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£)=Œ© 1(Œ£) A \in \Gamma_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma) = \Omega^1(\Sigma)

on spacetime. Interpreted as the field of electromagnetism on Œ£\Sigma, this is often called the vector potential. Then the de Rham differential of the vector potential is a differential 2-form

F‚âîdA F \coloneqq d A

known as the Faraday tensor. In the canonical coordinate basis 2-forms this may be expanded as

(2)F=‚àëi=1pE idx 0‚àßdx i+‚àëi<j=1pB ijdx i‚àßdx j. F = \underoverset{i = 1}{p}{\sum} E_i d x^0 \wedge d x^i + \underoverset{i \lt j = 1}{p}{\sum} B_{i j} d x^i \wedge d x^j \,.

Here (E i) i=1 p(E_i)_{i = 1}^p are called the components of the electric field, while (B ij)(B_{i j}) are called the components of the magnetic field.

Example

(field bundle for Yang-Mills field)

Let ùî§\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra of finite dimension with linear basis (t Œ±)(t_\alpha), in terms of which the Lie bracket is given by

(3)[t Œ±,t Œ≤]=C Œ≥ Œ±Œ≤t Œ≥. [t_\alpha, t_\beta] \;=\; C^\gamma{}_{\alpha \beta} t_\gamma \,.

Over Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma, consider then the field bundle which is the cotangent bundle tensored with the Lie algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g}

E‚âîT *Œ£‚äóùî§. E \coloneqq T^\ast \Sigma \otimes \mathfrak{g} \,.

This is the trivial vector bundle (example 2) with induced field coordinates

(a Œº Œ±). ( a_\mu^\alpha ) \,.

A section of this bundle is a Lie algebra-valued differential 1-form

A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£‚äóùî§)=Œ© 1(Œ£,ùî§). A \in \Gamma_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma \otimes \mathfrak{g}) = \Omega^1(\Sigma, \mathfrak{g}) \,.

with components

A *(a Œº Œ±)=A Œº Œ±. A^\ast(a_\mu^\alpha) = A^\alpha_\mu \,.

This is called a field history for Yang-Mills gauge theory.

For ùî§=‚Ñù\mathfrak{g} = \mathbb{R} is the line Lie algebra, this reduces to the case of the electromagnetic field (example 4).

For ùî§=ùî∞ùî≤(2)\mathfrak{g} = \mathfrak{su}(2) this is a field history for the gauge field of the strong nuclear force in quantum chromodynamics.

Given any field bundle, we will find the need to regard the set of all field histories Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E) as a ‚Äúsmooth set‚Äù itself, a smooth space of sections, to which constructions of differential geometry apply. For instance we need to be talking about differential forms on Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E).

However, a space of sections Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E) does not in general carry the structure of a smooth manifold; and it carries the correct smooth structure of an infinite dimensional manifold only if Œ£\Sigma is a compact space (see at manifold structure of mapping spaces). Even if it does carry infinite dimensional manifold structure, inspection shows that this is more structure than actually needed for the discussion of field theory. Namely it turns out below that all we need to know is what counts as a smooth family of sections/field histories, hence which functions of sets

Œ¶ (‚àí):‚Ñù n‚ü∂Œì Œ£(E) \Phi_{(-)} \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^n \longrightarrow \Gamma_\Sigma(E)

from any Cartesian space ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n into Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E) count as smooth functions, subject to some basic consistency condition on this choice.

This structure on Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E) is called the structure of a diffeological space:

Definition

(diffeological space)

A diffeological space XX is

  1. a set X s‚ààX_s \in Set;

  2. for each n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} a choice of subset

    X(‚Ñù n)‚äÇHom Set(‚Ñù s n,X s)={‚Ñù s n‚ÜíX s} X(\mathbb{R}^n) \subset Hom_{Set}(\mathbb{R}^n_s, X_s) = \left\{ \mathbb{R}^n_s \to X_s \right\}

    of the set of functions from the underlying set ‚Ñù s n\mathbb{R}^n_s of ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n to X sX_s, to be called the smooth funtions? or plot from ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n to XX;

  3. for each smooth function f:‚Ñù n 1‚ü∂‚Ñù n 2f \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^{n_1} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n_2} between Cartesian spaces a choice of function

    f *:X(‚Ñù n 2)‚ü∂X(‚Ñù n 1) f^\ast \;\colon\; X(\mathbb{R}^{n_2}) \longrightarrow X(\mathbb{R}^{n_1})

    to be thought of as the precomposition operation

    (‚Ñù n 2‚ü∂Œ¶X)overetf *‚Ü¶(‚Ñù n 1‚Üíf‚Ñù n 2‚ÜífX) \left( \mathbb{R}^{n_2} \overset{\Phi}{\longrightarrow} X \right) \;\overet{f^\ast}{\mapsto}\; \left( \mathbb{R}^{n_1} \overset{f}{\to} \mathbb{R}^{n_2} \overset{f}{\to} X \right)

such that

  1. (functoriality)

    If id ‚Ñù n:‚Ñù n‚Üí‚Ñù nid_{\mathbb{R}^n} \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^n is the identity function on ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n, then (id ‚Ñù n) *:X(‚Ñù n)‚ÜíX(‚Ñù n)\left(id_{\mathbb{R}^n}\right)^\ast \;\colon\; X(\mathbb{R}^n) \to X(\mathbb{R}^n) is the identity function on the set of plots X(‚Ñù n)X(\mathbb{R}^n);

    and if ‚Ñù n 1‚Üíf‚Ñù n 2‚Üíg‚Ñù n 3\mathbb{R}^{n_1} \overset{f}{\to} \mathbb{R}^{n_2} \overset{g}{\to} \mathbb{R}^{n_3} are two composable smooth functions between Cartesian spaces, then pullback of plots along them conseutively equals the pullback along the composition:

    f *‚àòg *=(g‚àòf) *AAAAAA X(‚Ñù n 2) f *‚Üó ‚Üò g * X(‚Ñù n 3) ‚ü∂(g‚àòf) * X(‚Ñù n 2) f^\ast \circ g^\ast = (g \circ f)^\ast \phantom{AAAAAA} \array{ && X(\mathbb{R}^{n_2}) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f^\ast}}\nearrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{g^\ast}} \\ X(\mathbb{R}^{n_3}) && \underset{ (g \circ f)^\ast }{\longrightarrow} && X(\mathbb{R}^{n_2}) }

  2. (gluing)

    If {U i‚Üíf i‚Ñù n} i‚ààI\{ U_i \overset{f_i}{\to} \mathbb{R}^n\}_{i \in I} is an open cover of a Cartesian space by smooth open balls (i.e. each U iU_i is diffeomorphic to ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n itself and the embeddings f if_i are smooth functions) then the function which restricts ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n-plots of XX to a set of U iU_i-plots

    X(‚Ñù n)‚Ü™((f i) *) i‚ààI‚àèi‚ààIX(U i) X(\mathbb{R}^n) \overset{( (f_i)^\ast )_{i \in I} }{\hookrightarrow} \underset{i \in I}{\prod} X(U_i)

    is a bijection onto the set of those tuples (Œ¶ i‚ààX(U i)) i‚ààI(\Phi_i \in X(U_i))_{i \in I} of plots, which are ‚Äúmatching families‚Äù in that they agree on intersections:

    œï i| U i‚à©U j=œï j| U i‚à©U jAAAAAA U i‚à©U j ‚Üô ‚Üò U i U j Œ¶ i‚Üò ‚Üô Œ¶ j X \phi_i\vert_{U_i \cap U_j} = \phi_j \vert_{U_i \cap U_j} \phantom{AAAAAA} \array{ && U_i \cap U_j \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ U_i && && U_j \\ & {}_{\mathrlap{\Phi_i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathllap{\Phi_j}} \\ && X }

Finally given X 1X_1 and X 2X_2 two diffeological spaces, then a smooth function between them

f:X 1‚ü∂X 2 f \;\colon\; X_1 \longrightarrow X_2

is

  • a function of the underlying sets

    f s:(X 1) s‚ü∂(X 2) s f_s \;\colon\; (X_1)_s \longrightarrow (X_2)_s

such that

  • for Œ¶‚ààX(‚Ñù n)\Phi \in X(\mathbb{R}^n) a plot of X 1X_1, then the composition f s‚àòŒ¶ sf_s \circ \Phi_s is a plot f *(Œ¶)f_\ast(\Phi) of X 2X_2:

    ‚Ñù n Œ¶‚Üô ‚Üò f *(Œ¶) X 1 ‚ü∂f X 2. \array{ && \mathbb{R}^n \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\Phi}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f_\ast(\Phi)}} \\ X_1 && \underset{f}{\longrightarrow} && X_2 } \,.

For more background on diffeological spaces see also geometry of physics -- smooth sets.

Example

(smooth manifolds are diffeological spaces)

Let XX be an ordinary smooth manifold. Then it becomes a diffeological space (def. 2) by declaring its plots Œ¶‚ààX(‚Ñù n)\Phi \in X(\mathbb{R}^n) to the the ordinary smooth functions Œ¶:‚Ñù n‚ÜíX\Phi \colon \mathbb{R}^n \to X.

Under this identification, a function f:(X 1) s‚Üí(X 2) sf \;\colon\; (X_1)_s \to (X_2)_s between the underlying sets of two smooth manifold is a smooth function in the ordinary sense of smooth manifold precisely if it is a smooth function in the sense of diffeological spaces.

Example

(diffeological space of field histories)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a smooth field bundle. Then the set Œì Œ£(E)\Gamma_\Sigma(E) of field histories/sections (def. 1) becomes a diffeological space (def. 2)

(4)Œì Œ£(E)‚ààDiffeologicalSpaces \Gamma_\Sigma(E) \in DiffeologicalSpaces

by declaring that a smooth family Œ¶ (‚àí)\Phi_{(-)} of field configurations, parameterized over any Cartesian space UU is a smooth function out of the Cartesian product manifold of Œ£\Sigma with UU

U√óŒ£ ‚ü∂Œ¶ (‚àí)(‚àí) E (u,x) ‚Ü¶ Œ¶ u(x) \array{ U \times \Sigma &\overset{\Phi_{(-)}(-)}{\longrightarrow}& E \\ (u,x) &\mapsto& \Phi_u(x) }

such that for each u‚ààUu \in U we have p‚àòŒ¶ u(‚àí)=id Œ£p \circ \Phi_{u}(-) = id_\Sigma, i.e.

E Œ¶ (‚àí)(‚àí)‚Üó ‚Üì fb U√óŒ£ ‚ü∂pr 2 Œ£. \array{ && E \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\Phi_{(-)}(-)}}\nearrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{fb}} \\ U \times \Sigma &\underset{pr_2}{\longrightarrow}& \Sigma } \,.

It is easy to define differential forms on diffeological spaces XX: Any kind of differential form œâ\omega on XX should admit pullback of differential forms along any smooth function ‚Ñù n‚ÜíŒ¶X\mathbb{R}^n \overset{\Phi}{\to} X (any plot) to yield an ordinary differential form Œ¶ *(œâ)\Phi^\ast(\omega) on the Cartesian space ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n. It turns out that this minimal requirement already suffices to completely fix the concept:

Definition

(differential forms on diffeological spaces)

Let XX be a diffeological space (def. 2) then a differential form œâ\omega on XX is

  • for each n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} and each plot ‚Ñù n‚ÜíŒ¶X\mathbb{R}^n \overset{\Phi}{\to} X an ordinary differential form

    Œ¶ *(œâ)‚ààŒ© ‚Ä¢(‚Ñù n) \Phi^\ast(\omega) \in \Omega^\bullet(\mathbb{R}^n)

such that

  • for each smooth function f:‚Ñù n 1‚Üí‚Ñù n 2f \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}^{n_1} \to \mathbb{R}^{n_2} between Cartesian spaces the ordinary pullback of differential forms along ff is compatible with these choices, in that for every plot ‚Ñù n 2‚ÜíŒ¶X\mathbb{R}^{n_2} \overset{\Phi}{\to} X we have

    f *(Œ¶ *(œâ))=(f *Œ¶) *(œâ)AAAAA‚Ñù n 1 ‚ü∂f ‚Ñù n 2 f *Œ¶‚Üò ‚Üô Œ¶ XAAŒ© ‚Ä¢(‚Ñù n 1) ‚üµf * Œ© ‚Ä¢(‚Ñù n 2) (f *Œ¶) *‚Üñ ‚Üó Œ¶ * Œ© ‚Ä¢(X). f^\ast\left(\Phi^\ast(\omega)\right) = ( f^\ast \Phi )^\ast(\omega) \phantom{AAAAA} \array{ \mathbb{R}^{n_1} && \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} && \mathbb{R}^{n_2} \\ & {}_{\mathllap{f^\ast \Phi}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\Phi}} \\ && X } \phantom{AA} \array{ \Omega^\bullet( \mathbb{R}^{n_1} ) && \overset{f^\ast}{\longleftarrow} && \Omega^\bullet(\mathbb{R}^{n_2}) \\ & {}_{\mathllap{(f^\ast \Phi)^\ast}}\nwarrow && \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\Phi^\ast}} \\ && \Omega^\bullet(X) } \,.

We write Œ© ‚Ä¢(X)\Omega^\bullet(X) for the set of differential forms on the diffeological space XX defined this way.

The usual operations on ordinary differential forms directly generalize plot-wise to differential forms on diffeological spaces:

Definition

(exterior differential and exterior product on diffeological spaces)

Let XX be a diffeological space (def. 2). Then

  1. For œâ‚ààŒ© n(X)\omega \in \Omega^n(X) a differential form on XX (def. 3) its exterior differential

    dœâ‚ààŒ© n+1(X) d \omega \in \Omega^{n+1}(X)

    is defined on any plot ‚Ñù n‚ÜíŒ¶X\mathbb{R}^n \overset{\Phi}{\to} X as the ordinary exterior differential of the pullback of œâ\omega along that plot:

    Œ¶ *(dœâ)‚âîdŒ¶ *(œâ). \Phi^\ast(d \omega) \coloneqq d \Phi^\ast(\omega) \,.

  2. For œâ 1‚ààŒ© n 1\omega_1 \in \Omega^{n_1} and œâ 2‚ààŒ© n 2(X)\omega_2 \in \Omega^{n_2}(X) two differential forms on XX (def. 3) then their exterior product

    œâ 1‚àßœâ 2‚ààŒ© n 1+n 2(X) \omega_1 \wedge \omega_2 \;\in\; \Omega^{n_1 + n_2}(X)

    is the differential form defined on any plot ‚Ñù n‚ÜíŒ¶X\mathbb{R}^n \overset{\Phi}{\to} X as the ordinary exterior product of the pullback of th differential forms œâ 1\omega_1 and œâ 2\omega_2 to this plot:

    Œ¶ *(œâ 1‚àßœâ 2)‚âîŒ¶ *(œâ 1)‚àßŒ¶ *(œâ 2). \Phi^\ast(\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2) \;\coloneqq\; \Phi^\ast(\omega_1) \wedge \Phi^\ast(\omega_2) \,.

Field variations

Given a field bundle as in def. 1 above, then we know what type of quantities the corresponding fields assign to a given spacetime point (event). Among all consistent such field configurations, some are to qualify as those that ‚Äúmay occur in reality‚Äù if we think of the field theory as a means to describe parts of the observable universe. Moreover, if the reality to be described does not exhibit ‚Äúaction at a distance‚Äù then admissibility of its field configurations should be determined over arbitrary small spacetime regions, in fact over the infinitesimal neighbourhood of any spacetime point. This means equivalently that the realized field configurations should be those that satisfy a given differential equation, hence an equation between the value of the derivatives of the field configuration at any spacetime point.

In order to formalize this, it is useful to first collect all the possible derivatives that a field may have at any given point into one big space of ‚Äúfield derivatives at spacetime points‚Äù. This collection is called the jet bundle of the field bundle, given as def. 5 below.

Moving around in this space means to change the possible value of fields and their derivatives, hence to vary the fields. Accordingly variational calculus of fields is just differential calculus on the jet bundle of the field bundle, this we consider in def. 8 below.

Definition

(jet bundle of a trivial vector bundle over Minkowski spacetime)

Given a field fiber vector space F=‚Ñù sF = \mathbb{R}^s with linear basis (œï a) a=1 s(\phi^a)_{a = 1}^s, then for k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} a natural number, the order-kk jet bundle

J Œ£ k(E) ‚Üì jb k Œ£ \array{ J^k_{\Sigma}( E ) \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{jb_k}} \\ \Sigma }

over Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma of the trivial vector bundle

E‚âîŒ£√óF E \coloneqq \Sigma \times F

is the Cartesian space which is spanned by coordinate functions to be denoted as follows:

((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),(œï ,Œº 1Œº 2 a),‚ãØ,(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a),‚ãØ) \left( (x^\mu) \,,\, (\phi^a ) \,,\, ( \phi^a_{,\mu} ) \,,\, ( \phi^a_{,\mu_1\mu_2} ) \,,\, \cdots \,,\, ( \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} ) \,,\, \cdots \right)

where the indices Œº,Œº 1,Œº 2,‚ãØ\mu, \mu_1, \mu_2, \cdots range from 0 to pp, while the index aa ranges from 11 to ss. In terms of these coordinates the bundle projection map jb kjb_k is just the one that remembers the spacetime coordinates x Œºx^\mu and forgets the values of the field œï a\phi^a and its derivatives œï Œº\phi_{\mu}. Similarly there are intermediate projection maps

‚ãØ ‚ü∂jb 3,2 J Œ£ 2(E) ‚ü∂jb 2,1 J Œ£ 1(E) ‚ü∂jb 1 E jb 2‚Üò jb 1‚Üì ‚Üô fb Œ£ \array{ \cdots &\overset{jb_{3,2}}{\longrightarrow}& J^{2}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{jb_{2,1}}{\longrightarrow}& J^1_\Sigma(E) &\overset{jb_1}{\longrightarrow}& E \\ && &{}_{\mathllap{jb_2}}\searrow& {}^{\mathllap{jb_1}}\downarrow &\swarrow_{\mathrlap{fb}}& \\ && && \Sigma && }

given by forgetting coordinates with more indices.

The infinite-order jet bundle

J Œ£ ‚àû(E)‚ààH J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \in \mathbf{H}

is the direct limit over these finite order jet bundles, formed in the category of smooth sets. This means that it is the smooth set which is defined by the fact that a smooth function

U‚ü∂fJ Œ£ ‚àû(E) U \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} J^\infty_\Sigma(E)

from some Cartesian space UU is equivalently a system of ordinary smooth functions into all the finite-order jet spaces

(U‚ü∂f kJ Œ£ k(E)) k‚àà‚Ñï, \left( U \overset{f_k}{\longrightarrow} J^k_\Sigma(E) \right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}} \,,

such that this system is compatible with the above projection maps, i.e. such that

‚àÄk‚àà‚Ñï(jb k+1,k‚àòf k+1=f k)AAAAAAA U f 2‚Üô f 1‚Üì ‚Üò f 0 ‚ãØ ‚ü∂jb 3,2 J Œ£ 2(E) ‚ü∂jb 2,1 J Œ£ 1(E) ‚ü∂jb 1 E jb 2‚Üò jb 1‚Üì ‚Üô fb Œ£ \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\forall} \left( jb_{k+1,k} \circ f_{k+1} = f_k \right) \phantom{AAAAAAA} \array{ && && U && \\ && & {}^{\mathllap{f_2}}\swarrow& {}_{\mathllap{f_1}}\downarrow &\searrow^{f_0}& \\ \cdots &\overset{jb_{3,2}}{\longrightarrow}& J^{2}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{jb_{2,1}}{\longrightarrow}& J^1_\Sigma(E) &\overset{jb_1}{\longrightarrow}& E \\ && &{}_{\mathllap{jb_2}}\searrow& {}^{\mathllap{jb_1}}\downarrow &\swarrow_{\mathrlap{fb}}& \\ && && \Sigma && }
Definition

(jet prolongation)

The smooth function from the space of sections of the original bundle to the space of sections of the jet bundle which records the field Œ¶\Phi and all its spacetimes derivatives is called jet prolongation:

Œì Œ£(E) ‚ü∂j Œ£ ‚àû Œì Œ£(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) (Œ¶ a) ‚Ü¶ ((Œ¶ a),(‚àÇŒ¶ a‚àÇx Œº),(‚àÇ 2Œ¶ a‚àÇx Œº 1‚àÇx Œº 2),‚ãØ). \array{ \Gamma_\Sigma(E) &\overset{j^\infty_\Sigma}{\longrightarrow}& \Gamma_\Sigma(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \\ (\Phi^a) &\mapsto& \left( \left( \Phi^a \right) \,,\, \left( \frac{\partial \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu} \right) \,,\, \left( \frac{\partial^2 \Phi^a}{\partial x^{\mu_1} \partial x^{\mu_2}} \right) \,,\, \cdots \right) } \,.

So the canonical coordinates on the jet bundle are the spacetime-point-wise possible values of fields and field derivates, while the jet prolongation picks the actual collections of field derivatives that may occur for an actual field history.

Example

(universal Faraday tensor/field strength on jet bundle)

Consider the field bundle (def. 1) of the electromagnetic field (example 4) over Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma, i.e. the cotangent bundle E=T *Œ£E = T^\ast \Sigma with jet coordinates ((x Œº),(a Œº),(a Œº,ŒΩ),‚ãØ)((x^\mu), (a_\mu), (a_{\mu,\nu}), \cdots ). Consider the functions on its jet bundle given by the linear combinations

(5)f ŒºŒΩ‚âî12(a Œº,ŒΩ‚àía ŒΩ,Œº) f_{\mu \nu} \;\coloneqq\; \tfrac{1}{2}\left( a_{\mu,\nu} - a_{\nu,\mu} \right)

of the first order jets.

Then for an electromagnetic field history (‚Äúvector potential‚Äù), hence a section

A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£)=Œ© 1(Œ£) A \in \Gamma_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma) = \Omega^1(\Sigma)

with components A *(a Œº)=A ŒºA^\ast (a_\mu) = A_\mu, its jet prolongation (def. 6)

j Œ£ ‚àû(A)‚ààŒì Œ£(J Œ£ ‚àû(T *Œ£)) j^\infty_\Sigma(A) \in \Gamma_\Sigma(J^\infty_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma))

has components

((A Œº),(dA Œºdx ŒΩ),‚ãØ). \left( (A_\mu), \left( \frac{d A_\mu}{d x^\nu} \right) , \cdots \right) \,.

The pullback of the functions f ŒºŒΩf_{\mu \nu} (5) along this jet prolongation are the components of the Faraday tensor of the field (2):

(j Œ£ ‚àû(A)) *(f ŒºŒΩ) =F ŒºŒΩ =(dA) ŒºŒΩ. \begin{aligned} \left(j^\infty_\Sigma(A)\right)^\ast(f_{\mu \nu}) & = F_{\mu \nu} \\ & = (d A)_{\mu \nu} \,. \end{aligned}

More generally, for ùî§\mathfrak{g} a Lie algebra and

E‚âîT *Œ£‚äóùî§ E \coloneqq T^\ast \Sigma \otimes \mathfrak{g}

the field bundle for Yang-Mills theory from example 5, consider the functions on the jet bundle given by

D_\mu a_\nu^\alpha \;\coloneqq\; a^\alpha_{\nu,\mu} + \tfrac{1}{2} \gamma^{\alpha}{}_{\beta \gamma} a^\beta_{\mu}} a^\gamma_{\nu} - (\mu \leftrightarrow \nu)

where (Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥) D_\mu a_\nu^\alpha \;\coloneqq\; a^\alpha_{\nu,\mu} + \tfrac{1}{2} \gamma^{\alpha}{}_{\beta \gamma} a^\beta_{\mu}}(\gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma}) the structure constants of the Lie algebra as in (3) and where the square brackets around the indices denote anti-symmetrization. For ùî§=‚Ñù\mathfrak{g} = \mathbb{R} the line Lie algebra this reduces to the universal Faraday tensor (5) for the electromagnetic field (example 8).

For A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£‚äóùî§)=Œ© 1(Œ£,ùî§)A \in \Gamma_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma \otimes \mathfrak{g}) = \Omega^1(\Sigma,\mathfrak{g}) a field history of Yang-Mills theory, hence a Lie algebra-valued differential 1-form, then the value of this function on that field are called the components of the covariant exterior derivative or field strength

F ŒºŒΩ ‚âîA *(D Œºa n) =(d AA) ŒºŒΩ \begin{aligned} F_{\mu \nu} & \coloneqq A^\ast(D_\mu a_n) \\ & = (d_A A)_{\mu \nu} \end{aligned}

While the jet bundle is not finite dimensional, reflecting the fact that there are arbitrarily high orders of spacetime derivatives of a field configurations, it turns out that it is only very ‚Äúmildly infinite dimensional‚Äù in that smooth functions on jet bundles turn out to locally depend on only finitely many of the jet coordinates (i.e. only on a finite order of spacetime derivatives). This is the content of the following prop. 2. In practice this means that the situation is very convenient:

  1. Any given local Lagrangian density (which will define a field theory, we come to this in def. 9 below) will locally depend on some finite number kk of derivatives and may hence locally be treated as living on the ordinary manifold J Œ£ k(E)J^k_\Sigma(E).

  2. while at the same time all formulas (such as for the Euler-Lagrange equations, def. 17) work uniformly without worries about fixing a maximal order of derivatives.

Proposition

(jet bundle is a locally pro-manifold)

Given a jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) as in def. 5, then a smooth function out of it

J Œ£ ‚àû(E)‚ü∂X J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \longrightarrow X

is such that around each point of J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) there is a neighbourhood U‚äÇJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)U \subset J^\infty_\Sigma(E) on which it is given by a function on a smooth function on J Œ£ k(E)J^k_\Sigma(E) for some finite kk.

(see Khavkine-Schreiber 17, section 2.2 and 3.3)

Example 8 shows that the de Rham differential may be encoded in terms of composing jet prolongation with a suitable function on the jet bundle. More generally, jet prolongation neatly encodes (possibly non-linear) differential operators:

Definition

(differential operator)

Let E 1‚Üífb 1Œ£E_1 \overset{fb_1}{\to} \Sigma and E 2‚Üífb 2Œ£E_2 \overset{fb_2}{\to} \Sigma be two smooth fiber bundles over a common base space Œ£\Sigma. Then a (possibly non-linear) differential operator from sections of E 1E_1 to sections of E 2E_2 is a bundle morphism from the jet bundle of E 1E_1 (def. 5) to E 2E_2:

J Œ£ ‚àû(E 1) ‚ü∂DÀú E 2 ‚Üò ‚Üô Œ£ \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma(E_1) && \overset{\tilde D}{\longrightarrow} && E_2 \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \Sigma }

or rather the function DD between the spaces of sections of these bundles which this induces after composition with jet prolongation (def. 6):

D:Œì Œ£(E 1)‚ü∂j Œ£ ‚àûŒì Œ£(J Œ£ ‚àû(E 1))‚ü∂DÀú‚àò(‚àí)Œì Œ£(E 2). D \;\colon\; \Gamma_\Sigma(E_1) \overset{j^\infty_\Sigma}{\longrightarrow} \Gamma_\Sigma(J^\infty_\Sigma(E_1)) \overset{\tilde D \circ (-)}{\longrightarrow} \Gamma_\Sigma(E_2) \,.
Remark

(variational calculus ‚Äì replacing plain bundle morphisms by differential operators)

Various concepts in variational calculus, especially the concept of evolutionary vector fields (def. 11 below) and gauge parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries (def. 28 below) follow from concepts in plain differential geometry by systematically replacing plain bundle morphisms by bundle morphisms out of the jet bundle, hence by differential operators DÀú\tilde D as in def. 7.

Definition

(variational derivative and total spacetime derivative ‚Äì the variational bicomplex)

On the jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) of a trivial vector bundle over Minkowski spacetime as in def. 5 we may consider its de Rham complex of differential forms; we write its de Rham differential in boldface:

d:Œ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢+1(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)). \mathbf{d} \;\colon\; \Omega^\bullet(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet+1}(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \,.

Since the jet bundle unified spacetime with field values, we want to decompose this differential into a contribution coming from forming the total derivatives of fields along spacetime (‚Äúhorizontal derivatives‚Äù), and actual variation of fields at a fixed spacetime point (‚Äúvertical derivatives‚Äù):

The total spacetime derivative or horizontal derivative on J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) is the map on differential forms on the jet bundle of the form

d:Œ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢+1(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) d \;\colon\; \Omega^\bullet( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) ) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet+1}( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) )

which on functions f:J Œ£ ‚àû(E)‚Üí‚Ñùf \colon J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \to \mathbb{R} (i.e. on 0-forms) is defined by

(6)df ‚âîdfdx Œºdx Œº ‚âî‚àëŒº=0p(‚àÇf‚àÇx Œº+‚àÇf‚àÇœï aœï ,Œº a+‚àÇf‚àÇœï ,ŒΩ aœï ,ŒΩŒº a+‚ãØ)dx Œº \begin{aligned} d f & \coloneqq \frac{d f}{d x^\mu} \mathbf{d} x^\mu \\ & \coloneqq \underoverset{\mu = 0}{p}{\sum} \left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^\mu} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi^a} \phi^a_{,\mu} + \frac{ \partial f }{ \partial \phi^a_{,\nu}} \phi^a_{,\nu \mu } + \cdots \right) \mathbf{d} x^\mu \end{aligned}

and extended to all forms by the graded Leibniz rule, hence as a nilpotent derivation of degree +1.

The variational derivative or vertical derivative

(7)Œ¥:Œ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢+1(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) \delta \;\colon\; \Omega^\bullet( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) ) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet+1}( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) )

is what remains of the full de Rham differential when the total spacetime derivative (horizontal derivative) is subtracted:

Œ¥‚âîd‚àíd. \delta \coloneqq \mathbf{d} - d \,.

This defines a bigrading on the de Rham complex of J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E), into horizontal degree rr and vertical degree ss

Œ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚âî‚äïr,sŒ© r,s(E) \Omega^\bullet\left( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \right) \;\coloneqq\; \underset{r,s}{\oplus} \Omega^{r,s}(E)

such that the horizontal and vertical derivative increase horizontal or vertical degree, respectively:

(8)C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))= Œ© 0,0(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ 1,0(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ 2,0(E) ‚ü∂d ‚ãØ ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ p+1,0(E) ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚ãØ ‚Üì Œ¥ Œ© Œ£ 0,1(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ 1,1(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ 2,1(E) ‚ü∂d ‚ãØ ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ p+1,1(E) ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚ãØ ‚Üì Œ¥ Œ© 0,2(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© 1,2(E) ‚ü∂d Œ© 2,2(E) ‚ü∂d ‚ãØ ‚ü∂d Œ© Œ£ p+1,2(E) ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚ãØ ‚Üì Œ¥ ‚ãÆ ‚ãÆ ‚ãÆ. \array{ C^\infty(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) = & \Omega^{0,0}(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{1,0}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{2,0}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \cdots &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \cdots && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} \\ & \Omega^{0,1}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{1,1}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{2,1}_\Sigma(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \cdots &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{p+1,1}_\Sigma(E) \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \cdots && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} \\ & \Omega^{0,2}(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{1,2}(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{2,2}(E) &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \cdots &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \Omega^{p+1,2}_\Sigma(E) \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} && \cdots && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\delta}} \\ & \vdots && \vdots && \vdots } \,.

This is called the variational bicomplex.

Accordingly we will refer to the differential forms on the jet bundle often as variational differential forms.

\,

derivatives on jet bundle

def.symbolsname in physicsname in mathematics
d\; \mathbf{d}de Rham differentialde Rham differential
8d‚âîdx Œºddx Œº\; d \coloneqq d x^\mu \frac{d}{d x^\mu}total spacetime derivativehorizontal derivative
8ddx Œº‚âî‚àÇ‚àÇx Œº+œï ,Œº a‚àÇ‚àÇœï a+‚ãØ \; \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \coloneqq \frac{\partial}{\partial x^\mu} + \phi^a_{,\mu} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} + \cdots total spacetime derivative along ‚àÇ Œº\partial_\muhorizontal derivative along ‚àÇ Œº\partial_\mu
8Œ¥‚âîd‚àíd\; \delta \coloneqq \mathbf{d} - dvariational derivativevertical derivative
4Œ¥ ELL‚âîdL+dŒò\; \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} \coloneqq \mathbf{d}\mathbf{L} + d \ThetaEuler-Lagrange variationEuler-Lagrange operator
20s BV\; s_{BV}BV-differentialKoszul differential
30s BRST\; s_{BRST} BRST differentialChevalley-Eilenberg differential
24s\; s BV-BRST differentialChevalley-Eilenberg-Koszul-Tate differential
38s‚àíd\; s - d local BV-BRST differential

\,

Example

(basic facts about variational calculus)

Given the jet bundle of a field bundle as in def. 5, then in its variational bicomplex (def. 8) we have the following:

  • The spacetime total derivative (horizontal derivative) of a spacetime coordinate function x Œºx^\mu coincides with its ordinary de Rham differential

    dx Œº =‚àÇx Œº‚àÇx ŒΩdx ŒΩ =dx Œº \begin{aligned} d x^\mu & = \frac{\partial x^\mu}{ \partial x^\nu} \mathbf{d}x^\nu \\ & = \mathbf{d} x^\mu \end{aligned}

    which hence is a horizontal 1-form

    dx Œº‚ààŒ© Œ£ 1,0(E). \mathbf{d}x^\mu \;\in\; \Omega^{1,0}_\Sigma(E) \,.

  • Therefore the variational derivative (vertical derivative) of a spacetime coordinate function vanishes:

    Œ¥x Œº=0, \delta x^\mu = 0 \,,

    reflective the fact that x Œºx^\mu is not a field coordinate that could be varied.

  • In particular the given volume form on Œ£\Sigma gives a horizontal p+1p+1-form on the jet bundle, which has the same coordinate expression (and which we denote by the same symbol)

    dvol Œ£=dx 0‚àßdx 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßdx p‚ààŒ© p+1,0. dvol_\Sigma = d x^0 \wedge d x^1 \wedge \cdots \wedge d x^p \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0} \,.

  • Generally any horizontal kk-form is of the form

    f Œº 1‚ãØŒº kdx Œº 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßdx Œº k‚ààŒ© Œ£ k,0(E) f_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} d x^{\mu_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d x^{\mu_k} \;\in\; \Omega^{k,0}_{\Sigma}(E)

    for

    f Œº 1‚ãØŒº k=f Œº 1‚ãØŒº k((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ)‚ààC ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) f_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} = f_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}\left((x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots\right) \in C^\infty(J^\infty_\Sigma(E))

    any smooth function of the spacetime coordinates and the field coordinates (locally depending only on a finite order of these, by prop. 2).

  • In particular every horizontal (p+1)(p+1)-form L‚ààŒ© p+1,0(E)\mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p+1,0}(E) is proportional to the above volume form

    L=Ldvol Œ£ \mathbf{L} = L \, dvol_\Sigma

    for L=L((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ)L = L((x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots) some smooth function that may depend on all the spacetime and field coordinates.

  • The spacetimes total derivatives /horizontal derivatives) of the variational derivative (vertical derivative) Œ¥œï\delta \phi of a field variable is the differential 2-form of horizontal degree 1 and vertical degree 2 given by

    d(Œ¥œï a) =‚àíŒ¥(dœï a) =‚àí(Œ¥œï ,Œº a)‚àßdx Œº. \begin{aligned} d (\delta \phi^a) & = - \delta (d \phi_a) \\ & = - (\delta \phi^a_{,\mu}) \wedge \mathbf{d} x^\mu \end{aligned} \,.

    In words this says that ‚Äúthe spacetime derivative of the variation of the field is the variation of its spacetime derivative‚Äù.

Proposition

(pullback along jet prolongation compatible with total spacetime derivatives)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle over a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 1), with induced jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E)

Then for Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E)\Phi \in \Gamma_\Sigma(E) any field configuration, the pullback of differential forms

j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *:Œ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢(Œ£) j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \;\colon\; \Omega^\bullet(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \longrightarrow \Omega^\bullet(\Sigma)

along the jet prolongation of Œ¶\Phi (def. 6):

  1. intertwines the de Rham differential on spacetime with the total spacetime derivative (horizontal derivative) on the jet bundle:

    d‚àòj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *=j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *‚àòd. d \circ j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \;=\; j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \circ d \,.

  2. annihilates all vertical differential forms

    j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *| Œ© Œ£ r,‚â•1(E)=0. j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast\vert_{\Omega^{r, \geq 1}_\Sigma(E)} = 0 \,.
Proof

Notice that generally the operation of pullback of differential forms along any smooth function intertwines the full de Rham differentials. In particular we have on general grounds that

d‚àòj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *=j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *‚àòd. d \circ j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast = j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \circ \mathbf{d} \,.

This means that the second statement immediately follows from the first, by definition of the variational (vertical) derivative as the differece between the full de Rham differential and the horizontal one:

j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *‚àòŒ¥ =j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *‚àò(d‚àíd) =(d‚àíd)‚àòj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) * =0 \begin{aligned} j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \circ \delta & = j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \circ (\mathbf{d} - d) \\ & = (d - d) \circ j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

It remains to see the first statement:

Since the jet prolongation j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶)j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi) preserves the spacetime coordinates x Œºx^\mu (being a section of the jet bundle) it is immediate that the claimed relation is satisfied on the horizontal basis 1-forms dx Œº=dx Œº\mathbf{d}x^\mu = d x^\mu (example 9):

dj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *(dx Œº)=d 2x Œº=0AAAAAj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *ddx Œº=j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *d 2x Œº. d j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast( \mathbf{d}x^\mu ) = d^2 x^\mu = 0 \phantom{AAAAA} j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast d \mathbf{d} x^\mu = j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast d^2 x^\mu \,.

Therefore it finally remains only to check the first statement on smooth functions (0-forms). So let

f=f((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ) f = f\left( (x^\mu) \,,\, (\phi^a) \,,\, ( \phi^a_{,\mu} ) \,,\, \cdots \right)

be a smooth function on the jet bundle. Then by the chain rule

dj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *f((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ) =df((x Œº),(Œ¶ a),(‚àÇŒ¶ a‚àÇx Œº),‚ãØ) =(‚àÇf‚àÇx Œº+‚àÇf‚àÇœï a‚àÇŒ¶ a‚àÇx Œº+‚àÇf‚àÇœï ,ŒΩ a‚àÇ 2Œ¶ a‚àÇx ŒΩ‚àÇx Œº+‚ãØ)dx Œº \begin{aligned} d j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast f\left( (x^\mu) \,,\, (\phi^a) \,,\, ( \phi^a_{,\mu} ) \,,\, \cdots \right) & = d f\left( (x^\mu) \,,\, (\Phi^a) \,,\, \left( \frac{\partial \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu} \right) \,,\, \cdots \right) \\ & = \left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^\mu} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi^a} \frac{\partial \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu}} \frac{\partial^2 \Phi^a}{\partial x^\nu \partial x^\mu} + \cdots \right) d x^\mu \end{aligned}

That this is equal to j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *dfj^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast d f follows by the very definition of the total spacetime derivative of ff (6).

Lagrangians

Given any type of fields (def. 1), those field configurations that are to be regarded as ‚Äúphysically realizable‚Äù (if we think of the field theory as a description of the observable universe) should satisfy some differential equation (the ‚Äúequation of motion‚Äù), meaning that realizability of any field configuration may be checked upon restricting the configuration to the infinitesimal neighbourhoods of each spacetime point. This expresses the physical absence of ‚Äúaction at a distance‚Äù and is one aspect of what it means to have a local field theory.

For many field theories of interest, their differential equation of motion is not a random partial differential equations, but is of the special kind that exhibits the ‚Äúprinciple of extremal action‚Äù determined by a local Lagrangian density (def. 9 below). These are called Lagrangian field theories, and this is what we consider here.

Namely among all the variational differential forms (def. 8) two kinds stand out, namley the 0-forms in Œ© Œ£ 0,0(E)\Omega^{0,0}_\Sigma(E) ‚Äì the smooth functions ‚Äì and the horizontal p+1p+1-forms Œ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)\Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) ‚Äì to be called the Lagrangian densities L\mathbf{L} (def. 9 below) ‚Äì since these occupy the two ‚Äúcorners‚Äù of the variational bicomplex (8). There is not much to say about the 0-forms, but the Lagrangian densities L\mathbf{L} do inherit special structure from their special position in the variational bicomplex.

Their variational derivative uniquely decomposes as 1) the Euler-Lagrange derivative Œ¥ ELEL\delta_{EL}\mathbf{EL} which is proportional to the variation of the fields (instead of their derivatives) and 2) the total spacetime derivative dŒòd \Theta of a potential Œò\Theta for a presymplectic current Œ© BFV‚âîŒ¥Œò\Omega_{BFV} \coloneqq \delta \Theta (prop. 4 below):

Œ¥ ELL=Œ¥ ELL‚àídŒò. \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} - d \Theta \,.

These two terms play a pivotal role in the theory: they induce the covariant phase space of the field theory; this we discuss below. Before we get to that, here we discuss the symmetries of these terms, which will be important:

It turns out that every infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian density induces a variational differential form called a conserved current (Noether's theorem, prop. 9 below) and that these conserved currents constitute an extension of the Lie algebra of symmetries, called the Dickey bracket.

In direct analogy, every infinitesimal symmetry of the presymplectic potential Œò\Theta (called a Hamiltonian vector field) is witnessed by a variational differential form, called a Hamiltonian differential form (def. 14 below). This is sometimes called the Hamiltonian Noether theorem. The corresponding Lie n-algebra is the all-important Poisson bracket Lie p+1-algebra of the Lagrangian field theory. In the simple special situation that we consider here, this is a plain Lie algebra (prop. 15 below).

When we turn attention to the covariant phase space below the transgression of the Poisson bracket Lie p+1-algebra of Hamiltonian differential forms yields the Poisson bracket Lie algebra on local observables on covariant phase space. This is the all-important structure of the theory: the deformation quantization induced by this bracket is the quantum aspect of the quantum field theory.

\,

Definition

(local Lagrangian density)

Given a field bundle EE over a (p+1)(p+1)-dimensional Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma as in example 2, then a local Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} (for the type of field thus defined) is a horizontal differential form of degree (p+1)(p+1) (def. 8) on the corresponding jet bundle (def. 5):

L‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E). \mathbf{L} \;\in \; \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma}(E) \,.

By example 9 in terms of the given volume form on spacetimes, any such Lagrangian density may uniquely be written as

L=Ldvol Œ£ \mathbf{L} = L \, dvol_\Sigma

where the coefficient function (the Lagrangian function) is a smooth function on the spacetime and field coordinates:

L=L((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ). L = L((x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots ) \,.

where by prop. 2 L((x Œº),‚ãØ)L((x^\mu), \cdots) depends locally on an arbitrary but finite order of derivatives œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}.

We say that a field bundle E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma (def. 1) equipped with a local Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is (or defines) a prequantum [Lagrangian field theory]] on the spacetime Œ£\Sigma.

(Over more general field bundles than we consider at the moment, the Lagrangian density may not exist as a globally defined differential (p+1)(p+1)-form, but as a p-gerbe connection. This is the case for locally variational field theories such as theories involving higher WZW terms.)

Example

(local Lagrangian density for free real scalar field on Minkowski spacetime)

Consider the field bundle for the real scalar field from example 3, i.e. the trivial line bundle over Minkowski spacetime.

According to def. 5 its jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) has canonical coordinates

{{x Œº},œï,{œï ,Œº},{œï ,Œº 1Œº 2},‚ãØ}. \{ \{x^\mu\}, \phi, \{\phi_{,\mu}\}, \{\phi_{,\mu_1 \mu_2}\}, \cdots \} \,.

In these coordinates, the local Lagrangian density L‚ààŒ© p+1,0(Œ£)L \in \Omega^{p+1,0}(\Sigma) (def. 9) defining the free real scalar field of mass m‚àà[0,‚àû)m \in [0,\infty) on Œ£\Sigma is

L‚âî12(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,Œºœï ,ŒΩ+m 2œï 2)dvol Œ£. L \coloneqq \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \phi_{,\nu} + m^2 \phi^2 \right) \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \,.
Example

(local Lagrangian density for free electromagnetism and Yang-Mills theory)

Consider the field bundle T *Œ£‚ÜíŒ£T^\ast \Sigma \to \Sigma for the electromagnetic field on Minkowski spacetime from example 4, i.e. the cotangent bundle, which over Minkowski spacetime happens to be a trivial vector bundle of rank p+1p+1. With fiber coordinates taken to be (a Œº) Œº=0 p(a_\mu)_{\mu = 0}^p, the induced fiber coordinates on the corresponding jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(T *Œ£)J^\infty_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma) (def. 5) are ((x Œº),(a Œº),(a Œº,ŒΩ),(a Œº,ŒΩ 1ŒΩ 2),‚ãØ)( (x^\mu), (a_\mu), (a_{\mu,\nu}), (a_{\mu,\nu_1 \nu_2}), \cdots ).

Consider then the local Lagrangian density (def. 9) given by

(9)L‚âî12f ŒºŒΩf ŒºŒΩdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(T *Œ£), \mathbf{L} \;\coloneqq\; \tfrac{1}{2} f_{\mu \nu} f^{\mu \nu} dvol_\Sigma \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma) \,,

where f ŒºŒΩ‚âî12(a Œº,ŒΩ‚àía ŒΩ,Œº)f_{\mu \nu} \coloneqq \tfrac{1}{2}(a_{\mu,\nu} - a_{\nu,\mu}) are the components of the universal Faraday tensor on the jet bundle from example 8.

This is the Lagrangian density that defines the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism.

Here for A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£)A \in \Gamma_\Sigma(T^\ast \Sigma) an electromagnetic field history (vector potential), then the pullback of f ŒºŒΩf_{\mu \nu} along its jet prolongation (def. 6) is the corresponding component of the Faraday tensor (2):

(j Œ£ ‚àû(A)) *(f ŒºŒΩ) =(dA) ŒºŒΩ =F ŒºŒΩ \begin{aligned} \left( j^\infty_\Sigma(A) \right)^\ast(f_{\mu \nu}) & = (d A)_{\mu \nu} \\ & = F_{\mu \nu} \end{aligned}

It follows that the pullback of the Lagrangian (9) along the jet prologation of the electromagnetic field is

(j Œ£ ‚àû(A)) *L =12F ŒºŒΩF ŒºŒΩdvol Œ£ =12F‚àß Œ∑‚ãÜF \begin{aligned} \left( j^\infty_\Sigma(A) \right)^\ast \mathbf{L} & = \tfrac{1}{2} F_{\mu \nu} F^{\mu \nu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = \tfrac{1}{2} F \wedge_\eta \star F \end{aligned}

Here ‚ãÜ Œ∑\star_\eta denotes the Hodge star operator of Minkowski spacetime.

More generally, for ùî§\mathfrak{g} a Lie algebra and E=T *Œ£‚äóùî§E = T^\ast \Sigma \otimes \mathfrak{g} the field bundle for Yang-Mills theory as in example 5.

The beauty of Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) is that a choice of Lagrangian density determines both the equations of motion of the fields as well as a presymplectic structure on the space of solutions to this equation (the ‚Äúshell‚Äù), making it the ‚Äúcovariant phase space‚Äù of the theory. All this we discuss below. But in fact all this key structure of the field theory is othing but the shadow (under ‚Äútransgression of variational differential forms‚Äù, def. 16 below)

Proposition

(Euler-Lagrange variational derivative and presymplectic current)

Given a Lagrangian density L‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)\mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) as in def. 9, then its de Rham differential has a unique decomposition as a sum of two terms

(10)dL=Œ¥ ELL‚àídŒò \mathbf{d} \mathbf{L} = \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} - d \Theta

such that Œ¥EL\delta EL is proportional to the variational derivative of the fields (but not their derivatives, called a ‚Äúsource form‚Äù):

Œ¥ ELL‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)‚àßŒ¥C ‚àû(E)‚äÇŒ© Œ£ p+1,1(E). \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma}(E) \wedge \delta C^\infty(E) \;\subset\; \Omega^{p+1,1}_{\Sigma}(E) \,.

The map

Œ¥ EL:Œ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)‚ü∂Œ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)‚àßŒ¥Œ© Œ£ 0,0(E) \delta_{EL} \;\colon\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma}(E) \longrightarrow \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma}(E) \wedge \delta \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma}(E)

thus defined is called the Euler-Lagrange operator and is explicitly given by

Œ¥ ELLdvol Œ£ ‚âîŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï aŒ¥œï a‚àßdvol Œ£ ‚âî(‚àÇL‚àÇœï a‚àíddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº a+d 2dx Œº 1dx Œº 2‚àÇL‚àÇœï Œº 1,Œº 2 a‚àí‚ãØ)Œ¥œï a‚àßdvol Œ£. \begin{aligned} \delta_{EL} L \, dvol_\Sigma & \coloneqq \frac{\delta_{EL} L}{\delta \phi^a} \delta \phi^a \wedge dvol_\Sigma \\ & \coloneqq \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a} - \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} + \frac{d^2}{d x^{\mu_1} d x^{\mu_2}} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{\mu_1, \mu_2}} - \cdots \right) \delta \phi^a \wedge dvol_\Sigma \,. \end{aligned}

The smooth subspace of the jet bundle on which the Euler-Lagrange form vanishes

(11)‚Ñ∞‚âî{x‚ààJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)|Œ¥ ELL| x=0}‚äÇJ Œ£ ‚àû(E). \mathcal{E} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ x \in J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \;\vert\; \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}\vert_x = 0 \right\} \;\subset\; J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \,.

is called the shell. The smaller subspace on which also all total spacetime derivatives vanish (the ‚Äúformally integrable prolongation‚Äù) is the prolonged shell

(12)‚Ñ∞ ‚àû‚âî{q‚ààJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)|(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº kŒ¥ ELL)| x=0}‚äÇJ Œ£ ‚àû(E). \mathcal{E}^\infty \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ q \in J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \;\vert\; \left( \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \right)\vert_x = 0 \right\} \;\subset\; J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \,.

Saying something holds ‚Äúon-shell‚Äù is to mean that it holds after restriction to this subspace. For example a variational differential form Œ±‚ààŒ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E)\alpha \in \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E) is said to vanish on shell if Œ±| ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû=0\alpha\vert_{\mathcal{E}^\infty} = 0.

The remaining term dŒòd \Theta in (10) is unique, while the ‚Äúpresymplectic potential‚Äù

(13)Œò‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,1(E) \Theta \in \Omega^{p,1}_{\Sigma}(E)

is unique only up to terms dŒ±d \alpha in the image of dd. One possible choice is

(14)Œò ‚âî+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï a‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ =+(‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ a‚àíddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥œï ,Œº a)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ =+‚ãØ, \begin{aligned} \Theta & \coloneqq \phantom{+} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a \; \wedge \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & \phantom{=} + \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\nu} - \frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & \phantom{=} + \cdots \,, \end{aligned}

where

Œπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£‚âî(‚àí1) Œºdx 0‚àß‚ãØdx Œº‚àí1‚àßdx Œº+1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßdx p \iota_{\partial_{\mu}} dvol_\Sigma \;\coloneqq\; (-1)^{\mu} d x^0 \wedge \cdots d x^{\mu-1} \wedge d x^{\mu+1} \wedge \cdots \wedge d x^p

denotes the contraction of the volume form with the vector field ‚àÇ Œº\partial_\mu.

The vertical derivative of a chosen Œò\Theta is called a pre-symplectic current for L\mathbf{L}:

Œ© BFV‚âîŒ¥Œò‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E), \Omega_{BFV} \coloneqq \delta \Theta \;\;\; \in \Omega^{p,2}_{\Sigma}(E) \,,

which, by the above, is unique up to addition of a total spacetime derivative dŒ¥Œ±d \delta \alpha.

Given a choice of Œò\Theta then the sum

(15)L+Œò‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)‚äïŒ© Œ£ p,1(E) \mathbf{L} + \Theta \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) \oplus \Omega^{p,1}_\Sigma(E)

is called the corresponding Lepage form. Its de Rham derivative is the sum of the Euler-Lagrange variation and the presymplectic current:

(16)d(L+Œò)=Œ¥ ELL+Œ© BFV. \mathbf{d}( \mathbf{L} + \Theta ) \;=\; \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} + \Omega_{BFV} \,.
Proof

Using L=Ldvol Œ£\mathbf{L} = L dvol_\Sigma and that dL=0d \mathbf{L} = 0 by degree reasons (example 9), we find

dL =(‚àÇL‚àÇœï aŒ¥œï a+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï ,Œº a+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº 1Œº 2 aŒ¥œï ,Œº 1Œº 2 a+‚ãØ)‚àßdvol Œ£. \begin{aligned} \mathbf{d}\mathbf{L} & = \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a} \delta \phi^a + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \mu_2}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \mu_2} + \cdots \right) \wedge dvol_{\Sigma} \end{aligned} \,.

The idea now is to have dŒòd \Theta pick up those terms that would appear as boundary terms under the integral ‚à´ Œ£j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *dL\int_\Sigma j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \mathbf{d}L if we were to consider integration by parts to remove spacetime derivatives of Œ¥œï a\delta \phi^a.

We compute, using example 9, the total horizontal derivative of Œò\Theta from (14) as follows:

dŒò =(d(‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï a)+d(‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ a‚àíddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥œï a)+‚ãØ)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ =(((d‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº a)‚àßŒ¥œï a‚àí‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥dœï a)+((d‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº a)‚àßŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ a‚àí‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥dœï ,ŒΩ a‚àí(dddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ a)‚àßŒ¥œï a+ddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥dœï a)+‚ãØ)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ =‚àí((ddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï a+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï ,Œº a)+(ddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ a+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥œï ,ŒΩŒº a‚àíd 2dx Œºdx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥œï a‚àíddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥œï ,Œº a)+‚ãØ)‚àßdvol Œ£, \begin{aligned} d \Theta & = \left( d \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a \right) + d \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\nu} - \frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{\mu \nu}} \delta \phi^a \right) + \cdots \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = \left( \left( \left( d \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \right) \wedge \delta \phi^a - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta d \phi^a \right) + \left( \left(d \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}}\right) \wedge \delta \phi^a_{,\nu} - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta d \phi^a_{,\nu} - \left( d \frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \right) \wedge \delta \phi^a + \frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \delta d \phi^a \right) + \cdots \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = - \left( \left( \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} \right) + \left( \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\nu} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\nu \mu} - \frac{d^2}{ d x^\mu d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \delta \phi^a - \frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} \right) + \cdots \right) \wedge dvol_\Sigma \,, \end{aligned}

where in the last line we used that

dx Œº 1‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œº 2dvol Œ£={dvol Œ£ | ifŒº 1=Œº 2 0 | otherwise d x^{\mu_1} \wedge \iota_{\partial_{\mu_2}} dvol_\Sigma = \left\{ \array{ dvol_\Sigma &\vert& \text{if}\, \mu_1 = \mu_2 \\ 0 &\vert& \text{otherwise} } \right.

Here the two terms proportional to ddx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ aŒ¥œï ,Œº a\frac{d}{d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} cancel out, and we are left with

dŒò=‚àí(ddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº a‚àíd 2dx Œºdx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ a+‚ãØ)Œ¥œï a‚àßdvol Œ£‚àí(‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº aŒ¥œï ,Œº a+‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒΩŒº aŒ¥œï ,ŒΩŒº a+‚ãØ)‚àßdvol Œ£ d \Theta \;=\; - \left( \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} - \frac{d^2}{ d x^\mu d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu \nu}} + \cdots \right) \delta \phi^a \wedge dvol_\Sigma - \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\mu} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\nu \mu}} \delta \phi^a_{,\nu \mu} + \cdots \right) \wedge dvol_\Sigma

Hence ‚àídŒò-d \Theta shares with dL\mathbf{d} \mathbf{L} the terms that are proportional to Œ¥œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\delta \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} for k‚â•1k \geq 1, and so the remaining terms are proportional to Œ¥œï a\delta \phi^a, as claimed:

dL+dŒò=(‚àÇL‚àÇœï a‚àíddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº a+d 2dx Œºdx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ a+‚ãØ)Œ¥œï a‚àßdvol Œ£‚èü=Œ¥ ELL. \mathbf{d}L + d \Theta = \underset{ = \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a} - \frac{d}{d x^\mu}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} + \frac{d^2}{d x^\mu d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu\nu}} + \cdots \right) \delta \phi^a \wedge dvol_\Sigma }} \,.
Example

(Euler-Lagrange variational derivative and presymplectic current for free real scalar field)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of the free real scalar field from example 10.

Then the Euler-Lagrange form and presymplectic current (prop. 4) are

(17)Œ¥ ELL=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒΩ+m 2)Œ¥œï‚àßdvol œÉ‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,1(E). \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \;=\; \left(\eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu \nu} + m^2 \right) \delta \phi \wedge dvol_\sigma \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,1}_{\Sigma}(E) \,.

and

Œ© BFV=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩŒ¥œï ,Œº‚àßŒ¥œï)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E), \Omega_{BFV} \;=\; \left(\eta^{\mu \nu} \delta \phi_{,\mu} \wedge \delta \phi \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_{\Sigma} \;\in\; \Omega^{p,2}_{\Sigma}(E) \,,

respectively.

Proof

We need to show that Euler-Lagrange operator Œ¥ EL:Œ© p+1,0(Œ£)‚ÜíŒ© S p+1,1(Œ£)\delta_{EL} \colon \Omega^{p+1,0}(\Sigma) \to \Omega^{p+1,1}_S(\Sigma) takes the local Lagrangian density for the free scalar field to

Œ¥ ELL=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒΩ+m 2œï)Œ¥œï‚àßdvol Œ£. \delta_EL L \;=\; \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu \nu} + m^2 \phi \right) \delta \phi \wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \,.

First of all, the result of applying the variational derivative (vertical derivative) to the local Lagrangian density is

Œ¥L=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ+m 2œïŒ¥œï)‚àßdvol Œ£. \delta L \;=\; \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \delta \phi_{,\nu} + m^2 \phi \delta \phi \right) \wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \,.

By definition of the Euler-Lagrange operator, in order to find Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} and Œò\Theta, we need to exhibit this as the sum of the form (‚àí)‚àßŒ¥œï‚àídŒò(-) \wedge \delta \phi - d \Theta.

The key to find Œò\Theta is to realize Œ¥œï ,ŒΩ‚àßdvol Œ£\delta \phi_{,\nu}\wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma as a total spacetime derivative (horizontal derivative). Since dœï=œï ,Œºdx Œºd \phi = \phi_{,\mu} d x^\mu this is accomplished by

Œ¥œï ,ŒΩ‚àßdvol Œ£=Œ¥dœï‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£ \delta \phi_{,\nu} \wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma = \delta d \phi \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma

Hence we may take the presymplectic potential (13) of the free scalar field to be

(18)Œò‚âîŒ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒ¥œï‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£, \Theta \coloneqq \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \delta \phi \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \,,

because with this we have

dŒò=Œ∑ ŒºŒΩ(œï ,ŒºŒΩŒ¥œï‚àíŒ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒ¥œï ,ŒΩ)‚àßdvol Œ£. d \Theta = \eta^{\mu \nu} \left( \phi_{,\mu \nu} \delta \phi - \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \delta \phi_{,\nu} \right) \wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \,.

In conclusion this yields the decomposition of the vertical differential of the Lagrangian density

Œ¥L=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒΩ+m 2œï)Œ¥œï‚àßdvol Œ£‚èü=Œ¥ EL‚Ñí‚àídŒò, \delta L = \underset{ = \delta_{EL} \mathcal{L} }{ \underbrace{ \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu \nu} + m^2 \phi \right) \delta \phi \wedge \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma } } - d \Theta \,,

which shows that Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} L is as claimed, and that Œò\Theta is a presymplectic potential current (13). Hence the presymplectic current itself is

Œ© BFV ‚âîŒ¥Œò =Œ¥(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒ¥œï‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£) =(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩŒ¥œï ,Œº‚àßŒ¥œï)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£. \begin{aligned} \Omega_{BFV} &\coloneqq \delta \Theta \\ & = \delta \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \delta \phi \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} \mathrm{dvol}_\Sigma \right) \\ & = \left(\eta^{\mu \nu} \delta \phi_{,\mu} \wedge \delta \phi \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_{\Sigma} \end{aligned} \,.
Example

(Euler-Lagrange variational derivative for free electromagnetism)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism from example 11.

The Euler-Lagrange variational derivative is

Œ¥ ELL=ddx Œºf ŒºŒΩŒ¥a ŒΩ. \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} \;=\; \frac{d}{d x^\mu} f^{\mu \nu} \delta a_\nu \,.

Hence the shell (11) in this case is

‚Ñ∞=Œ£√ó{(œï,(œï ,Œº),(œï ,ŒºŒΩ)‚ãØ)|Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒΩ+m 2=0}‚äÇJ Œ£ ‚àû(Œ£√ó‚Ñù). \mathcal{E} = \Sigma \times \left\{ (\phi, (\phi_{,\mu}), (\phi_{,\mu \nu}) \cdots) \;\vert\; \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu \nu} + m^2 = 0 \right\} \;\subset\; J^\infty_\Sigma(\Sigma \times \mathbb{R}) \,.

Example 12 is a special case of the following important situation.

Example

(Euler-Lagrange variation for spacetime-independent Lagrangian densities)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle E‚âÉŒ£√óFE \simeq \Sigma \times F over Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma (example 2).

In general the Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is a function of all the spacetime and field coordinates

L=L((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ)dvol Œ£. \mathbf{L} = L((x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots) dvol_\Sigma \,.

Consider the special case that L\mathbf{L} is spacetime-independent in that the Lagrangian funtion LL is independent of the spacetime coordinate (x Œº)(x^\mu). Then the same evidently holds for the Euler-Lagrange form Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} (prop. 4). Therefore in this case the shell (12) is itself a trivial bundle over spacetime.

In this situation every point œÜ\varphi in the jet fiber defines a constant section of the shell:

(19)Œ£√ó{œÜ}‚äÇ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû. \Sigma \times \{\varphi\} \subset \mathcal{E}^\infty \,.

The following fact is immediate from prop. 4, but of central importance:

Proposition

(total spacetime derivative of presymplectic current vanishes on-shell)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9). Then the Euler-Lagrange form Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} and the presymplectic current (prop. 4) are related by

dŒ© BFV=‚àíŒ¥(Œ¥ ELL). d \Omega_{BFV} = - \delta(\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \,.

In particular this means that the total spacetime derivative of the presymplectic current vanishes on-shell (prop. 4):

dŒ© BFV| ‚Ñ∞=0. d \Omega_{BFV}\vert_{\mathcal{E}} \;=\; 0 \,.

This means that the presymplectic current is indeed a conserved current (def. 13 below) with values in differential 2-forms, whence the name.

Proof

By prop. 4 we have

Œ¥L=Œ¥ ELL‚àídŒò. \delta \mathbf{L} = \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} - d \Theta \,.

The claim follows from applying the variational derivative Œ¥\delta to both sides, using Œ¥ 2=0\delta^2 = 0 and Œ¥‚àòd=‚àíd‚àòŒ¥\delta \circ d = - d \circ \delta.

\,

Symmetries

Definition

(variation)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle (def. 1).

A variation is a vertical vector field vv on the jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) (def. 5) hence a vector field which vanishes when evaluated in the horizontal differential forms.

In the special case that the field bundle is trivial vector bundle over Minkowski spacetime as in example 2, a variation is of the form

v=v a‚àÇ œï a+v ,Œº a‚àÇ œï ,Œº a+v Œº 1Œº 2 a‚àÇ œï Œº 1Œº 2 a+‚ãØ v = v^a \partial_{\phi^a} + v^a_{,\mu} \partial_{\phi^a_{,\mu}} + v^a_{\mu_1 \mu_2} \partial_{\phi^a_{\mu_1 \mu_2}} + \cdots

The concept of variation in def. 10 is very general, in that it allows to vary the field coordinates independently from the corresponding jets. This generality is necessary for discussion of symmetries of presymplectic currents in def. 14 below. But for discussion of symmetries of Lagrangian densities we are interested in explicitly varying just the field coordinates (def. 11 below) and inducing from this the corresponding variations of the field derivatives (prop. 7) below.

In order to motivate the following definition 11 of evolutionary vector fields we follow remark 1 saying that concepts in variational calculus are obtained from their analogous concepts in plain differential calculus by replacing plain bundle morphisms by morphism out of the jet bundle:

Given a fiber bundle E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma, then a vertical vector field on EE is of course a section of its vertical vector bundle V Œ£EV_\Sigma E, hence is a bundle morphism as shown here on the left:

E ‚ü∂vertical vector field V Œ£E id‚Üò ‚Üô EAAAAAAAAAJ Œ£ ‚àûE ‚ü∂evolutionary vector field V Œ£E jb ‚àû,0‚Üò ‚Üô E \array{ E && \overset{\text{vertical vector field}}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & {}_{\mathllap{id}}\searrow && \swarrow \\ && E } \phantom{AAAAAAAAA} \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma E && \overset{\text{evolutionary vector field}}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & {}_{jb_{\infty,0}}\searrow && \swarrow \\ && E }

The variational version replaces the vector bundle on the left here with its jet bundle:

Definition

(evolutionary vector fields)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a fiber bundle. Then an evolutionary vector field vv on EE is a a ‚Äúvariational vertical vector field‚Äù on EE, hence a smooth bundle homomorphism out of the jet bundle (def. 5)

J Œ£ ‚àûE ‚ü∂v V Œ£E jb ‚àû,0‚Üò ‚Üô E \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma E && \overset{v}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & {}_{\mathllap{jb_{\infty,0}}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathllap{}} \\ && E }

to the vertical vector bundle V Œ£E‚ÜíŒ£V_\Sigma E \overset{}{\to} \Sigma of E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma.

We write

Œì E ev(V Œ£E)‚ààŒ© Œ£ 0,0(E)Mod \Gamma_E^{ev}\left( V_\Sigma E \right) \;\in\; \Omega^{0,0}_\Sigma(E) Mod

for the space of evolutionary vector fields, regarded as a module over the ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-algebra

Œ© Œ£ 0,0(E)=C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) \Omega^{0,0}_\Sigma(E) \;=\; C^\infty\left( J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \right)

of smooth functions on the jet bundle.

An evolutionary vector field (def. 11) describes an infinitesimal change of field values depending on, possibly, the point in spacetime and the values of the field and all its derivatives (locally to finite order, by prop. 2).

This induces a corresponding infinitesimal change of the derivatives of the fields, called the prolongation of the evolutionary vector field:

Proposition

(prolongation of evolutionary vector field)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a fiber bundle.

Given an evolutionary vector field vv on EE (def. 11) there is a unique vector field v^\hat v on the jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) (def. 5) such that

  1. v^\hat v agrees on field coordinates (as opposed to field derivatives) with vv:

    (jb ‚àû,0) *(v^)=v; (jb_{\infty,0})_\ast(\hat v) = v \,;

  2. contraction with v^\hat v anti-commutes with the total spacetime derivative:

    (20)Œπ v^‚àòd+d‚àòŒπ v^=0. \iota_{\hat v} \circ d + d \circ \iota_{\hat v} = 0 \,.

In particular Cartan's homotopy formula for the Lie derivative ‚Ñí v^\mathcal{L}_{\hat v} holds with respect to the variational derivative Œ¥\delta:

(21)‚Ñí v^=Œ¥‚àòŒπ v^+Œπ v^‚àòŒ¥ \mathcal{L}_{\hat v} = \delta \circ \iota_{\hat v} + \iota_{\hat v} \circ \delta

In the special case that the fiber bundle is a trivial vector bundle over Minkowski spacetime (example 2) with field coordinates œï a\phi^a, so that vv has the expansion

v=v a‚àÇ œï a v = v^a \partial_{\phi^a}

then v^\hat v is given by

v^=‚àën=0‚àûd nv adx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº n‚àÇ œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº n a. \hat v = \underoverset{n = 0}{\infty}{\sum} \frac{d^n v^a}{ d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_n} } \partial_{\phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_n}} \,.
Proof

It is sufficient to prove the coordinate version of the statement. We prove this by induction over the maximal jet order kk. Notice that the coefficient of ‚àÇ œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\partial_{\phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}} in v^\hat v is given by the contraction Œπ v^Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\iota_{\hat v} \delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}.

Similarly (at ‚Äúk=‚àí1k = -1‚Äù) the component of ‚àÇ Œº 1\partial_{\mu_1} is given by Œπ v^dx Œº\iota_{\hat v} d x^{\mu}. But by the second condition above this vanishes:

Œπ v^dx Œº =dŒπ v^x Œº =0 \begin{aligned} \iota_{\hat v} d x^\mu & = d \iota_{\hat v} x^\mu \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

Moreover, the coefficient of ‚àÇ œï a\partial_{\phi^a} in v^\hat v is fixed by the first condition above to be

Œπ v^Œ¥œï a=v a. \iota_{\hat v} \delta \phi^a = v^a \,.

This shows the statement for k=0k = 0. Now assume that the statement is true up to some k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N}. Observe that the coefficients of all ‚àÇ œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k+1 a\partial_{\phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_{k+1}}} are fixed by the contractions with Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº kŒº k+1 a‚àßdx Œº k+1\delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_{k} \mu_{k+1}} \wedge d x^{\mu_{k+1}}. For this we find again from the second condition and using Œ¥‚àòd+d‚àòŒ¥=0\delta \circ d + d \circ \delta = 0 as well as the induction assumption that

Œπ v^Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k+1 a‚àßdx Œº k+1 =Œπ v^Œ¥dœï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a =dŒπ v^Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a =dd kv adx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k =d k+1v adx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k+1dx Œº k+1. \begin{aligned} \iota_{\hat v} \delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_{k+1}} \wedge d x^{\mu_{k+1}} & = \iota_{\hat v} \delta d \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \\ & = d \iota_{\hat v} \delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \\ & = d \frac{d^k v^a}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \\ & = \frac{d^{k+1}v^a }{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_{k+1}}} d x^{\mu_{k+1}} \,. \end{aligned}

This shows that v^\hat v satisfying the two conditions given exists uniquely. Finally the formula for the Lie derivative follows from the second of the two conditions with Cartan's homotopy formula ‚Ñí v^=d‚àòŒπ v^+Œπ v^‚àòd\mathcal{L}_{\hat v} = \mathbf{d} \circ \iota_{\hat v} + \iota_{\hat v} \circ \mathbf{d} together with d=Œ¥+d\mathbf{d} = \delta + d (7).

Proposition

(evolutionary vector fields form a Lie algebra)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a fiber bundle.
