For any two evolutionary vector fields v 1v_1, v 2v_2 on EE (def. 11) the Lie bracket of vector fields of their prolongations v^ 1\hat v_1, v^ 2\hat v_2 (def. 7) is itself the prolongation [v 1,v 2]^\widehat{[v_1, v_2]} of a unique evolutionary vector field [v 1,v 2][v_1,v_2].

This defines the structure of a Lie algebra on evolutionary vector fields.

Proof

It is clear that [v^ 1,v^ 2][\hat v_1, \hat v_2] is still vertical, therefore by prop. 7 it is sufficient to show that contraction with this vector field anti-commutes with the horizontal derivative dd, hence that [d,Œπ [v^ 1,v^ 2]]=0[d, \iota_{[\hat v_1, \hat v_2]}] = 0.

Now [d,Œπ [v^ 1,v^ 2]][d, \iota_{[\hat v_1, \hat v_2]}] is an operator that sends vertical 1-forms to horizontal 1-forms and vanishes on horizontal 1-forms. Therefore it is sufficient to see that this operator in fact also vanishes on all vertical 1-forms. But for this it is sufficient that it commutes with the vertical derivative. This we check by Cartan calculus, using [d,Œ¥]=0[d,\delta] = 0 and [d,Œπ v^ i][d, \iota_{\hat v_i}], by assumption:

[Œ¥,[d,Œπ [v^ 1,v^ 2]]] =‚àí[d,[Œ¥,Œπ [v^ 1,v^ 2]]] =‚àí[d,‚Ñí [v^ 1,v^ 2]] =‚àí[d,[‚Ñí v^ 1,Œπ v^ 2]] =‚àí[d,[[Œ¥,Œπ v^ 1],Œπ v^ 2]] =0. \begin{aligned} [\delta, [d,\iota_{[\hat v_1, \hat v_2]}] ] & = - [d, [\delta, \iota_{[\hat v_1, \hat v_2]}]] \\ & = - [d, \mathcal{L}_{[\hat v_1, \hat v_2]}] \\ & = -[d, [\mathcal{L}_{\hat v_1}, \iota_{\hat v_2}] ] \\ & = - [d, [ [\delta, \iota_{\hat v_1}], \iota_{\hat v_2} ]] \\ & = 0 \,. \end{aligned}

Now given an evolutionary vector field, we want to consider the flow that it induces on the space of field histories:

Definition

(flow of field histories along evolutionary vector field)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle (def. 1) and let vv be an evolutionary vector field (def. 11) such that the ordinary flow of its prolongation v^\hat v (prop. 7)

exp(tv^):J Œ£ ‚àû(E)‚ü∂J Œ£ ‚àû(E) \exp(t \hat v) \;\colon\; J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \longrightarrow J^\infty_\Sigma(E)

exists on the jet bundle (e.g. if the order of derivatives of field coordinates that it depends on is bounded).

For Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E)\Phi \in \Gamma_\Sigma(E) a field history, hence a point in the space of field histories (4), the flow of vv through Œ¶\Phi is the smooth function

‚Ñù 1‚ü∂exp(v)(Œ¶)Œì Œ£(E) \mathbb{R}^1 \overset{\exp(v)(\Phi)}{\longrightarrow} \Gamma_\Sigma(E)

whose unique factorization exp(v)^(Œ¶)\widehat{\exp(v)}(\Phi) through the space of jets of field histories

im(j Œ£ ‚àû) ‚Ü™ Œì Œ£(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)) exp(v)^(Œ¶)‚Üó ‚Üì ‚âÉ ‚Ñù 1 ‚ü∂exp(v)(Œ¶) Œì Œ£(E) \array{ && im(j^\infty_\Sigma) &\hookrightarrow& \Gamma_\Sigma(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\widehat{\exp(v)}(\Phi)}} \nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} \\ \mathbb{R}^1 &\underset{ \exp(v)(\Phi) }{\longrightarrow}& \Gamma_{\Sigma}(E)_{} }

takes a plot t (‚àí):U‚Üí‚Ñù 1t_{(-)} \;\colon\; U \to \mathbb{R}^1 of the real line, regarded as a smooth space, to the plot

(22)(exp(t(‚àí)v^)‚àòj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)):U√óŒ£‚ü∂J Œ£ ‚àûE) (\exp(t(-) \hat v) \circ j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)) \;\colon\: U \times \Sigma \longrightarrow J^\infty_\Sigma E )

of the smooth space of sections of the jet bundle.

(That exp(t(‚àí)v^)\exp(t(-) \hat v) indeed flows jet prolongations j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)) again to jet prolongations is due to its defining relation to the evolutionary vector field vv from prop. 7.)

Definition

(infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian and conserved currents)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

Then

  1. an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian is a variation vv (def. 10) which arises as the prolongation v^\hat v (prop. 7) of an evolutionary vector field vv (def. 11) such that the Lie derivative ‚Ñí v\mathcal{L}_v of the Lagrangian density along v^\hat v is a total spacetime derivative

    ‚Ñí vL=dJÀú v \mathcal{L}_v \mathbf{L} = d \tilde J_v

  2. an on-shell conserved current is a horizontal pp-form J‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,0(E)J \in \Omega^{p,0}_\Sigma(E) whose total spacetime derivative vanishes on the shell (11)

    dJ| ‚Ñ∞=0. d J\vert_{\mathcal{E}} = 0 \,.
Proposition

(Noether's theorem I)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

If vv is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13) with ‚Ñí vL=dJÀú v\mathcal{L}_v \mathbf{L} = d \tilde J_v, then

J v‚âîJÀú v‚àíŒπ vŒò J_v \coloneqq \tilde J_v - \iota_v \Theta

is an on-shell conserved current (def. 13), for Œò\Theta a presymplectic potential (13) from def. 4.

Proof

By Cartan's homotopy formula for the Lie derivative and using (10) and the fact that the variation vector field vv vanishes on horizontal differential forms we may re-express the defining equation for the symmetry as

dJÀú =‚Ñí vL =Œπ vdL‚èü=Œ¥ ELL‚àídŒò+dŒπ vL‚èü=0 =Œπ vŒ¥ ELL+dŒπ vŒò \begin{aligned} d \tilde J & = \mathcal{L}_v \mathbf{L} \\ & = \iota_v \underset{= \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} - d \Theta}{\underbrace{\mathbf{d} \mathbf{L}}} + \mathbf{d} \underset{= 0}{\underbrace{\iota_v \mathbf{L}}} \\ & = \iota_v \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} + d \iota_v \Theta \end{aligned}

which is equivalent to

d(JÀú‚àíŒπ vŒò‚èü=J v)=Œπ vŒ¥ ELL d(\underset{= J_v}{\underbrace{\tilde J - \iota_v \Theta}}) = \iota_v \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}

Since by definition of ‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} the form Œ¥ ELLŒ¥v\frac{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}}{\delta v} vanishes on ‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} this yields the claim.

Proposition

(flow along infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian preserves on-shell space of field histories)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

For vv an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13) the flow on the space of field histories (example 7) that it induces by def. 12 preserves the space of on-shell field histories (from prop. 4):

Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 ‚Ü™ Œì Œ£(E) exp(v^)| Œ¥ ELL=0‚Üë ‚Üë exp(v^) Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 ‚Ü™ Œì Œ£(E) \array{ \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} &\hookrightarrow& \Gamma_\Sigma(E) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\exp(\hat v)\vert_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} }} \uparrow && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{\exp(\hat v)}} \\ \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} &\hookrightarrow& \Gamma_\Sigma(E) }
Proof

By def. 17 a field history Œ¶\Phi is on-shell precisely if

j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)) *(Œ¥ ELL)=0 j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-))^\ast(\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) = 0

and by prop. 16 this is the case precisely if for all bump functions b‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma) the integral against bdvol Œ£b dvol_\Sigma vanishes

‚à´ Œ£j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)) *(Œ¥ ELL)bdvol Œ£=0. \int_\Sigma j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-))^\ast(\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \, b dvol_\Sigma \;=\; 0 \,.

Hence we need to show that this holds true also for all values tt of the flow parameter if it holds at t=0t = 0, hence that the above implies for all bump functions bb that

‚à´ Œ£(exp(tv^)‚àòj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *(Œ¥ ELL)bdvol Œ£ =‚à´ Œ£(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *exp(tv^) *(Œ¥ ELL)bdvol Œ£ =0 \begin{aligned} \int_\Sigma \left( \exp(t \hat v) \circ j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)) \right)^\ast (\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \, b dvol_\Sigma & = \int_\Sigma (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast \exp(t \hat v)^\ast (\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \, b dvol_\Sigma \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

for all t‚àà‚Ñù 1t \in \mathbb{R}^1. But since we know it holds true at one point t=0t = 0, it is in fact sufficient to show that the derivative of this smooth family of differential forms with respect to tt vanishes at all tt. This argument in turn is the same at t=0t = 0 as at any other value, so we consider the derivative at t=0t = 0.

Now by definition of Lie derivatives, the derivative of the above expression with respect to tt at t=0t = 0 is given by the Lie derivative ‚Ñí v^\mathcal{L}_{\hat v} via

ddt‚à´ Œ£((j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *exp(tv^) *(Œ¥ ELL))bdvol Œ£| t=0=‚à´ Œ£(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *‚Ñí v^Œ¥ ELL‚èü=d(Œπ v^‚àíŒ¥J v)Œ© BFVbdvol Œ£. \frac{d}{d t } \int_\Sigma \left( (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast \exp(t \hat v)^\ast (\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \right) \, b dvol_\Sigma \vert_{t = 0} = \int_\Sigma (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast \underset{= d (\iota_{\hat v} -\delta J_v) \Omega_{BFV} }{ \underbrace{ \mathcal{L}_{\hat v} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} }} \, b dvol_\Sigma \,.

We compute that the Lie derivative has the value indicated under the braces as follows:

‚Ñí v^Œ¥ ELL =Œπ v^Œ¥Œ¥ ELL‚èü=‚àídŒ© BFV+Œ¥Œπ v^Œ¥ ELL‚èü=dJ v =‚àíŒπ v^dŒ© BFV+Œ¥dJ v =d(Œπ v^Œ© BFV‚àíŒ¥J v) \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_{\hat v} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} & = \iota_{\hat v} \underset{ = - d\Omega_{BFV} }{\underbrace{\delta \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}} } + \delta \,\underset{= d J_v}{\underbrace{\iota_{\hat v} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}}} \\ & = - \iota_{\hat v} d\Omega_{BFV} + \delta d J_v \\ & = d \left(\iota_{\hat v} \Omega_{BFV} - \delta J_v \right) \end{aligned}

Here we first used Cartan's homotopy formula for evolutionary vector fields (21), then, under the braces, the conserved current property of the presymplectic current (prop. 6) as well as Noether's theorem I (prop. 9), and finally the defining verticality condition of prolongations of evolutionary vector fields (prop. 7) as well as the anti-commutativity of Œ¥\delta and dd.

Hence continuing the computation of the derivative above we have

ddt‚à´ Œ£((j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *exp(tv^) *(Œ¥ ELL))bdvol Œ£| t=0 =‚àí‚à´ Œ£(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *d(Œπ v^Œ© BFV‚àíŒ¥J v)bdvol Œ£ =‚àí‚à´ Œ£dj Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)) *(Œπ v^Œ© BFV‚àíŒ¥J v)bdvol Œ£ =0 \begin{aligned} \frac{d}{d t } \int_\Sigma \left( (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast \exp(t \hat v)^\ast (\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) \right) \, b dvol_\Sigma \vert_{t = 0} & = - \int_\Sigma (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast d (\iota_{\hat v} \Omega_{BFV} - \delta J_v) \, b dvol_\Sigma \\ & = - \int_\Sigma d j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-))^\ast (\iota_{\hat v}\Omega_{BFV} - \delta J_v) \, b dvol_\Sigma \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

by prop. 3.

Example

(energy-momentum of the scalar field)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of the free scalar field from def. 10:

L=12(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,Œºœï ,ŒΩ+m 2œï 2)dvol Œ£. \mathbf{L} \;=\; \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \eta^{\mu \nu}\phi_{,\mu} \phi_{,\nu} + m^2 \phi^2 \right) dvol_\Sigma \,.

For ŒΩ‚àà{0,1,‚ãØ,p}\nu \in \{0, 1, \cdots, p\} consider the vector field on the jet bundle given by

v ŒΩ‚âîœï ,ŒΩ‚àÇ œï+œï ,ŒºŒΩ‚àÇ œï ,Œº+‚ãØ. v_\nu \;\coloneqq\; \phi_{,\nu} \partial_{\phi} + \phi_{,\mu \nu} \partial_{\phi_{,\mu}} + \cdots \,.

This describes infinitesimal translations of the fields in the direction of ‚àÇ ŒΩ\partial_\nu.

And this is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13), since

Œπ v ŒΩdL=dL‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£. \iota_{v_\nu} \mathbf{d}\mathbf{L} = d L \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_\Sigma \,.

With the formula (18) for the presymplectic potential

Œò=Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒ¥œïŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£ \Theta = \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \delta \phi \iota_{\partial_{\nu}} dvol_\Sigma

it hence follows from Noether's theorem (prop. 9) that the corresponding conserved current (def. 13) is

T ŒΩ =LŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚àíŒπ v ŒΩŒò =LŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚àíŒ∑ œÅŒºœï ,œÅœï ,ŒΩŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ =(Œ¥ ŒΩ ŒºL‚àíŒ∑ œÅŒºœï ,œÅœï ,ŒΩ‚èü=:T ŒΩ Œº)Œπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£. \begin{aligned} T_\nu & = L \, \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_\Sigma - \iota_{v_\nu}\Theta \\ & = L \, \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_\Sigma - \eta^{\rho \mu} \phi_{,\rho} \phi_{,\nu} \, \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = ( \underset{=: T^\mu_\nu}{ \underbrace{ \delta^\mu_\nu L - \eta^{\rho \mu} \phi_{,\rho} \phi_{,\nu} } } ) \, \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \end{aligned} \,.

This conserved current is called the energy-momentum tensor.

Evidently Noether's theorem I in variational calculus (prop. 9) is the special case for horizontal p+1p+1-forms of a more general phenomenon relating symmetries of variational forms to forms that are closed up to a contraction. The same phenomenon applied instead to the presymplectic current yields the following:

Definition

(infinitesimal symmetry of the presymplectic potential and Hamiltonian differential forms)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory with presymplectic potential Œò\Theta (13). Write ‚Ñ∞‚Ü™J Œ£ ‚àû(E)\mathcal{E} \hookrightarrow J^\infty_\Sigma(E) for the shell (11).

  1. An on-shell variation vv (def. 10) is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lepage form or Hamiltonian vector field if on-shell (def. 4) its Lie derivative along vv is a variational derivative:

    ‚Ñí vŒò=Œ¥HÀú vAAAon‚Ñ∞ \mathcal{L}_v \Theta = \delta \tilde H_v \phantom{AAA} \text{on}\, \mathcal{E}

    for some variational form HÀú v\tilde H_v.

  2. A Hamiltonian differential form HH (or local Hamiltonian current) is a variational form on the shell such that there exists a variation vv with

    Œ¥H=Œπ vŒ© BFVAAon‚Ñ∞. \delta H = \iota_v \Omega_{BFV} \phantom{AA} \, \text{on}\, \mathcal{E} \,.

We write

Œ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E)‚âî{(H,v)|vis a variation andŒπ vŒ© BFV=J} \Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma, Ham}(E) \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ (H,v) \;\vert\; v \, \text{is a variation and}\, \iota_v \Omega_{BFV} = J \right\}

for the space of pairs consisting of a Hamiltonian differential forms on-shell and a corresponding variation.

Proposition

(Hamiltonian Noether's theorem)

A variation vv is an infinitesimal symmetry of the presymplectic potential (def. 14) with ‚Ñí v(Œò)=Œ¥HÀú v\mathcal{L}_v ( \Theta ) = \delta \tilde H_v precisely if

H v‚âîHÀú v‚àíŒπ vŒò H_v \coloneqq \tilde H_v - \iota_v \Theta

is a Hamiltonian differential form for vv.

Proof

By Cartan's homotopy formula for the Lie derivative we have

‚Ñí vŒò =dŒπ vŒò‚èü=Œ¥Œπ vŒò‚àíŒπ vdŒò+Œπ vdŒò‚èüŒπ vŒ¥Œò+Œπ vdŒò =Œ¥Œπ vŒò+Œπ vŒ¥Œò‚èü=Œ© BFV. \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_v \Theta & = \underset{ = \delta \iota_v \Theta - \iota_v d \Theta }{ \underbrace{ \mathbf{d} \iota_v \Theta } } + \underset{ \iota_v \delta \Theta + \iota_v d \Theta }{ \underbrace{ \iota_v \mathbf{d} \Theta }} \\ & = \delta \iota_v \Theta + \iota_v \underset{ = \Omega_{BFV}}{\underbrace{\delta \Theta}} \,. \end{aligned}

This directly implies the claim.

\,

Noether theorem and Hamiltonian Noether theorem

\, variational form \,\, symmetry \,\, homotopy formula \,\, physical quantity \,\,\,\, local symmetry algebra \,
Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L}‚Ñí vL=dJÀú\mathcal{L}_v \mathbf{L} = d \tilde J‚áîd(JÀú‚àíŒπ vŒò‚èü=J v)=Œπ vŒ¥ ELL\Leftrightarrow d(\underset{= J_v}{\underbrace{\tilde J - \iota_v \Theta}}) = \iota_v \, \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}conserved current J vJ_vDickey bracket
presymplectic current Œ© BFV\Omega_{BFV}‚Ñí vŒò=Œ¥HÀú\mathcal{L}_v \Theta = \delta \tilde H‚áîŒ¥(HÀú v‚àíŒπ vŒò‚èü=H v)=Œπ vŒ© BFV\Leftrightarrow \delta(\underset{= H_v}{\underbrace{\tilde H_v - \iota_v \Theta}}) = \iota_v \Omega_{BFV}Hamiltonian form H vH_vlocal Poisson bracket

\,

Since therefore both the conserved currents from Noether's theorem as well as the Hamiltonian differential forms are generators of infinitesimal symmetries of certain variational forms (namely of the Lagrangian density and of the presymplectic current, respectively) they form a Lie algebra. For the conserved currents this is sometimes known as the Dickey bracket Lie algebra. For the Hamiltonian forms it is the Poisson bracket Lie p+1-algebra. Since here for simplicity we are considering just vertical variations, we have just a plain Lie algebra. The transgression of this Lie algebra of Hamiltonian forms on the jet bundle to Cauchy surfaces yields a presymplectic structure on phase space, this we discuss below.

Proposition

(local Poisson bracket)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

On the space Œ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E)\Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma,Ham}(E) pairs (H,v)(H,v) of Hamiltonian differential forms HH with compatible variation vv (def. 14) the following operation constitutes a Lie bracket:

(23){(H 1,v 1),(H 2,v 2)}‚âî(Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œ© BFV,[v 1,v 2]). \left\{(H_1, v_1),\, (H_2, v_2)\right\} \;\coloneqq\; (\iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV},\, [v_1,v_2]) \,.

(Here [v 1,v 2][v_1, v_2] denotes the ordinary Lie bracket of vector fields.)

We call this the local Poisson Lie bracket.

Proof

First we need to check that the bracket is well defined in itself. It is clear that it is linear and skew-symmetric, but what needs proof is that it does indeed land in Œ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E)\Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma,Ham}(E), hence that the following equation holds:

Œ¥Œπ v 2Œπ v 1Œ© BFV=Œπ [v 1,v 2]Œ© BFV. \delta \iota_{v_2} \iota_{v_1} \Omega_{BFV} \;=\; \iota_{[v_1, v_2]} \Omega_{BFV} \,.

To see this we use Cartan calculus:

Since the variation vv is purely vertical, by definition, contraction with vv anti-commutes with the total horizontal derivative:

d‚àòŒπ v+Œπ v‚àòd=0. d \circ \iota_{v} + \iota_v \circ d = 0 \,.

This makes Cartan's homotopy formula for the Lie derivative

‚Ñí v=d‚àòŒπ v+Œπ v‚àòd \mathcal{L}_v = \mathbf{d} \circ \iota_v + \iota_v \circ \mathbf{d}

have an analogue with the full de Rham differential replaced by the variational derivative (vertical derivative) Œ¥=d‚àíd\delta = \mathbf{d} - d:

‚Ñí v=Œ¥‚àòŒπ v+Œπ v‚àòŒ¥. \mathcal{L}_v = \delta \circ \iota_v + \iota_v \circ \delta \,.

With this we compute as follows:

Œ¥Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œ© BFV =12Œ¥Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œ© BFV‚àí12(v 1‚Üîv 2) =12(‚Ñí v 1Œπ v 2Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 1Œ¥Œπ v 2Œ© BFV)‚àí12(v 1‚Üîv 2) =12(‚Ñí v 1Œπ v 2Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 1‚Ñí v 2Œ© BFV+Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œ¥Œ© BFV‚èü=0)‚àí12(v 1‚Üîv 2) =[‚Ñí v 2,Œπ v 1]Œ© BFV =Œπ [v 1,v 2]Œ© BFV. \begin{aligned} \delta \iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} & = \tfrac{1}{2} \delta \iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} - \tfrac{1}{2} (v_1 \leftrightarrow v_2) \\ & = \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \mathcal{L}_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_1} \delta \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} \right) - \tfrac{1}{2} (v_1 \leftrightarrow v_2) \\ & = \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \mathcal{L}_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_1} \mathcal{L}_{v_2} \Omega_{BFV} + \iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \underset{= 0}{\underbrace{\delta \Omega_{BFV}}} \right) - \tfrac{1}{2} (v_1 \leftrightarrow v_2) \\ & = [\mathcal{L}_{v_2}, \iota_{v_1}] \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = \iota_{[v_1, v_2]} \Omega_{BFV} \,. \end{aligned}

This shows that the bracket is well defined.

It remains to see that the bracket satifies the Jacobi identity:

{(H 1,v 1),{(H 2,v 2),(H 3,v 3)}}+(cyclic)=0 \left\{ (H_1, v_1), \left\{ (H_2, v_2), (H_3,v_3) \right\} \right\} \;+\; (cyclic) \;=\; 0

hence that

(Œπ v 1Œπ [v 2,v 3]Œ© BFV,[v 1,[v 2,v 2]])+(cyclic)=0. \left( \iota_{v_1} \iota_{[v_2,v_3]} \Omega_{BFV} ,\, [v_1, [v_2, v_2]] \right) \;+\; (cyclic) \;=\; 0 \,.

Here [v 1,[v 2,v 3]]+(cyclic)=0 [v_1, [v_2, v_3]] + (cyclic) = 0 is the ordinary Jacobi identity for vector fields, and hence what needs to be shown is that

Œπ v 1Œπ [v 2,v 3]Œ© BFV+(cyclic)=0 \iota_{v_1} \iota_{[v_2, v_3]} \Omega_{BFV} + (cyclic) = 0

We check this by repeated uses of Cartan calculus, using in addition that

  1. Œ¥Œπ v iŒ© BFV=0\delta \iota_{v_i} \Omega_{BFV} = 0

    (since Œπ v iŒ© BFV=Œ¥H i\iota_{v_i} \Omega_{BFV} = \delta H_i by v iv_i being Hamiltonian)

  2. ‚Ñí v iŒ© BFV=0\mathcal{L}_{v_i} \Omega_{BFV} = 0

    (since in addition Œ¥Œ© BFV=0\delta \Omega_{BFV} = 0)

  3. Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œπ v 3Œ© BFV=0\iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} = 0

    (since Œ© BFV‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E)\Omega_{BFV} \in \Omega^{p,2}_\Sigma(E) is of vertical degree 2, and since all variations v iv_i are vertical by assumption).

So we compute as follows (a special case of FRS 13b, lemma 3.1.1):

0 =Œ¥Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œπ v 3Œ© BFV =‚Ñí v 1Œπ v 2Œπ v 3Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 1Œ¥Œπ v 2Œπ v 3Œ© BFV =Œπ [v 1,v 2]Œπ v 3Œ© BFV+Œπ v 2‚Ñí v 1Œπ v 3Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 1‚Ñí v 2Œπ v 3Œ© BFV+Œπ v 1Œπ v 2Œ¥Œπ v 3Œ© BFV =Œπ [v 1,v 2]Œπ v 3Œ© BFV+Œπ v 2Œπ [v 1,v 3]Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 1Œπ [v 2,v 3]Œ© BFV =‚àíŒπ v 1Œπ [v 2,v 3]Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 2Œπ [v 3,v 1]Œ© BFV‚àíŒπ v 3Œπ [v 1,v 2]Œ© BFV. \begin{aligned} 0 & = \delta \iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = \mathcal{L}_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_1} \delta \iota_{v_2} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = \iota_{[v_1, v_2]} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} + \iota_{v_2} \mathcal{L}_{v_1} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_1} \mathcal{L}_{v_2} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} + \iota_{v_1} \iota_{v_2} \delta \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = \iota_{[v_1, v_2]} \iota_{v_3} \Omega_{BFV} + \iota_{v_2} \iota_{[v_1,v_3]} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_1} \iota_{[v_2, v_3]} \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = - \iota_{v_1} \iota_{[v_2, v_3]} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_2} \iota_{[v_3, v_1]} \Omega_{BFV} - \iota_{v_3} \iota_{[v_1, v_2]} \Omega_{BFV} \,. \end{aligned}

\,

The local Poisson bracket Lie algebra (Œ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E),[‚àí,‚àí])(\Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma,Ham}(E), [-,-]) from prop. 15 is but the lowest stage of a higher Lie theoretic structure called the Poisson bracket Lie p-algebra. Here we will not go deeper into this higher structure (see at Higher Prequantum Geometry for more), but below we will need the following simple shadow of it:

Lemma

The horizontally exact Hamiltonian forms constitute a Lie ideal for the local Poisson Lie bracket (23).

Proof

Let EE be a horizontally exact Hamiltonian form, hence

E=dK E = d K

for some KK. Write ee for a Hamiltonian vector field for EE.

Then for (H,v)(H,v) any other pair consisting of a Hamiltonian form and a corresponding Hamiltonian vector field, we have

Œπ vŒπ eŒ© BFV =‚àíŒπ vŒ¥E =‚àíŒπ vŒ¥dK =‚àíŒπ vdŒ¥K =‚àídŒπ vŒ¥K. \begin{aligned} \iota_v \, \iota_e \, \Omega_{BFV} & = \phantom{-}\iota_v \, \delta E \\ & = \phantom{-}\iota_v \, \delta \, d \, K \\ & = - \iota_v \, d \, \delta K \\ & = \phantom{-}d \, \iota_v \, \delta \, K \,. \end{aligned}

Here we used that the horizontal derivative anti-commutes with the vertical one by construction of the variational bicomplex, and that Œπ e\iota_e anti-commutes with the horizontal derivative dd since the variation ee (def. 10) is by definition vertical.

Example

(local Poisson bracket for real scalar field)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory for the free real scalar field from example 10.

By example 12 is presymplectic current is

Œ© BFV=Œ∑ ŒºŒΩŒ¥œï ,Œº‚àßŒ¥œï‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ \Omega_{BFV} = \eta^{\mu \nu} \delta \phi_{,\mu} \wedge \delta \phi \wedge \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \,

The corresponding Poisson bracket Lie (p+1)-algebra (prop. 15) has in degree 0 Hamiltonian forms (def. 11) such as

Q‚âîœïŒπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£‚ààŒ© p,0(E) Q \coloneqq \phi \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma \in \Omega^{p,0}(E)

and

P‚âîŒ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© p,0(E). P \coloneqq \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_{\Sigma} \in \Omega^{p,0}(E) \,.

The corresponding Hamiltonian vector fields are

v P=‚àÇ œï ,0 v_P = \partial_{\phi_{,0}}

and

v Q=‚àí‚àÇ œï. v_Q = - \partial_{\phi} \,.

Hence the corresponding local Poisson bracket is

{Q,P}=Œπ v QŒπ v Pœâ=Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£. \{Q,P\} = \iota_{v_Q} \iota_{v_P} \omega = \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma \,.

More generally for b 1,b 2‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b_1, b_2 \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma) two bump functions then

{b 1Q,b 2P}=b 1b 2Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£. \{ b_1 Q, b_2 P \} = b_1 b_2 \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma \,.
Definition

(local Heisenberg Lie algebra)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle as in example 2, its jet bundle (def. 5) inherits the structure of a trivial vector bundle (this is the only case we have been making explicit here anyway, def. 5). Hence addition in the fibers gives it the structure of a group, by translation.

If the presymplectic current is left invariant with respect to this group structure, then it makes sense to ask for that sub Lie algebra of the local Poisson bracket Lie algebra (def. 15) which covers these translations. This is the corresponding local Heisenberg algebra.

\,

Observables

Given a field theory as above, then an observable quantity (or just observable, for short) is a smooth function

A:Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ EL=0‚ü∂‚ÑÇ A \;\colon\; \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL} = 0} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}

on the space of on-shell field trajectories (def. 17). We think of this function as assigning to each physically realizable field history Œ¶\Phi the value A(Œ¶)A(\Phi) of the given quantity as exhibited by that field history. For instance concepts like ‚Äúavarage field amplitude in spacetime region ùí™\mathcal{O}‚Äù should be observables.

In local field theory the idea is that both the equations of motion as well as the observations are fully determined by their restriction to infinitesimal neighbourhoods of spacetime points (events). For the equations of motion this means that they are partial differential equations as we have seen above. For the observables it should mean that they must be averages over regions of spacetime of functions of the value of the field histories and their derivatives at any point of spacetime. Now a ‚Äúsmooth function of the value of the field field histories and their derivatives at any point‚Äù is precisely a smooth function on the jet bundle of the field bundle (example 5) pulled back via jet prolongation (def. 6). If this is to be averaged over spacetime it needs to be the coefficient of a horizontal p+1p+1-form (prop. 8).

In mathematical terminology these desiderata say that the local observables in a local field theory should be precisely the ‚Äútransgressions‚Äù (def. 16 below) of horizontal variational p+1p+1-forms (with compact spacetime support, def. 15 below) to the space of field histories (example 7). This is def. 18 below.

A key example of a local observable in Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) is the action functional (example 17 below). This is the transgression of the Lagrangian density itself, or rather of its product with an ‚Äúadiabatic switching function‚Äù that localizes its support in a compact spacetime region. In typical cases the physical quantity whose observation is represented by the action functional is the difference of the kinetic energy-momentum minus the potential energy of a field history averaged over the given region of spacetime.

The equations of motion of a Lagrangian field theory say that those field histories are physically realized which are critical points of this action functional observable. This is the principle of extremal action (prop. 16 below).

This formalizes what it means for a field history Œ¶\Phi to be ‚Äúrealizable‚Äù (physically admissible) (a solution to the Euler-Lagrange equations, def. 17) and what the (local) observable quantities on field histories are (def. 18). It remains to formalize what it means for the physical system to be in some definite state so that the observable quantities take some definite value, reflecting the properties of that state.

Whatever formalization for states of a field theory one considers, at the very least the space of states StatesStates should come with a pairing linear map

Obs‚äóStates ‚ü∂ ùíû (A,‚ü®‚àí‚ü©) ‚Ü¶ ‚ü®A‚ü© \array{ Obs \otimes States & \longrightarrow& \mathcal{C} \\ \left( A , \langle - \rangle \right) &\mapsto& \langle A \rangle }

which reads in an observable quantity AA and a state, to be denoted ‚ü®‚àí‚ü©\langle - \rangle, and produces the complex number ‚ü®A‚ü©\langle A \rangle which is the ‚Äúvalue of the observable quantity AA in the case that the physical system is in the state ‚ü®‚àí‚ü©\langle -\rangle‚Äù.

One might imagine that it is fundamentally possible to pinpoint the exact field history that the physical system is found in. From this perspective fixing a state should simply mean to pick an element in the on-shell space of field histories Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Phi \in \Gamma_{\Sigma}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0}. If we write ‚ü®‚àí‚ü© Œ¶\langle -\rangle_{\Phi} for this state, its pairing map with the states would simply be evaluation of the observable, being a function on the field history space, on that particular element in this space:

‚ü®A‚ü© Œ¶‚âîA(Œ¶). \langle A \rangle_{\Phi} \coloneqq A(\Phi) \,.

However, in the practice of experiment a field history can never be known precisely, without remaining uncertainty. Moreover, quantum physics (to which we finally come below), suggests that this is true even in principle. Therefore we should allow states to be a kind of probability distributions on the space of field histories, and regard the pairing ‚ü®A‚ü©\langle A \rangle of a state ‚ü®‚àí‚ü©\langle - \rangle with an observable AA as a kind of expectation value of the function AA averaged with respect to this probability distribution. Specifically if the observable quantity AA is (a smooth approximation to) a characteristic function of a subset S‚äÇŒì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0S \subset \Gamma_{\Sigma}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} of the space of field histories, then its value in a given state should be the probability to find the physical system in that that subset of field histories.

But, moreover, the superposition principle of quantum physics says that the actually observable observables are only those of the form A *AA^\ast A (for A *A^\ast the image under the star-operation on the star algebra of observables.

This finally leads to the definition of states in def. 21 below.

\,

Definition

(spacetime support)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle over a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 1), with induced jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E)

For every subset S‚äÇŒ£S \subset \Sigma let

J Œ£ ‚àû(E)| S ‚Ü™Œπ S J Œ£ ‚àû(E) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì S ‚Ü™ Œ£ \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma(E)\vert_S &\overset{\iota_S}{\hookrightarrow}& J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ S &\hookrightarrow& \Sigma }

be the corresponding restriction of the jet bundle of EE.

The spacetime support supp Œ£(A)supp_\Sigma(A) of a differential form A‚ààŒ© ‚Ä¢(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))A \in \Omega^\bullet(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) on the jet bundle of EE is the topological closure of the maximal subset S‚äÇŒ£S \subset \Sigma such that the restriction of AA to the jet bundle restrited to this subset vanishes:

supp Œ£(A)‚âîCl({x‚ààŒ£|Œπ {x} *A=0}) supp_\Sigma(A) \coloneqq Cl( \{ x \in \Sigma | \iota_{\{x\}^\ast A = 0} \} )

We write

Œ© Œ£,cp r,s(E)‚âî{A‚ààŒ© Œ£ r,s(E)|supp Œ£(A)is compact}‚Ü™Œ© Œ£ r,s(E) \Omega^{r,s}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) \coloneqq \left\{ A \in \Omega^{r,s}_\Sigma(E) \;\vert\; supp_\Sigma(A) \, \text{is compact} \right\} \;\hookrightarrow\; \Omega^{r,s}_\Sigma(E)

for the subspace of differential forms on the jet bundle whose spacetime support is a compact subspace.

Definition

(transgression of variational differential forms to space of field histories)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle over a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 1). and let

Œ£ r‚Ü™Œ£ \Sigma_r \hookrightarrow \Sigma

be a submanifold of spacetime of dimension r‚àà‚Ñïr \in \mathbb{N}. Recall the space of field histories restricted to its infinitesimal neighbourhood, denoted Œì Œ£ r(E)\Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E) (def. 1).

Then the operation of transgression of variational differential forms to Œ£ r\Sigma_r is the linear map

œÑ Œ£ r:Œ© Œ£,cp ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E)‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢(Œì Œ£ r(E)) \tau_{\Sigma_r} \;\colon\; \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) \overset{ }{\longrightarrow} \Omega^\bullet\left( \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E) \right)

that sends a variational differential form A‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E)A \in \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) to the differential form œÑ Œ£ r‚ààŒ© ‚Ä¢(Œì Œ£ r(E))\tau_{\Sigma_r} \in \Omega^\bullet(\Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E)) which to a smooth family on field configurations

Œ¶ (‚àí)(‚àí):U√óN Œ£Œ£ r‚ü∂E \Phi_{(-)}(-) \;\colon\; U \times N_\Sigma \Sigma_r \longrightarrow E

assigns the differential form given by first forming the pullback of differential forms along the family of jet prolongation j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶ (‚àí))j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi_{(-)}) followed by the integration of differential forms over Œ£ r\Sigma_r:

(œÑ Œ£A) Œ¶‚âî‚à´ Œ£ r(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶ (‚àí))) *A‚ààŒ© ‚Ä¢(U). (\tau_{\Sigma}A)_\Phi \;\coloneqq\; \int_{\Sigma_r} (j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi_{(-)}))^\ast A \;\in\; \Omega^\bullet(U) \,.
Remark

(transgression to dimension rr picks out hiorizontal rr-forms)

In def. 16 we regard integration of differential forms over Œ£ r\Sigma_r as an operation defined on differential forms of all degrees, which vanishes except on forms of degree rr, and hence transgression of variational differential forms to Œ£ r\Sigma_r vanishes except on the subspace

Œ© Œ£ r,‚Ä¢(E)‚äÇŒ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E) \Omega^{r,\bullet}_\Sigma(E) \;\subset\; \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E)

of forms of horizontal degree rr.

Example

(adiabatically switched action functional)

Given a field bundle E‚ü∂fbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\longrightarrow} \Sigma, consider a local Lagrangian density (def. 9)

L‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,0(E). \mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) \,.

For any bump function b‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma), the transgression of bLb \mathbf{L} (def. 16) is called the action functional

ùíÆ bL‚âîœÑ Œ£(bL):Œì Œ£(E)‚ü∂‚Ñù \mathcal{S}_b \mathbf{L} \coloneqq \tau_{\Sigma} \left( b \mathbf{L} \right) \;\colon\; \Gamma_\Sigma(E) \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}

induced by L\mathbf{L}, ‚Äúadiabatically switched‚Äù by bb.

Specifically if the field bundle is a trivial vector bundle as in example 2, such that the Lagrangian density may be written in the form

L=L((x Œº),(œï a),(œï ,Œº a),‚ãØ)bdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp p+1,0(E). \mathbf{L} \;=\; L \left( (x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots \right) \, b dvol_\Sigma \;\in\; \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma,cp}( E ) \,.

then its action functional takes a field history Œ¶\Phi to the value

ùíÆ bL(Œ¶):‚à´ Œ£L(x,(Œ¶ a(x)),(‚àÇŒ¶ a‚àÇx Œº(x)),‚ãØ)b(x)dvol Œ£(x) \mathcal{S}_{b \mathbf{L}}(\Phi) \:\colon\; \int_\Sigma L \left( x, \left( \Phi^a(x) \right), \left(\frac{\partial \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu}(x)\right), \cdots \right) \, b(x) dvol_\Sigma(x)
Proposition

(transgression compatible with variational derivative)

Let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a field bundle over a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 1) and let Œ£ r‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_r \hookrightarrow \Sigma be a submanifold possibly with boundary ‚àÇŒ£ r‚Ü™Œ£ r\partial \Sigma_r \hookrightarrow \Sigma_r. Write

Œì Œ£ r(E)‚ü∂(‚àí)| ‚àÇŒ£ rŒì ‚àÇŒ£ r(E) \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E) \overset{(-)\vert_{\partial \Sigma_r}}{\longrightarrow} \Gamma_{\partial \Sigma_r}(E)

for the boundary restriction map.

Then the operation of transgression of variational differential forms (def. 16)

œÑ Œ£:Œ© Œ£,cp ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E)‚ü∂Œ© ‚Ä¢(Œì Œ£ r(E)) \tau_{\Sigma} \;\colon\; \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) \longrightarrow \Omega^\bullet\left(\Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E)\right)

is compatible with the variational derivative Œ¥\delta and with the total spacetime derivative dd in the following way:

  1. On variational forms that are in the image of the total spacetime derivative a transgressive Stokes' theorem holds:

    œÑ Œ£ r(dŒ±)=((‚àí)| ‚àÇŒ£) *œÑ ‚àÇŒ£ r(Œ±) \tau_{\Sigma_r}(d \alpha) \;=\; ((-)\vert_{\partial \Sigma})^\ast \tau_{\partial \Sigma_r}( \alpha)

  2. Transgression intertwines, up to a sign, the variational derivative Œ¥\delta on variational differential forms with the plain de Rham differential on the space of field histories:

    œÑ Œ£(Œ¥Œ±)=(‚àí1) p+1dœÑ Œ£(Œ±). \tau_{\Sigma}\left( \delta \alpha \right) \;=\; (-1)^{p+1}\, d \,\tau_{\Sigma}(\alpha) \,.
Proof

Regarding the first statement, consider a horizontally exact variational form

dŒ±‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp r,s(E). d \alpha \in \Omega^{r,s}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) \,.

By prop. 3 the pullback of this form along the jet prolongation of fields is exact in the Œ£\Sigma-direction:

(j Œ£ ‚àûŒ¶ (‚àí)) *(dŒ±)=d Œ£(j Œ£ ‚àûŒ¶ (‚àí)) *Œ±, (j^\infty_\Sigma\Phi_{(-)})^\ast(d \alpha ) \;=\; d_\Sigma (j^\infty_\Sigma\Phi_{(-)})^\ast \alpha \,,

(where we write d=d U+d Œ£d = d_U + d_\Sigma for the de Rham differential on U√óŒ£U \times \Sigma). Hence by the ordinary Stokes' theorem restricted to any Œ¶ (‚àí):U‚ÜíŒì Œ£ r(E)\Phi_{(-)} \colon U \to \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E) with restriction (‚àí)| ‚àÇŒ£ r‚àòŒ¶ (‚àí):U‚ÜíŒì Œ£ r(E)(-)\vert_{\partial \Sigma_r} \circ \Phi_{(-)} \colon U \to \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E) the relation

(Œ¶ (‚àí)) *œÑ Œ£ r(dŒ±) =‚à´ Œ£ rd Œ£ r(j Œ£ ‚àûŒ¶ (‚àí)) *Œ± =‚à´ ‚àÇŒ£ r(j Œ£ ‚àûŒ¶ (‚àí)) *Œ± =‚à´ ‚àÇŒ£ r(j Œ£ ‚àû((‚àí)| Œ£‚àòŒ¶ (‚àí))) *Œ± =((‚àí)| Œ£‚àòŒ¶ (‚àí)) *œÑ ‚àÇŒ£ r(Œ±) =(Œ¶ (‚àí)) *((‚àí)| Œ£ r) *œÑ ‚àÇŒ£ r(Œ±).. \begin{aligned} (\Phi_{(-)})^\ast \tau_{\Sigma_r}(d \alpha) & = \int_{\Sigma_r} d_{\Sigma_r} (j^\infty_\Sigma\Phi_{(-)})^\ast\alpha \\ & = \int_{\partial \Sigma_r} (j^\infty_\Sigma\Phi_{(-)})^\ast\alpha \\ & = \int_{\partial \Sigma_r} (j^\infty_\Sigma ( (-)\vert_\Sigma \circ \Phi_{(-)}) )^\ast\alpha \\ & = ( (-)\vert_\Sigma \circ \Phi_{(-)} )^\ast \tau_{\partial \Sigma_r}(\alpha) \\ & = (\Phi_{(-)})^\ast ((-)\vert_{\Sigma_r})^\ast \tau_{\partial \Sigma_r}(\alpha) \,. \end{aligned} \,.

Regarding the second statement: by the Leibniz rule for de Rham differential (product law of differentiation) it is sufficient to check the claim on variational derivatives of local coordinate functions

Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab‚ààŒ© Œ£ 0,1(E). \delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} b \in \Omega^{0,1}_\Sigma(E) \,.

The pullback of differential forms along j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶ (‚àí)):U√óŒ£‚ÜíJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi_{(-)}) \colon U \times \Sigma \to J^\infty_\Sigma(E) has two contributions: one from the variation along Œ£\Sigma, the other from variation along UU:

  1. By prop. 3, for fixed u‚ààUu \in U the pullback of Œ¥œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\delta \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} along the jet prolongation vanishes.

  2. For fixed x‚ààŒ£x \in \Sigma, the pullback of the full de Rham differential dœï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\mathbf{d} \phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k} is

    (Œ¶ (‚àí)(x)) *(dœï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a) =d U(Œ¶ (‚àí)(x)) *(œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a) =d U‚àÇ kŒ¶ (‚àí)(x)‚àÇx Œº 1‚ãØ‚àÇx Œº k \begin{aligned} (\Phi_{(-)}(x))^\ast( \mathbf{d} \phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k} ) & = d_U (\Phi_{(-)}(x))^\ast(\phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k}) \\ & = d_U \frac{ \partial^k \Phi_{(-)}(x)}{\partial x^{\mu^1} \cdots \partial x^{\mu_k}} \end{aligned}

    (since the full de Rham differentials always commute with pullback of differential forms), while the pullback of the horizontal derivative dœï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a=œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº kŒº k+1 adx Œº k+1d \phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k} = \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_{k} \mu_{k+1}} \mathbf{d}x^{\mu_{k+1}} vanishes at fixed x‚ààŒ£x \in \Sigma.

This implies over the given smooth family Œ¶ (‚àí)\Phi_{(-)} that

œÑ Œ£(Œ¥œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab)| Œ¶ (‚àí) =œÑ Œ£(d(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab))| Œ¶ (‚àí)‚àíœÑ Œ£(d(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab))| Œ¶ (‚àí)‚èü=0 =‚à´ Œ£d U(Œ¶ (‚àí)) *(œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab) =(‚àí1) p+1d U‚à´ Œ£(Œ¶ (‚àí)) *(œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k ab) =(‚àí1) p+1d UœÑ Œ£(Œ¶ (‚àí)) *(œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a). \begin{aligned} \tau_\Sigma\left( \delta \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} b \right)\vert_{\Phi_{(-)}} & = \tau_\Sigma\left( \mathbf{d} ( \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} b) \right) \vert_{\Phi_{(-)}} - \underset{ = 0 }{ \underbrace{ \tau_\Sigma \left( d (\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} b) \right)\vert_{\Phi_{(-)}} }} \\ & = \int_\Sigma d_U (\Phi_{(-)})^\ast ( \phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k} b ) \\ & = (-1)^{p+1} d_U \int_\Sigma (\Phi_{(-)})^\ast ( \phi^a_{\mu_1\cdots \mu_k} b ) \\ & = (-1)^{p+1} d_U \tau_{\Sigma}( \Phi_{(-)} )^\ast ( \phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} ) \,. \end{aligned}

and since this holds covariantly for all smooth families Œ¶ (‚àí)\Phi_{(-)}, this implies the claim.

Example

(variation of the action functional)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) (def. 9) then the derivative of its adiabatically switched action functional (def. 17) equals the transgression of the Euler-Lagrange variational derivative Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} (def. 4):

dùíÆ bL=œÑ Œ£(bŒ¥ ELL). d \mathcal{S}_{b \mathbf{L}} \;=\; \tau_\Sigma( b \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} ) \,.
Proof

By the second statement of prop. 13 we have

dùíÆ bL=œÑ Œ£(Œ¥(bL)). d \mathcal{S}_{b \mathbf{L}} \;=\; \tau_\Sigma( \delta ( b \mathbf{L} ) ) \,.

By prop. 4 this is

‚ãØ =œÑ Œ£(bŒ¥ ELL+dŒò b) =œÑ Œ£(bŒ¥ ELL)+œÑ Œ£(dŒò b)‚èü=0, \begin{aligned} \cdots & = \tau_\Sigma( b \, \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} + d \Theta_b ) \\ & = \tau_\Sigma( b \, \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} ) + \underset{= 0}{\underbrace{\tau_\Sigma( d \Theta_b )}} \end{aligned} \,,

where the second term vanishes by the first statement of prop. 13.

Definition

(Euler-Lagrange equation of motion)

Given a field bundle EE over spacetime Œ£\Sigma as in example 2 equipped with a local Lagrangian density L‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,1(E)\mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p+1,1}_{\Sigma}(E) as in def. 9 then the corresponding Euler-Lagrange equations of motion on fields Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E)\Phi \in \Gamma_\Sigma(E) is the equation

j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *(Œ¥ ELL)=0, j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast \left(\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}\right) = 0 \,,

where j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶):Œ£‚ÜíJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi) \colon \Sigma \to J^\infty_{\Sigma}(E) denotes the jet prolongation of Œ¶\Phi (def. 5), j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *j^\infty_{\Sigma}(\Phi)^\ast the operation of pullback of differential forms along this function, and Œ¥ EL\delta_{EL} is the Euler-Lagrange operator from prop. 4.

In the case that the field bundle is a trivial vector bundle over Minowski spacetime as in example 2 this equation is equivalently the following differential equation (again using prop. 4):

(‚àÇL‚àÇœï a‚àíddx Œº‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,Œº a+d 2dx Œºdx ŒΩ‚àÇL‚àÇœï ,ŒºŒΩ a‚àí‚ãØ)((x Œº),(Œ¶ a),(‚àÇŒ¶ a‚àÇx Œº),(‚àÇ 2Œ¶ a‚àÇx Œº‚àÇx ŒΩ),‚ãØ)=0. \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a} - \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu}} + \frac{d^2}{d x^\mu d x^\nu} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu\nu}} - \cdots \right) \left( (x^\mu), (\Phi^a), \left( \frac{\partial \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu}\right), \left( \frac{\partial^2 \Phi^a}{\partial x^\mu \partial x^\nu} \right), \cdots \right) \;=\; 0 \,.

We write

(24)Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0‚Ü™Œì Œ£(E) \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL} L = 0} \hookrightarrow \Gamma_\Sigma(E)

for the smooth subspace of the space of field histories (4) on those that solve this differential equation.

This is another incarnation of the ‚Äúshell‚Äù (12).

Similarly for Œ£ r‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_r \hookrightarrow \Sigma a submanifold of spacetime, we write

(25)Œì Œ£ r(E) Œ¥ ELL=0‚Ü™Œì Œ£ r(E) \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E)_{\delta_{EL} L = 0} \hookrightarrow \Gamma_{\Sigma_r}(E)

for the subspace of on-shell field histories restricted to the infinitesimal neighbourhood of Œ£ r\Sigma_r in Œ£\Sigma (1).

Example

(equation of motion of free real scalar field is Klein-Gordon equation)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of the free real scalar field from example 10.

By example 12 its Euler-Lagrange form is

Œ¥ ELL=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒΩ+m 2)Œ¥œï‚àßdvol œÉ \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \;=\; \left(\eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu \nu} + m^2 \right) \delta \phi \wedge dvol_\sigma

Hence for Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E)=C ‚àû(X)\Phi \in \Gamma_\Sigma(E) = C^\infty(X) a field trajectory, its Euler-Lagrange equation of motion according to def. 17 is

Œ∑ ŒºŒΩ‚àÇ 2‚àÇx Œº‚àÇx ŒΩŒ¶+m 2Œ¶=0 \eta^{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial^2 }{\partial x^\mu \partial x^\nu} \Phi + m^2 \Phi \;=\; 0

often abbreviated as

(‚ñ°+m 2)Œ¶=0. (\Box + m^2) \Phi \;=\; 0 \,.

This PDE is called the Klein-Gordon equation on Minowski spacetime. If the mass mm vanishes, m=0m = 0, then this is the relativistic wave equation.

Example

(equations of motion of free electromagnetism ‚Äì vacuum Maxwell equations)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime from example 11.

By example 13 its Euler-Lagrange form is

Œ¥ ELL=ddx Œºf ŒºŒΩŒ¥a ŒΩ. \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \;=\; \frac{d}{d x^\mu}f^{\mu \nu} \delta a_\nu \,.

Hence for A‚ààŒì Œ£(T *Œ£)=Œ© 1(Œ£)A \in \Gamma_{\Sigma}(T^\ast \Sigma) = \Omega^1(\Sigma) a field trajectory (‚Äúvector potential‚Äù), its Euler-Lagrange equation of motion according to def. 17 is

‚àÇ‚àÇx ŒºF ŒºŒΩ=0 ‚áî d‚ãÜ Œ∑F=0, \begin{aligned} & \frac{\partial}{\partial x^\mu} F^{\mu \nu} = 0 \\ \Leftrightarrow\;\; & d \star_\eta F = 0 \end{aligned} \,,

where F=dAF = d A is the Faraday tensor (2). (In the coordinate-free formulation in the second line ‚Äú‚ãÜ Œ∑\star_\eta‚Äù denotes the Hodge star operator induced by the pseudo-Riemannian metric Œ∑\eta on Minkowski spacetime.)

These PDEs are called the vacuum Maxwell's equations.

Proposition

(principle of extremal action)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

Then the de Rham differential of the action functional (def. 18) vanishes for all adiabatic switchings b‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma) on a field history Œ¶\Phi precisely if Œ¶\Phi solves the Euler-Lagrange equations of motion (def. 17):

(‚àÄb‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)(dùíÆ bL(Œ¶)=0))‚áî(j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)) *(Œ¥ ELL)=0). \left( \underset{b \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma)}{\forall} \left( d \mathcal{S}_{b \mathbf{L}}(\Phi) = 0 \right) \right) \;\Leftrightarrow\; \left( j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-))^\ast ( \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} ) = 0 \right) \,.
Proof

By prop. 13 we have for each fixed adiabatic switching bb the equivalence

(dùíÆ bL(Œ¶)=0)‚áî(‚à´ Œ£j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí)) *(Œ¥ ELL)(x)b(x)dvol Œ£(x)=0). \left( d \mathcal{S}_{b \mathbf{L}}(\Phi) \;=\; 0 \right) \;\Leftrightarrow\; \left( \int_\Sigma j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-))^\ast ( \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} )(x) \, b(x) dvol_\Sigma(x) \;=\; 0 \right) \,.

But if the right hand side holds for all bb, then (j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶(‚àí))) *(Œ¥ ELL)=0(j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi(-)))^\ast (\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}) = 0. Because suppose that j Œ£ ‚àû(Œ¶) *(Œ¥ ELL)j^\infty_\Sigma(\Phi)^\ast ( \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} ) does not vanish at some x‚ààŒ£x \in \Sigma, then by continuity it is non-vanishing also on some neighbourhood of xx and hence the integral of any one of its components against a non-negative or non-positive bump function bb supported inside this neighbourhood is non-vanishing.

Definition

(local observables)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) (def. 9) with on-shell space of histories Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0} (24) then the space

(26)Obs Œ£(E)‚âîC ‚àû(Œì Œ£(E)) Obs_\Sigma(E) \;\coloneqq\; C^\infty( \Gamma_\Sigma(E) )

of observables is simply the space of complex-valued smooth functions

A:Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0‚ü∂‚ÑÇ A \;\colon\; \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}

on the on-shell space of field histories. This is a star-algebra under pointwise complex conjugation.

(That we consider functions with values in complex numbers instead of real numbers is a reflection of the superposition principle in quantum physics, more about this below.)

On the other hand the local observables are the horizontal p+1-forms

  1. of compact spacetime support (def. 15)

  2. modulo total spacetime derivatives

  3. restricted to the shell ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty (12):

LocObs Œ£(E)‚âî(Œ© Œ£,cp p+1,0(E)/(im(d)))| ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû LocObs_\Sigma(E) \;\coloneqq\; \left(\Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E)/(im(d))\right)\vert_{\mathcal{E}^\infty}

which we may identify with the subspace of all observables (26) on those that arise as the image under transgression of variational differential forms œÑ Œ£\tau_\Sigma (def. 16) of local observables to functionals on the on-shell space of field histories:

LocObs Œ£(E)‚Ü™œÑ Œ£‚ààC ‚àû(Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0). LocObs_\Sigma(E) \overset{\tau_\Sigma}{\hookrightarrow} \in C^\infty\left( \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \right) \,.

This is a sub-vector space inside all observables which is in general not closed under the product of functions. We write

‚Ñ±‚âî‚ü®LocObs Œ£‚ü© C ‚àû(Œì Œ£(E)) Œ¥ ELL=0 \mathcal{F} \;\coloneqq\; \langle LocObs_\Sigma \rangle_{C^\infty\left(\Gamma_\Sigma(E)\right)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0}}

for the smallest subalgebra of observables, under the pointwise product, that contains all the local observables. This is called the algebra of multilocal observables.

maybe better consider formal power series of observables around a background solution

Example

(local observables of the real scalar field)

Consider the field bundle of the real scalar field (example 3).

A typical example of local observables (def. 18) in this case is the ‚Äúfield amplitude averaged over a given spacetime region‚Äù determined by a bump function b‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma). On an on-shell field configuration Œ¶\Phi this observable takes as value the integral

œÑ Œ£(bœï)(Œ¶)=‚à´ Œ£Œ¶(x)b(x)dvol Œ£(x). \tau_\Sigma(b \phi)(\Phi) \;=\; \int_\Sigma \Phi(x) b(x) dvol_\Sigma(x) \,.
Example

(local observables of the electromagnetic field)

Consider the field bundle for free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma.

Then for b‚ààC ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C^\infty(\Sigma) a bump function on spacetime, the transgression of the universal Faraday tensor (def. 8) against bb times the volume form is a local observable (def. 18), namely the field strength (2) of the electromagnetic field averaged over spacetime.

The definition of local observables in def. 18 uses explicit restriction to the shell, hence, by the principle of extremal action (prop. 16) to the the ‚Äúcritical locus‚Äù of the action functional. Such critical loci are often hard to handle explicitly. It often helps to consider a ‚Äúhomological resolution‚Äù given, in good circumstances, by the corresponding ‚Äúderived critical locus‚Äù.

In order to have good control over these resolutions, we now consider the first perturbative aspect of field theory, namely we consider the restriction of local observables to just an infinitesimal neighbourhood of a background on-shell field history:

Definition

(local observables around infinitesimal neighbourhood of background on-shell field history)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) and whose Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is spacetime-independent (example 5). Let Œ£√ó{œÜ}‚Ü™‚Ñ∞\Sigma \times \{\varphi\} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{E} be a constant section of the shell (19) as in example 5.

Then we write

LocObs Œ£(E,œÜ) LocObs_\Sigma(E,\varphi)

for the restriction of the local observables (def. 18) to the fiberwise infinitesimal neighbourhood (example 1) of Œ£√ó{œÜ}\Sigma \times \{\varphi\}.

Explicitly, this means the following:

First of all, by prop. 2 the dependence of the Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} on the order of field derivatives is bounded by some k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} on some neighbourhood of œÜ\varphi and hence, by the spacetime independence of L\mathbf{L}, on some neighbourhood of Œ£√ó{œÜ}\Sigma \times \{\varphi\}.

Therefore we may restrict without loss to the order-kk jets. By slight abuse of notation we still write

‚Ñ∞‚Ü™J Œ£ k(E) \mathcal{E} \hookrightarrow J^k_\Sigma(E)

for the corresponding shell. It follows then that the restriction of the ring Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E)\Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) of smooth functions on the jet bundle to the infinitesimal neighbourhood is equivalently the formal power series ring over C cp ‚àû(Œ£)C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma) in the variables

((œï a‚àíœÜ a),(œï ,Œº a‚àíœÜ ,Œº a),‚ãØ,(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a‚àíœÜ ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a)) ((\phi^a- \varphi^a), (\phi^a_{,\mu}- \varphi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots, (\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} - \varphi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}) )

We denote this by

(27)Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)‚âîC cp ‚àû(Œ£)[[(œï a‚àíœÜ a),(œï ,Œº a‚àíœÜ ,Œº a),‚ãØ,(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a‚àíœÜ ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a)]]. \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) \;\coloneqq\; C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma)\left[ \left[ (\phi^a - \varphi^a ), (\phi^a_{,\mu} -\varphi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots, (\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}- \varphi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}) \right] \right] \,.

A key consequence is that the further restriction of this ring to the shell ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty (12) is now simply the further quotient ring by the ideal generated by the total spacetime derivatives of the components ‚àÇ ELLŒ¥œï a\frac{\partial_{EL}L}{\delta \phi^a} of the Euler-Lagrange form (prop. 4).

(28)Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ ‚âîŒ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)/(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº lŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a) a‚àà{1,‚ãØ,s}l‚àà{1,‚ãØ,k}Œº r‚àà{0,‚ãØ,p} =C cp ‚àû(Œ£)[[(œï a‚àíœÜ a),(œï ,Œº a‚àíœÜ ,Œº a),‚ãØ,(œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a‚àíœÜ ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a)]]/(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº lŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a) a‚àà{1,‚ãØ,s}l‚àà{1,‚ãØ,k}Œº r‚àà{0,‚ãØ,p}. \begin{aligned} \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}} & \coloneqq \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) / \left( \frac{d^k}{ d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_l}} \frac{\delta_{EL} L}{\delta \phi^a} \right)_{ { a \in \{1, \cdots, s\} } \atop { { l \in \{1, \cdots, k\} } \atop { \mu_r \in \{0, \cdots, p\} } } } \\ & = C^\infty_{cp}(\Sigma)\left[ \left[ (\phi^a - \varphi^a ), (\phi^a_{,\mu} -\varphi^a_{,\mu}), \cdots, (\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}- \varphi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}) \right] \right] / \left( \frac{d^k}{ d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_l}} \frac{\delta_{EL} L}{\delta \phi^a} \right)_{ { a \in \{1, \cdots, s\} } \atop { { l \in \{1, \cdots, k\} } \atop { \mu_r \in \{0, \cdots, p\} } } } \end{aligned} \,.

Finally the local observables restricted to the infinitesimal neighbourhood is the module

(29)LocObs Œ£(E,œÜ)‚âÉ(Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞‚ü®dvol Œ£‚ü©)/(im(d)). LocObs_\Sigma(E,\varphi) \;\simeq\; \left( \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}} \langle dvol_\Sigma \rangle \right)/(im(d)) \,.

The space of local observables in def. 19 is the quotient of a formal power series algebra by the components of the Euler-Lagrange form and by the image of the horizontal spacetime de Rham differential. It is convenient to also conceive of the components of the Euler-Lagrange form as the image of a differential, for then the algebra of local observables obtaines a cohomological interpretation, which will lend itself to computation. This differential, whose image is the components of the Euler-Lagrange form, is called the BV-differential. We introduce this now first (def. 20 below) in a direct ad-hoc way. Further below we discuss the conceptual nature of this differential as part of the construction of the reduced phase space as a derived critical locus (example 34 below).

Definition

(local BV-complex of ordinary Lagrangian density)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) and whose Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is spacetime-independent (example 19). Let Œ£√ó{œÜ}‚Ü™‚Ñ∞ ‚àû\Sigma \times \{\varphi\} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{E}^\infty be a constant section of the shell (19).

In correspondence with def. 19, write

Œì Œ£,cp(V Œ£J ‚àûŒ£E,œÜ)‚âÉŒì Œ£,cp(J ‚àûŒ£V Œ£E,œÜ)‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E)Mod \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}(V_\Sigma J^\infty^\Sigma E,\varphi) \simeq \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}(J^\infty^\Sigma V_\Sigma E,\varphi) \;\in\; \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) Mod

for the restriction of vertical vector fields on the jet bundle to the fiberwise infinitesimal neighbourhood (example 1) of Œ£√óœÜ\Sigma \times {\varphi}.

Now we regard this as a graded module over Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)\Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) (27) concentrated in degree ‚àí1-1:

Œì Œ£,cp(J Œ£ ‚àûV Œ£E,œÜ)[‚àí1]‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E)Mod ‚Ñ§. \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}(J^\infty_\Sigma V_\Sigma E,\varphi)[-1] \;\in\; \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) Mod^{\mathbb{Z}} \,.

This is called the module of antifields corresponding the given type of fields encoded by EE.

If the field bundle is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) with field coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a), then we write

(30)œï¬Ø a,Œº 1‚ãØŒº l‚âî(‚àÇ (œï Œº 1‚ãØŒº l a))[‚àí1]‚ààŒì Œ£,cp(V Œ£J Œ£ ‚àûE,œÜ)[‚àí1] \overline{\phi}_{a,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_l} \;\coloneqq\; \left( \partial_{(\phi^a_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_l})} \right)[-1] \;\in\; \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}(V_\Sigma J^\infty_\Sigma E,\varphi)[-1]

for the vector field generator that takes derivatives along ‚àÇ œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a\partial_{\phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}}, but regarded now in degree -1.

Evaluation of vector fields in the total spacetime derivatives d ldx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº lŒ¥L‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,0(E)‚àßŒ¥Œ© Œ£ 0,0(E)\frac{d^l}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_l}} \delta\mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p,0}_\Sigma(E) \wedge \delta \Omega^{0,0}_\Sigma(E) of the variational derivative (prop. 4) yields a linear map over Œ© Œ£,cp ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E,œÜ)\Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) (28)

Œπ (‚àí)Œ¥ ELL:Œì Œ£,cp(J Œ£ ‚àûV Œ£E,œÜ)[‚àí1]‚ü∂Œ© Œ£,cp p+1,0(E,œÜ). \iota_{(-)}\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} \;\colon\; \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}( J^\infty_\Sigma V_\Sigma E,\varphi)[-1] \longrightarrow \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) \,.

If we use the volume form dvol Œ£dvol_\Sigma on spacetime Œ£\Sigma to induce an identification

Œ© Œ£ p+1,0(E)‚âÉC ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))‚ü®dvol œÉ‚ü© \Omega^{p+1,0}_\Sigma(E) \;\simeq\; C^\infty(J^\infty_\Sigma(E))\langle dvol_\sigma\rangle

with respect to which the Lagrangian density decomposes as

L=Ldvol Œ£ \mathbf{L} = L dvol_\Sigma

then this is a Œ© œÉ 0,0(E,œÜ)\Omega^{0,0}_\sigma(E,\varphi)-linear map of the form

Œπ (‚àí)Œ¥L EL:Œì Œ£,cp ev(V Œ£E,œÜ)[‚àí1]‚ü∂Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ). \iota_{(-)}{\delta L_{EL}} \;\colon\; \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}^{ev}(V_\Sigma E,\varphi)[-1] \longrightarrow \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) \,.

In the special case that the field bundle E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) with field coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a) so that the Euler-Lagrange variational derivative has the coordinate expansion

Œ¥ L=Œ¥ ELLŒ¥œï aŒ¥œï a \delta_L \;=\; \frac{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} \delta \phi^a

then this map is given on the antifield basis elements (30) by

Œπ (‚àí)Œ¥L EL:œï¬Ø a,Œº 1‚ãØŒº l‚Ü¶d ldx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº lŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a. \iota_{(-)} {\delta L_{EL}} \;\colon\; \overline{\phi}_{a,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_l} \;\mapsto\; \frac{d^l}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_l}} \frac{\delta_{EL} L}{\delta \phi^a} \,.

Consider then the graded symmetric algebra

C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû((V Œ£E)[‚àí1]√ó Œ£E,œÜ))‚âîSym Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)(Œì Œ£,cp(J Œ£ ‚àûV Œ£E,œÜ)[‚àí1]) C^\infty( J^\infty_\Sigma((V_\Sigma E)[-1] \times_\Sigma E, \varphi) ) \;\coloneqq\; Sym_{\Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)}\left( \Gamma_{\Sigma,cp}(J^\infty_\Sigma V_\Sigma E,\varphi)[-1] \right)

which is generated over Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)\Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) from the module of vector fields in degree -1.

If we think of a single vector field as a fiber-wise linear function on the cotangent bundle, and of a multivector field similarly as a multilinear function on the cotangent bundle, then we may think of this as the algebra of functions on the infinitesimal neighbourhood (example 1) of œÜ\varphi inside the graded manifold (V Œ£E)[‚àí1]√ó Œ£E(V_\Sigma E)[-1] \times_\Sigma E.

Let now

(31)s BV:C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû((V Œ£E)[‚àí1]√ó Œ£E,œÜ))‚ü∂C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû((V Œ£E)[‚àí1]√ó Œ£E,œÜ)) s_{BV} \;\colon\; C^\infty( J^\infty_\Sigma((V_\Sigma E)[-1] \times_\Sigma E, \varphi) ) \;\longrightarrow\; C^\infty( J^\infty_\Sigma((V_\Sigma E)[-1] \times_\Sigma E, \varphi) )

be the unique extension of the linear map Œπ (‚àí)Œ¥ ELL\iota_{(-)}{\delta_{EL} L} to an ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-linear derivation of degree +1 on this algebra.

The resulting differential graded-commutative algebra over ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}

Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ BV‚âî(C ‚àû(J Œ£ ‚àû((V Œ£E)[‚àí1]√ó Œ£E,œÜ)),s BV) \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}} \;\coloneqq\; \left( C^\infty( J^\infty_\Sigma((V_\Sigma E)[-1] \times_\Sigma E, \varphi) ) \,,\, s_{BV} \right)

is called the local BV-complex of the Lagrangian field theory at the background solution œÜ\varphi. This is the CE-algebra of the infintiesimal neighbourhood of Œ£√ó{œÜ}\Sigma \times \{\varphi\} in the derived prolonged shell (def. 36). In this case, in the absence of any explicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries, this is an example of a Koszul complex.

There are canonical homomorphisms of dgc-algebras, one from the algebra of functions Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)\Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) on the infinitesimal neighbourhood of the background solution œÜ\varphi to the local BV-complex and from there to the local observables on the neighbourhood of the background solution œÜ\varphi (28), all considered with compact spacetime support:

(32)Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)‚ü∂Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ BV‚ü∂Œ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi) \longrightarrow \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}} \longrightarrow \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}}

such that the composite is the canonical quotient coprojection.

Similarly we obtain a factorization for the entire variational bicomplex:

(33)Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E,œÜ)‚ü∂Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ BV‚ü∂Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞, \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E,\varphi) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}} \longrightarrow \Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}} \,,

where Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,‚Ä¢(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ BV\Omega^{\bullet,\bullet}_\Sigma(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}} is now triply graded, with three anti-commuting differentials dd Œ¥\delta and s BVs_{BV}.

By construction this is now such that the local observables (def. 18) are the cochain cohomology of this complex in horizontal form degree p+1, vertical degree 0 and BV-degree 0:

LocObs Œ£(E)‚âÉŒ© Œ£,cp p+1,0(E)/(im(s BV+d)). LocObs_\Sigma(E) \simeq \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E)/(im(s_{BV} + d)) \,.
Definition

(states)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}), then a (classical) state is a function from the space Obs Œ£Obs_\Sigma of observables to the complex numbers

‚ü®‚àí‚ü©:Obs Œ£‚ü∂‚ÑÇ \langle -\rangle \;\colon\; Obs_\Sigma \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}

such that

  1. (linearity) this is a linear map;

  2. (positivity) for any A‚ààObsA \in Obs we have that ‚ü®A *A‚ü©‚â•0\langle A^\ast A \rangle \geq 0

(Below we consider quantum states. These are defined formally in just the same way, only that now the algebra of observables is equipped with another product, which changes the meaning of the product expression A *AA^\ast A.)

\,

Phase space

It might seem that with the construction of the local observables (def. 18) on the on-shell space of field histories (prop. 4) the field theory defined by a Lagrangian density (def. 9) has been completely analyzed: This data specifies, in principle, which field histories are realized, and which observable properties these have.

In particular, if the Euler-Lagrange equations of motion (def. 17) admit Cauchy surfaces (def. 22 below), i.e. spatial codimension 1 slices of spacetimes such that a field history is uniquely specified already by its restriction to the infinitesimal neighbourhood of that spatial slice, then a sufficiently complete collection of local observables whose spacetime support (def. 15) covers that Cauchy surface allows to predict the evolution of the field configurations through time from that Cauchy surface.

This is all what one might think a theory of physical fields should accomplish, and in fact this is essentially all that was thought to be required of a theory of nature from about Isaac Newton‚Äôs time to about Max Planck‚Äôs time.

However, we have also seen that there are generically infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian (def. 13) and their analog in codimension 1 infinitesimal symmetries of the pre-symplectic current (def. 14), forming an infinitesimal symmetry group, reflected by the local Poisson bracket (prop. 15).

The transgression of that local Poisson bracket to the on-shell space of field histories yields the corresponding infinitesimal symmetry group acting on the on-shell field histories, the actual Poisson bracket. This data, the on-shell space of field histories equipped with infinitesimal gauge symmetry exhibited by the Poisson bracket is called the phase space of the theory (def. 23) below.

But from the basic principles of homotopy theory we learn that given any structure on a space which is invariant with respect to a symmetry group acting on the space (here: the Lagrangian/action functional on the jet bundle/space of field histories) then the true structure at hand is the homotopy quotient of that space by that symmetry group. We will explain this further below. This here just to point out that the homotopy quotient of the phase space by the infintiesimal symmetries of the presymplectic current is called the symplectic groupoid and that true algebra of observables is hence the (polarized) convolution algebra of function on this groupoid. This turns out to the ‚Äúalgebra of quantum observables‚Äù and the passage from the naive local observables on presymplectic phase space to this non-commutative algebra of functions on its homotopy quotient to the symplectic groupoid is called quantization. This we discuss in much detail below; for the moment this is just to motivate why the covariant phase space is the crucial construction to be extracted from a Lagrangian field theory.

\,

{on-shell space of field histories with local observables restricted to any Cauchy surface} ‚ü∂homotopy-quotient by infinitesimal symmetries {covariant phase space} ‚ü∂Lie algebra of functions {Poisson algebra of observables} ‚Üò ‚Üì Lie integration ‚Üì quantization {symplecticgroupoid} ‚ü∂polarized convolution algebra of functions {quantum algebra of observables} \array{ \left\{ \array{ \text{on-shell space of field histories} \\ \text{with local observables} \\ \text{restricted to any Cauchy surface} } \right\} &\overset{\array{ \text{homotopy-quotient by} \\ \text{infinitesimal symmetries} }}{\longrightarrow} & \left\{ \array{ \text{covariant} \\ \text{phase space} } \right\} &\overset{ \text{Lie algebra of functions} }{\longrightarrow}& \left\{ \array{ \text{Poisson algebra} \\ \text{of observables} } \right\} \\ & \searrow & \Big\downarrow{}^\mathrlap{{\text{Lie integration}}} && \Big\downarrow{}^{\mathrlap{quantization}} \\ && \left\{ \text{symplectic} \atop \text{groupoid} \right\} & \overset{ \array{ \text{polarized convolution} \\ \text{algebra of functions} } }{\longrightarrow}& \left\{ \array{ \text{quantum algebra} \\ \text{of observables} } \right\} }

\,

A remarkable aspect of Lagrangian field theory is that the de Rham differential of the local Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} (def. 9) decomposes into two kinds of variational differential forms (prop. 4):

On the one hand the Euler-Lagrange variational derivative Œ¥ ELL‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,1(E)\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \in \Omega^{p+1,1}_\Sigma(E) appears. This being of horizontal degree p+1p+1 its transgression implies a differential 1-form on the space of field histories over all of spacetime. We have seen that this is the derivative of the action functional (def. 17) which embodies the principle of extremal action (prop. 16) and with it a structure in full spacetime dimension p+1p+1: the on-shell space of field histories Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Gamma_{\Sigma}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} (def. 17).

But there is a second contribution: The presymplectic current Œ© BFV‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E)\Omega_{BFV} \in \Omega^{p,2}_{\Sigma}(E). Since this is of horizontal degree pp, its transgression implies a further structure on the space of field histories of restricted to spacetime submanifolds of dimension pp (i.e. of spacetime ‚Äúcodimension 1‚Äù). There may be such submanifolds such that this restriction does not actually change the on-shell space of field histories, these are called the Cauchy surfaces (def. 22 below).

Moreover, we have seen that, via the Noether theorem (prop. 9) and the Hamiltonian Noether theorem (prop. 11), the infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian and of the presymplectic potential induce special classes of variational differential forms that are also in horizontal degree pp: the conserved currents (def. 13) and the Hamiltonian differential form (def. 14). By transgression this impplies that the corresponding Lie (p+1)-algebras of local infinitesimal symmetries, namely the Dickey bracket Lie algebra and the local Poisson bracket (prop. 15), induce Lie algebra structure on physical quantities in spacetime dimension pp called conserved charges (prop. 25 below) and Hamiltonian local observables (def. 24 below), the actual Poisson bracket (def. 26 below).

This structure in spacetime codimension 1, i.e. the restriction of the on-shell space of field histories to a Cauchy surface and equipped via transgression with the induced presymplectic form and Poisson bracket on Hamiltonian local observables is called the phase space of the Lagrangian field theory (def. 23 below), and specifically the covariant phase space, to amplify that it does not actually depend on the choice of Cauchy surface (prop. 17 below).

Definition

(Cauchy surface)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E, \mathbf{L}) on a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 9), then a Cauchy surface is a submanifold Œ£ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma such that the restriction map from the on-shell space of field histories Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} (24) to the space (25) of on-shell field histories restricted to the infinitesimal neighbourhood of Œ£ p\Sigma_p is an isomorphism:

(33)Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0‚ü∂‚âÉ(‚àí)| N Œ£Œ£ pŒì Œ£ p(E) Œ¥ ELL=0. \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0 } \underoverset{\simeq}{(-)\vert_{N_\Sigma \Sigma_p}}{\longrightarrow} \Gamma_{\Sigma_p}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \,.
Definition

(phase space associated with a Cauchy surface)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E, \mathbf{L}) on a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 9) and given a Cauchy surface Œ£ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma (def. 22) then the corresponding phase space is

  1. the smooth space Œì Œ£ p(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Gamma_{\Sigma_p}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} (25) of on-shell field histories restricted to the infinitesimal neighbourhood of Œ£ p\Sigma_p;

  2. equipped with the presymplectic form

    (34)œâ Œ£ p‚âîœÑ Œ£ p(Œ© BFV)‚ààŒ© 2(Œì Œ£ p(E) Œ¥ ELL=0) \omega_{\Sigma_p} \;\coloneqq\; \tau_{\Sigma_p}\left(\Omega_{BFV}\right) \;\in\; \Omega^2\left( \Gamma_{\Sigma_p}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \right)

    which is the transgression of the presymplectic current Œ© BFV\Omega_{BFV} (def. 4).

Example

(presymplectic form for free real scalar field)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory for the free real scalar field from example 10.

Its space of field histories is simply the smooth space C ‚àû(Œ£)C^\infty(\Sigma) of smooth functions with real values on Minkowski spacetime. This is naturally a vector space. Since the equation of motion is the Klein-Gordon equation (‚ñ°+m 2)Œ¶=0(\Box + m^2) \Phi = 0 (example 14) which is a linear differential operator, also the on-shell space of field histories is still canonically a vector space.

The presymplectic form on the phase space (def. 23) associated with a Cauchy surface Œ£ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma takes two smooth function w 1,w 2‚ààC ‚àû(Œ£)w_1,w_2 \in C^\infty(\Sigma), regarded as tangent vectors at zero to

œâ Œ£ p(w 1,w 2)=‚à´ Œ£ p((‚àÇ nw 1)w 2‚àíw 1‚àÇ nw 2)dvol Œ£ p, \omega_{\Sigma_p}(w_1, w_2) \;=\; \int_{\Sigma_{p}} \left( (\partial_n w_1) w_2 - w_1 \partial_n w_2 \right) dvol_{\Sigma_{p}} \,,

where dvol Œ£ pdvol_{\Sigma_p} is the volume form on the Cauchy surface which is induced from the ambient metric on Minkowski spacetime, and n‚ààNŒ£ pn \in N \Sigma_p denotes the normal vector field of the embedding.

Proof

By example 12 the presymplectic current is

Œ© BFV=(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩŒ¥œï ,Œº‚àßŒ¥œï)‚àßŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E). \Omega_{BFV} \;=\; \left(\eta^{\mu \nu} \delta \phi_{,\mu} \wedge \delta \phi \right) \wedge \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_{\Sigma} \;\in\; \Omega^{p,2}_{\Sigma}(E) \,.

Hence its transgression is

œâ Œ£ p(w 1,w 2) =(‚à´ Œ£ p(Œ∑ ŒºŒΩŒ¥‚àÇ Œºœï‚àßŒ¥œï)Œπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£)(w 1,w 2) =‚à´ Œ£ p((‚àÇ nw 1)w 2‚àíw 1‚àÇ nw 2)dvol Œ£ p \begin{aligned} \omega_{\Sigma_{p}}(w_1, w_2) & = \left( \int_{\Sigma_p} \left( \eta^{\mu \nu} \delta \partial_\mu \phi \wedge \delta \phi \right) \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_\Sigma \right) (w_1, w_2) \\ & = \int_{\Sigma_{p}} \left( (\partial_n w_1) w_2 - w_1 \partial_n w_2 \right) dvol_{\Sigma_{p}} \end{aligned}

Since by definition of Cauchy surface (def. 22) the underlying smooth space of the phase space associated with it (def. 23) is isomorphic to the on-shell space of field histories, and hence also to the phase spaces associated with any other Cauchy surface, a natural question is whether their presymplectic forms are compatible with these isomorphisms, so that all phase spaces are in fact isomorphic as presymplectic smooth spaces. The following proposition says that this is the case. Therefore one speaks of the covariant phase space of a Lagrangian field theory:

Proposition

(covariant phase space)

Consider (E,L)(E, \mathbf{L}) a Lagrangian field theory on a spacetime Œ£\Sigma (def. 9).

Let

Œ£ tra‚Ü™traŒ£ \Sigma_{tra} \overset{tra}{\hookrightarrow} \Sigma

be a submanifold with two boundary components ‚àÇŒ£ tra=Œ£ in‚äîŒ£ out\partial \Sigma_{tra} = \Sigma_{in} \sqcup \Sigma_{out} , both of which are Cauchy surfaces (def. 22).

Then the corresponding inclusion diagram

Œ£ tra in‚Üó ‚Üñ out Œ£ in Œ£ out \array{ && \Sigma_{tra} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{in}}\nearrow && \nwarrow^{\mathrm{out}} \\ \Sigma_{in} && && \Sigma_{out} }

induces a Lagrangian correspondence between the associated phase spaces (def. 23)

Œì Œ£ tra(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 (‚àí)| in‚Üô ‚Üò (‚àí)| out Œì Œ£ (in)(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 Œì Œ£ (out)(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 œâ in‚Üò ‚Üô œâ out Œ© 2 \array{ && \Gamma_{\Sigma_{tra}}(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ (-)\vert_{in} }}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{ (-)\vert_{out} }} \\ \Gamma_{\Sigma^{(in)}}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}= 0} && && \Gamma_{\Sigma^{(out)}}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}= 0} \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\omega_{in}}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\omega_{out}}} \\ && \mathbf{\Omega}^{2} }

in that the pullback of the two presymplectic forms (34) coincides on the space of field histories:

((‚àí)| in) *(œâ in)=((‚àí)| out) *(œâ out)AAAA‚ààŒ© 2(Œì Œ£ tra(E) Œ¥ ELL=0). \left( (-)\vert_{in}\right)^\ast\left( \omega_{in}\right) \;=\; \left( (-)\vert_{out} \right)^\ast \left( \omega_{out} \right) \phantom{AAAA} \in \Omega^2 \left( \Gamma_{\Sigma_{tra}}(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0} \right) \,.

Hence there is a well defined presymplectic form

œâ‚ààŒ© 2(Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0) \omega \in \Omega^2\left( \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}} = 0 \right)

on the genuine space of field histories, given by œâ‚âîi *œâ Œ£ p\omega \coloneqq i^\ast \omega_{\Sigma_p} for any Cauchy surface Œ£ p‚Ü™iŒ£\Sigma_p \overset{i}{\hookrightarrow} \Sigma. This presymplectic smooth space

(Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL,œâ) \left( \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}} \,,\, \omega \right)

is therefore called the covariant phase space of the Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}).

Proof

By prop. 6 the total spacetime derivative dŒ© BFVd \Omega_{BFV} of the presymplectic current vanishes on-shell:

dŒ© BFV=‚àíŒ¥Œ¥ ELL. d \Omega_{BFV} = - \delta \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} \,.

This means that the transgression of dŒ© BFVd \Omega_{BFV} to Œì Œ£ tra(E) Œ¥ ELL=0\Gamma_{\Sigma_{tra}}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} vanishes. But then the claim follows with prop. 13:

0 =œÑ Œ£ tra(dŒ© BFV) =((‚àí)| Œ£ tra) *œÑ ‚àÇŒ£ traŒ© BFV. \begin{aligned} 0 & = \tau_{\Sigma_{tra}}(d \Omega_{BFV}) \\ & = ((-)\vert_{\Sigma_{tra}})^\ast \tau_{\partial \Sigma_{tra}} \Omega_{BFV} \,. \end{aligned}
Definition

(Hamiltonian local observables)

Let (E,L)(E, \mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

Consider a local observable (def. 18)

œÑ Œ£(A):Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0‚ü∂‚ÑÇ, \tau_\Sigma(A) \;\colon\; \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C} \,,

hence the transgression of a variational horizontal p+1p+1-form A‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp p+1,0(E)A \in \Omega^{p+1,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E) of compact spacetime support.

Given a Cauchy surface Œ£ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma (def. 22) we say that œÑ Œ£(A)\tau_\Sigma (A) is Hamiltonian if it is also the transgression of a Hamiltonian differential form (def. 14), hence if there exists

(H,v)‚ààŒ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E) (H,v) \in \Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma, Ham}(E)

whose transgression over the Cauchy surface Œ£ p\Sigma_p equals the transgression of AA over all of spacetime Œ£\Sigma, under the isomorphism (33)

Œì Œ£(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 ‚ü∂‚âÉ(‚àí)| N Œ£Œ£ p Œì Œ£ p(E) Œ¥ ELL=0 œÑ Œ£(A)‚Üò ‚Üô œÑ Œ£ p(H) Œ© 2 \array{ \Gamma_\Sigma(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0 } && \underoverset{\simeq}{(-)\vert_{N_\Sigma \Sigma_p}}{\longrightarrow} && \Gamma_{\Sigma_p}(E)_{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0} \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\tau_\Sigma}(A)}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{ \tau_{\Sigma_p}(H) }} \\ && \mathbf{\Omega}^2 }

Beware that the local observable œÑ Œ£ p(H)\tau_{\Sigma_p}(H) defined by a Hamiltonian differential form H‚ààŒ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E)H \in \Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma,Ham}(E) as in def. 24 does in general depend not just on the choice of HH, but also on the choice Œ£ p\Sigma_p of the Cauchy surface. The exception are those Hamiltonian forms which are conserved currents:

Proposition

(conserved charges ‚Äì transgression of conserved currents)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

If a Hamiltonian differential form J‚ààŒ© Œ£,Ham p,0(E)J \in \Omega^{p,0}_{\Sigma,Ham}(E) (def. 14) happens to be a conserved current (def. 13) in that its total spacetime derivative vanishes on-shell

dJ| ‚Ñ∞=0 d J \vert_{\mathcal{E}} \;= \; 0

then the induced Hamiltonian local observable œÑ Œ£ p(J)\tau_{\Sigma_p}(J) (def. 24) is independent of the choice of Cauchy surface Œ£ p\Sigma_p (def 22) in that for Œ£ p,Œ£‚Ä≤ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p, \Sigma'_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma any two Cauchy surfaces which are cobordant, then

œÑ Œ£ p(J)=œÑ Œ£‚Ä≤ p(J). \tau_{\Sigma_p}(J) = \tau_{\Sigma'_p}(J) \,.

The resulting constant is called the conserved charge of the conserved current, traditionally denoted

Q‚âîœÑ Œ£ p(J). Q \;\coloneqq\; \tau_{\Sigma_p}(J) \,.
Proof

By definition the transgression of dJd J vanishes on the on-shell space of field configurations. Therefore the result is given by Stokes' theorem.

Definition

(Poisson bracket of Hamiltonian local observables on covariant phase space)

The Poisson bracket on Hamiltonian local observables (def. 24) is the transgression (def. 16) of the Poisson bracket Lie (p+1)-algebra (def. 15) of the corresponding Hamiltonian differential forms (def. 15) to the covariant phase space (def. 17).

Explicitly: for Œ£ p‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_p \hookrightarrow \Sigma a choice of Cauchy surface (def. 22) then the Poisson bracket between two local Hamiltonian observables œÑ Œ£ p((H i,v i))\tau_{\Sigma_p}((H_i, v_i)) is

(35){œÑ Œ£ p((H 1,v 1)),œÑ Œ£ p((H 2,v 2))}‚âîœÑ Œ£ p({(H 1,v 1),(H 2,v 2)}), \left\{ \tau_{\Sigma_p}((H_1, v_1)) \,,\, \tau_{\Sigma_p}( (H_2, v_2) ) \right\} \;\coloneqq\; \tau_{\Sigma_p}( \{ (H_1, v_1), (H_2, v_2) \} ) \,,

where on the right we have the transgression of the Poisson bracket of Hamiltonian forms on the jet bundle.

Proof

We need to see that equation (35) is well defined, in that it does not depend on the choice of Hamiltonian form (H i,v i)(H_i, v_i) representing the local Hamiltonian observable œÑ Œ£ p(H i)\tau_{\Sigma_p}(H_i).

It is clear that all the transgressions involved depend only on the restriction of the Hamiltonian forms to the pullback of the jet bundle to N Œ£Œ£ pN_\Sigma \Sigma_p. Moreover the Poisson bracket on the jet bundle (23) respects this restriction.

Now after this restriction, a Hamiltonian form is in the kernel of the transgression relative to Œ£ p\Sigma_p precisely if it is horizontally exact. Therefore the claim follows with the statement that horizontally exact forms constitute a Lie ideal for the Poisson bracket on the jet bundle (lemma 1).

Example

(Poisson bracket of the real scalar field ‚Äì the Peierls bracket)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of the free scalar field (example 10), and consider the Cauchy surface defined by x 0=0x^0 = 0.

By example 16 the local Poisson bracket of the Hamiltonian forms

Q‚âîœïŒπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£‚ààŒ© p,0(E) Q \coloneqq \phi \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma \in \Omega^{p,0}(E)

and

P‚âîŒ∑ ŒºŒΩœï ,ŒºŒπ ‚àÇ ŒΩdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© p,0(E). P \coloneqq \eta^{\mu \nu} \phi_{,\mu} \iota_{\partial_\nu} dvol_{\Sigma} \in \Omega^{p,0}(E) \,.

is

{Q,P}=Œπ v QŒπ v Pœâ=Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£. \{Q,P\} = \iota_{v_Q} \iota_{v_P} \omega = \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma \,.

Upon transgression according to def. 26 this yields the following Poisson bracket
