{‚à´ Œ£ pb 1(x‚Üí)œï(t,x‚Üí)Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£(x)d px‚Üí,‚à´ Œ£ pb 2(x‚Üí)‚àÇ 0œï(t,x‚Üí)Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£(x‚Üí)}=‚à´ Œ£ pb 1(x‚Üí)b 2(x‚Üí)Œπ ‚àÇ 0dvol Œ£(x‚Üí)d px‚Üí. \left\{ \int_{\Sigma_p} b_1(\vec x) \phi(t,\vec x) \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma(x) d^p \vec x \;,\; \int_{\Sigma_p} b_2(\vec x) \partial_0 \phi(t,\vec x) \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma(\vec x) \right\} \;=\; \int_{\Sigma_p} b_1(\vec x) b_2(\vec x) \iota_{\partial_0} dvol_\Sigma(\vec x) d^p \vec x \,.

where

œï(x),‚àÇ 0œï(x):PhaseSpace(Œ£ p t)‚Üí‚Ñù \phi(x), \partial_0 \phi(x) : PhaseSpace(\Sigma_p^t) \to \mathbb{R}

denote the point-evaluation functions (functionals), which act on a field configuration Œ¶‚ààŒì Œ£(E)=C ‚àû(Œ£)\Phi \in \Gamma_\Sigma(E) = C^\infty(\Sigma) as

œï(x)(Œ¶)‚âîŒ¶(x)AAAAAAAA‚àÇ 0œï(x)(Œ¶)‚âî‚àÇ 0Œ¶(x). \phi(x)(\Phi) \coloneqq \Phi(x) \phantom{AAAAAAAA} \partial_0 \phi(x) (\Phi) \coloneqq \partial_0 \Phi(x) \,.

Notice that these point-evaluation functions themselves do not arise as the transgression of elements in Œ© p,0(E)\Omega^{p,0}(E), only their smearings such as ‚à´ Œ£ pb 1œïdvol Œ£ p\int_{\Sigma_p} b_1 \phi dvol_{\Sigma_p} do. Nevertheless we may express the above Poisson bracket conveniently via the integral kernel

(36){œï(t,x‚Üí),œï(t,y‚Üí)}=Œ¥(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí). \{\phi(t,\vec x), \phi(t,\vec y) \} = \delta(\vec x - \vec y) \,.

This integral kernel is the causal propagator

Œî‚ààùíü‚Ä≤(Œ£√óŒ£) \Delta \;\in\; \mathcal{D}'(\Sigma \times \Sigma)

(also known as the Pauli-Jordan distribution or Peierls bracket) on Minkowski spacetime:

{œï(x),œï(y)} =Œî(x,y) ‚âî‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´12E(k‚Üí)(e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0‚àík‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí)‚àíe +iE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0+k‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí))d pk‚Üí =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Œ¥(k Œºk Œº+m 2)sgn(k 0)e ‚àíik Œº(x‚àíy) Œºd p+1k. \begin{aligned} \{ \phi(x), \phi(y) \} & = \Delta(x,y) \\ & \coloneqq -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \tfrac{1}{2 E(\vec k)}\left( e^{- i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 - \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} - e^{+ i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 + \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} \right) d^p \vec k \\ & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \delta( k_\mu k^\mu + m^2 ) sgn( k_0 ) e^{ - i k_\mu (x-y)^\mu } d^{p+1} k \,. \end{aligned}
Proof

By Fourier transform the general solution to the Klein-Gordon equation (example 14) may be expressed in the form

Œ¶(x)=(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Amp(k)e ‚àíik Œºx ŒºŒ¥(k Œºk Œº+m 2)d p+1k, \Phi(x) \;=\; (2\pi)^{-p} \int Amp(k) e^{- i k_\mu x^\mu } \delta( k_\mu k^\mu + m^2 ) d^{p+1} k \,,

where Amp(k)‚àà‚ÑÇAmp(k) \in \mathbb{C} is the complex amplitude of the kkth mode (k‚àà‚Ñù p+1)(k \in \mathbb{R}^{p+1}).

We may split this into the contributions with positive and those with negative energy k 0k_0 by decomposing the integral over k 0k_0 as

Œ¶(x) =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´ 0 ‚àû‚à´Amp(k 0,k‚Üí)e ‚àíik 0x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚ÜíŒ¥(‚àík 0 2+k‚Üí+m 2)d pk‚Üídk 0 =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´ 0 ‚àû‚à´Amp(‚àík 0,k‚Üí)e +ik 0x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚ÜíŒ¥(‚àík 0 2+k‚Üí 2+m 2)d pk‚Üídk 0. \begin{aligned} \Phi(x) & = \phantom{+} (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int_0^\infty \int Amp(k_0, \vec k) e^{- i k_0 x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \delta(- k_0^2 + \vec k + m^2) d^p \vec k \, d k_0 \\ & \phantom{=} + (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int_0^\infty \int Amp(-k_0, \vec k) e^{+ i k_0 x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \delta(-k_0^2 + \vec k^2 + m^2) d^p \vec k \, d k_0 \,. \end{aligned}

By changing integration variables via k 0=+hk_0 = +\sqrt{ h } this yields

Œ¶(x) =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´ 0 ‚àû‚à´Amp(h,k‚Üí)e ‚àíihx 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚ÜíŒ¥(‚àíh+k‚Üí+m 2)d pk‚Üídh2h =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´ 0 ‚àû‚à´Amp(‚àíh,k‚Üí)e +ihx 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚ÜíŒ¥(‚àíh+k‚Üí 2+m 2)d pk‚Üídh2h =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´Amp(E(k‚Üí),k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚Üí =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´Amp(‚àíE(k‚Üí),k‚Üí)e +iE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚Üí \begin{aligned} \Phi(x) & = \phantom{+} (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int_0^\infty \int Amp(\sqrt{h}, \vec k) e^{- i \sqrt{h} x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \delta(- h + \vec k + m^2) d^p \vec k \, \frac{d h}{2\sqrt{h}} \\ & \phantom{=} + (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int_0^\infty \int Amp(- \sqrt{h}, \vec k) e^{+ i \sqrt{h} x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \delta(- h + \vec k^2 + m^2) d^p \vec k \, \frac{d h}{2 \sqrt{h}} \\ & = \phantom{+} (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int Amp(E(\vec k), \vec k) e^{- i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k \\ & \phantom{=} + (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int Amp(-E(\vec k), \vec k) e^{+ i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k \end{aligned}

where we defined the on-shell energy

E(k‚Üí)‚âî+k‚Üí 2+m 2. E(\vec k) \coloneqq + \sqrt{ \vec k^2 + m^2 } \,.

It is convenient to also change variables k‚Üí‚Ü¶‚àík‚Üí\vec k \mapsto - \vec k in the second integral. This yields

Œ¶(x) =+(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´Amp(E(k‚Üí),k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚Üí =+(‚àí1) p(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´Amp(‚àíE(k‚Üí),k‚Üí)e +iE(k‚Üí)x 0+ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚Üí. \begin{aligned} \Phi(x) &= \phantom{+} (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int Amp(E(\vec k), \vec k) e^{- i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k \\ & \phantom{=} + (-1)^p (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int Amp(-E(\vec k), \vec k) e^{+ i E(\vec k) x^0 + i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k \end{aligned} \,.

Since Œ¶\Phi is real-valued, it follows that under complex conjugation (‚àí) *(-)^\ast the amplitudes are related by

Amp(E(k‚Üí),k‚Üí) *=(‚àí1) pAmp(‚àíE(k‚Üí),k‚Üí). Amp(E(\vec k), \vec k)^\ast = (-1)^p Amp(-E(\vec k), \vec k) \,.

We abbreviate (cf. Scharf 01 (1.1.18))

A(k‚Üí)‚âîE(k‚Üí)Amp(E(k‚Üí),k‚Üí), A(\vec k) \coloneqq E(\vec k) Amp(E(\vec k), \vec k) \,,

where the prefactor just serves to make some of the following formulas come out conveniently.

With this the general solution to the Klein-Gordon equation is finally of the form

(37)Œ¶(x)=(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´12E(k‚Üí)(A(k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí+A(k‚Üí) *e +iE(k‚Üí)x 0+ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí)d pk‚Üí. \Phi(x) = (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 E(\vec k)}} \left( A(\vec k) e^{- i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} + A(\vec k)^\ast e^{+ i E(\vec k) x^0 + i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \right) d^p \vec k \,.

and hence its time derivative is

‚àÇ 0Œ¶(x)=(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´‚àíiE(k)/2(A(k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí‚àíA(k‚Üí) *e +iE(k‚Üí)x 0+ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí)d pk‚Üí. \partial_0 \Phi(x) = (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int -i \sqrt{E(k)/2} \left( A(\vec k) e^{- i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} - A(\vec k)^\ast e^{+ i E(\vec k) x^0 + i \vec k \cdot \vec x} \right) d^p \vec k \,.

This allows to express the modes in terms of the value of the field and its time derivative at t=0t = 0:

A(k‚Üí)=(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´(E(k)/2Œ¶(0,x‚Üí)+i12E(k)‚àÇ 0Œ¶(0,x‚Üí))exp(ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí)d px‚Üí. A(\vec k) = (2 \pi)^{-p/2} \int \left( \sqrt{E(k)/2}\Phi(0,\vec x) + i \frac{1}{2\sqrt{E(k)}} \partial_0 \Phi(0,\vec x)\right) \exp( i \vec k \cdot \vec x ) d^p \vec x \,.

As in example 22 we denote the corresponding evaluation functional

a(k‚Üí):C ‚àû(Œ£)‚ü∂‚ÑÇ a(\vec k) \;\colon\; C^\infty(\Sigma) \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}

by the corresponding lower case symbol:

a(k‚Üí)‚âî(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´(E(k)/2œï(x‚Üí)+i12E(k)‚àÇ 0œï(x‚Üí))exp(ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üí)d px‚Üí. a(\vec k) \;\coloneqq\; (2 \pi)^{-p/2} \int \left( \sqrt{E(k)/2}\phi(\vec x) + i \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 E(k)}} \partial_0 \phi(\vec x)\right) \exp( i \vec k \cdot \vec x ) d^p \vec x \,.

With the Poisson bracket kernel {œï(x‚Üí),œï(y‚Üí)}=Œ¥(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí)\{\phi(\vec x), \phi(\vec y)\} = \delta(\vec x - \vec y) from example 22 (36), it follow that the (integral kernel for the) Poisson bracket of these mode functionals is that of the canonical commutation relations:

(38){a(k‚Üí 1),a(k‚Üí 2) *} =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Œ¥(x‚Üí 1‚àíx‚Üí 2)e i(k‚Üí 1‚ãÖx‚Üí 1‚àík‚Üí 2‚ãÖx‚Üí 2)dx‚Üí 1dx‚Üí 2 =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´e i(k‚Üí 1‚àík‚Üí 2)‚ãÖx‚Üídx‚Üí = =‚àíiŒ¥(k‚Üí 1‚àík‚Üí 2), \begin{aligned} \{ a(\vec k_1), a(\vec k_2)^\ast \} & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \delta(\vec x_1 - \vec x_2) e^{i ( \vec k_1 \cdot \vec x_1 - \vec k_2 \cdot \vec x_2) } d \vec x_1 d\vec x_2 \\ & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int e^{i (\vec k_1 - \vec k_2) \cdot \vec x } d \vec x & = \\ & = -i \delta(\vec k_1 - \vec k_2) \,, \end{aligned}

where in the last step we used the Fourier transform representation of the delta distribution (this prop.).

In order to finally compute {œï(x),œï(y)}\{\phi(x), \phi(y)\}, it is convenient to break this up into two contributions: Write

œï (+)(x)‚âî(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´12E(k‚Üí)a(k‚Üí) *e +iE(k‚Üí)x 0+ik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚ÜíAAAAœï (‚àí)(x)‚âî(2œÄ) ‚àíp/2‚à´12E(k‚Üí)a(k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)x 0‚àíik‚Üí‚ãÖx‚Üíd pk‚Üí \phi^{(+)}(x) \;\coloneqq\; (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 E(\vec k)}} a(\vec k)^\ast e^{+ i E(\vec k) x^0 + i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k \phantom{AAAA} \phi^{(-)}(x) \;\coloneqq\; (2\pi)^{-p/2} \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 E(\vec k)}} a(\vec k) e^{- i E(\vec k) x^0 - i \vec k \cdot \vec x} d^p \vec k

for the positive and negative energy contributions from the Fourier expansion in (37), so that

œï(x)=œï (‚àí)(x)+œï (+)(x). \phi(x) = \phi^{(-)}(x) + \phi^{(+)}(x) \,.

Using the canonical commutation relation of the mode functions (38), we find

(39)‚àíiœâ(x,y) ‚âî{œï (‚àí)(x),œï (+)(y)} =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´12E(k‚Üí)e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0‚àík‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí)d pk‚Üí =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Œ¥(k Œºk Œº+m 2)Œò(k 0)e ‚àíik Œº(x‚àíy) Œºd p+1k, \begin{aligned} -i \omega(x,y) & \coloneqq \{ \phi^{(-)}(x), \phi^{(+)}(y) \} \\ &= -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \tfrac{1}{2 E(\vec k)} e^{- i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 - \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} d^{p} \vec k \\ & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \delta( k_\mu k^\mu + m^2 ) \Theta( k_0 ) e^{ - i k_\mu (x-y)^\mu } d^{p+1} k \,, \end{aligned}

where in the last line we again applied change of integration variables. This œâ\omega is known as the 2-point function or Hadamard propagator on Minkowski spacetime. Similarly

{œï (+)(x),œï (‚àí)(y)} =+i(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´12E(k‚Üí)e iE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0+k‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí)d pk‚Üí =+i(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Œ¥(k Œºk Œº+m 2)Œò(‚àík 0)e ‚àíik Œº(x‚àíy) Œºd p+1k . \begin{aligned} \{ \phi^{(+)}(x), \phi^{(-)}(y) \} & = + i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \tfrac{1}{2 E(\vec k)} e^{i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 + \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} d^{p} \vec k \\ & = + i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \delta( k_\mu k^\mu + m^2 ) \Theta( -k_0 ) e^{ - i k_\mu (x-y)^\mu } d^{p+1} k \\ \end{aligned} \,.

In particular this says that

{œï (+)(x),œï (‚àí)(y)}=‚àíœâ(y,x)‚âî‚àí{œï (‚àí)(y),œï (+)(x)}. \{ \phi^{(+)}(x), \phi^{(-)}(y) \} = - \omega(y,x) \coloneqq - \{ \phi^{(-)}(y), \phi^{(+)}(x) \} \,.

With this we finally obtain the expression for the causal propagator as the skew-symmetrization of the 2-point function:

{œï(x),œï(y)} ={œï (‚àí)(x),œï (+)(y)}+{œï (+)(x),œï (‚àí)(y)} =œâ(x,y)‚àíœâ(y,x) =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´12E(k‚Üí)(e ‚àíiE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0‚àík‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí)‚àíe +iE(k‚Üí)(x‚àíy) 0+k‚Üí‚ãÖ(x‚Üí‚àíy‚Üí))d pk‚Üí =‚àíi(2œÄ) ‚àíp‚à´Œ¥(k Œºk Œº+m 2)sgn(k 0)e ‚àíik Œº(x‚àíy) Œºd p+1k. \begin{aligned} \{ \phi(x), \phi(y) \} & = \{ \phi^{(-)}(x), \phi^{(+)}(y) \} + \{\phi^{(+)}(x), \phi^{(-)}(y)\} \\ & = \omega(x,y) - \omega(y,x) \\ & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \tfrac{1}{2 E(\vec k)}\left( e^{- i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 - \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} - e^{+ i E(\vec k) (x-y)^0 + \vec k \cdot (\vec x - \vec y)} \right) d^p \vec k \\ & = -i (2\pi)^{-p} \int \delta( k_\mu k^\mu + m^2 ) sgn( k_0 ) e^{ - i k_\mu (x-y)^\mu } d^{p+1} k \,. \end{aligned}

So far we have discussed the covariant phase space (prop. 17) in terms of explicit restriction to the shell. We now turn to the more flexible perspective where a homological resolution of the shell in terms of ‚Äúantifields‚Äù is used (def. 20).

Example

(BV-presymplectic current)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) and whose Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is spacetime-independent (example 5). Let Œ£√ó{œÜ}‚Ü™‚Ñ∞\Sigma \times \{\varphi\} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{E} be a constant section of the shell (19).

Then in the BV-variational bicomplex (33) there exists the BV-presymplectic current

Œ© BV‚âîŒ¥œï¬Ø a‚àßŒ¥œï a‚àßdvol Œ£‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E,œÜ)| ‚Ñ∞ BV, \Omega_{BV} \coloneqq \delta \overline{\phi}_a \wedge \delta \phi^a \wedge dvol_{\Sigma} \;\;\; \in \Omega^{p,2}_\Sigma(E,\varphi)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}} \,,

where (œï a)(\phi^a) are the given field coordinates, œï¬Ø a\overline{\phi}_a the corresponding antifield coordinates (30) and Œ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a\frac{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} the corresponding components of the Euler-Lagrange form (prop. 4).

Proposition

(local BV-BFV relation)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) whose field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle (example 2) and whose Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is spacetime-independent (example 5). Let Œ£√ó{œÜ}‚Ü™‚Ñ∞\Sigma \times \{\varphi\} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{E} be a constant section of the shell (19).

Then the BV-presymplectic current Œ© BV\Omega_{BV} (def. 23) witnesses the on-shell vanishing (prop. 6) of the total spacetime derivative of the genuine presymplectic current Œ© BFV\Omega_{BFV} (prop. 4) in that the total spacetime derivative of Œ© BFV\Omega_{BFV} equals the BV-differential s BVs_{BV} of Œ© BV\Omega_{BV}:

dŒ© BFV=sŒ© BV. d \Omega_{BFV} = s \Omega_{BV} \,.

Hence if Œ£ tra‚Ü™Œ£\Sigma_{tra} \hookrightarrow \Sigma is a submanifold of spacetime of full dimension p+1p+1 with boundary ‚àÇŒ£ tra=Œ£ in‚äîŒ£ out\partial \Sigma_{tra} = \Sigma_{in} \sqcup \Sigma_{out}

Œ£ tra in‚Üó ‚Üñ out Œ£ in Œ£ out \array{ && \Sigma_{tra} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{in}}\nearrow && \nwarrow^{\mathrm{out}} \\ \Sigma_{in} && && \Sigma_{out} }

then the pullback of the two presymplectic forms (34) on the incoming and outgoing spaces of field histories, respectively, differ by the BV-differential of the transgression of the BV-presymplectic current:

((‚àí)| in) *(œâ in)‚àí((‚àí)| out) *(œâ out)=œÑ ùîª√óŒ£ tra(sŒ© BV)AAAA‚ààŒ© 2(Œì Œ£ tra(E) Œ¥ ELL=0). \left( (-)\vert_{in}\right)^\ast\left( \omega_{in}\right) \;-\; \left( (-)\vert_{out} \right)^\ast \left( \omega_{out} \right) = \tau_{\mathbb{D} \times \Sigma_{tra}} ( s \Omega_{BV} ) \phantom{AAAA} \in \Omega^2 \left( \Gamma_{\Sigma_{tra}}(E)_{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = 0} \right) \,.

This homological resolution of the Lagrangian correspondence that exhibits the ‚Äúcovariance‚Äù of the covariant phase space (prop. 17) is known as the BV-BFV relation (Cattaneo-Mnev-Reshetikhin 12 (9)).

Proof

For the first statement we compute as follows:

sŒ© BV =‚àíŒ¥(sœï¬Ø a)Œ¥œï awegedvol Œ£ =‚àíŒ¥Œ¥ ELLŒ¥œï aŒ¥œï advol Œ£ =‚àíŒ¥Œ¥ ELL =dŒ© BFV, \begin{aligned} s \Omega_{BV} & = - \delta (s \overline{\phi}_a) \delta \phi^a \wege dvol_{\Sigma} \\ & = - \delta \frac{\delta_{EL}L }{\delta \phi^a} \delta \phi^a dvol_{\Sigma} & = - \delta \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \\ & = d \Omega_{BFV} \,, \end{aligned}

where the first steps simply unwind the definitions, and where the last step is prop. 6.

With this the second statement follows by immediate generalization of the proof of prop. 17.

Example

(derived presymplectic current of real scalar field)

Consider a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) without any non-trivial implicial infinitesimal gauge transformations (def. 27); for instance the real scalar field (def. 10).

Inside its BV-complex (def. 20) we may form the linear combination of

  1. the presymplectic current Œ© BFV\Omega_{BFV} (example 12)

  2. the BF-presymplectic current Œ© BV\Omega_{BV} (example 23).

This yields a vertical 2-form

Œ©‚âîŒ© BV+Œ© BFV‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,2(E)| ‚Ñ∞ BV \Omega \;\coloneqq\; \Omega_{BV} + \Omega_{BFV} \;\; \in \Omega^{p,2}_\Sigma(E)\vert_{\mathcal{E}_{BV}}

which is closed under the BV-horizontal derivative d‚àísd - s:

(d‚àís)(Œ© BV+Œ© BFV) =dŒ© BFV‚àísŒ© BV‚èü=0+dŒ© BV‚àísŒ© BFV =0 \begin{aligned} (d - s) (\Omega_{BV} + \Omega_{BFV}) & = \underset{= 0}{\underbrace{d \Omega_{BFV} - s \Omega_{BV}}} + d \Omega_{BV} - s \Omega_{BFV} \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

Here the first term vanishes via the local BV-BFV relation (prop. 18) while the other two terms vanish simply by degree reasons.

\,

Gauge symmetries

The existence of the covariant phase space (prop. 17) of a Lagrangian field theory requires the existence of Cauchy surfaces (def. 22) for its Euler-Lagrange equations of motion. In general these may not exist. An obstruction to their existence turns out to be (prop. 19 below) the presence of infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian (def. 13) that have compact spacetime support (def. 15).

This obstruction is neatly captured by the cochain cohomology of a cochain complex which is induced by the equations of motion, called the local BV-complex (def. 20) of the Lagrangian theory. This may be understood as the algebra of functions on an extension of the jet bundle from a (locally pro-finite dimensional, prop. 29) smooth manifold to a differential graded manifold. This appearance of homotopy theory in the guise of homological algebra in Lagrangian field theory paves the way to understanding the cause of the obstruction: It disappears when the field bundle (or more generally its jet bundle) is promoted to its infinitesimal homotopy quotient by the action of these compactly supported symmetries (the ‚Äúaction Lie algebroid‚Äù, def. 31 below).

Passing to this homotopy quotient means to hard-wire into the geometry of the types of field their equivalence under these symmetries: in physics this is called gauge equivalence. The result is called the ‚Äúreduced phase space‚Äù, which we turn to further below.

Therefore the presence of infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian with compact spacetime support is a defect of the theory which however implies its own solution, by indicating which relations ought to be promoted to ‚Äúgauge‚Äù equivalences. Therefore we call these the implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries (remark 3 below).

An obvious candidate class of such implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations are infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian which appear linearly parameterized by arbitrary sections (and their derivatives) of some vector bundle on spacetime: Because then for every such section of compact support the corresponding symmetry will have compact spacetime support and hence be an implicit gauge symmetry. Therefore such sections are called gauge parameters (def. 28 below). In applications typically all implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations come from gauge parameters this way, notably so for the theory of electromagnetism (example 26) and more generally Yang-Mills theory.

\,

Definition

(implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetry)

Given a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E, \mathbf{L}) (def. 9), then an implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetry is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13) with compact spacetime support (def. 15).

There always exist ‚Äútrivial‚Äù implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations:

Example

(trivial implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

Then every evolutionary vector field (def. 11) of the special form

œµ‚âîŒ¥LŒ¥œï aŒ∫ [ab]‚àÇ œï a‚ààŒì E ev(V Œ£E) \epsilon \coloneqq \frac{\delta L }{\delta \phi^a} \kappa^{[a b]} \partial_{\phi^a} \;\in\; \Gamma_E^{ev}( V_\Sigma E )

for a collection of smooth functions with compact spacetimes support

(Œ∫ [ab]‚ààŒ© Œ£ 0,0(E))‚ààŒ© Œ£,cp 0,0(E) (\kappa^{[a b]} \in \Omega^{0,0}_\Sigma(E)) \;\;\;\; \in \Omega^{0,0}_{\Sigma,cp}(E)

which is skew-symmetric in its indices (Œ∫ [ab]=‚àíŒ∫ [ba]\kappa^{[a b]} = - \kappa^{[b a]}) is an implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetry (def. 27).

This is so for a ‚Äútrivial reason‚Äù namely just that skew symmetry:

Œπ œµŒ¥ ELL=(Œ¥LŒ¥œï a)(Œ¥LŒ¥œï b)Œ∫ [ab]‚èü=0dvol Œ£ \iota_\epsilon \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} = \underset{= 0}{ \underbrace{ \left( \frac{\delta L }{\delta \phi^a} \right) \left( \frac{\delta L }{\delta \phi^b} \right) \kappa^{[a b]} } } \, dvol_\Sigma

These are called the trivial infinitesimal gauge transformation.

Moreover, by prop. 4 the action of these implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries œµ\epsilon vanishes on-shell (def. 4) up to a total horizontal derivative and hence indeed act trivially on on-shell local observables.

Remark

(terminology)

The literature on the variational bicomplex knows a more refined concept of infinitesimal gauge transformations than the ‚Äúimplicit‚Äù infinitesimal gauge transformations of def. 27, namely in terms of differential operators taking values in infinitesimal symmetries of the Lagrangian. But for the purpose of constructing the covariant phase space of a gauge theory, def. 27 is what needs to be considered (prop. 19 below).

We do say ‚Äúimplicit‚Äù here to distinguish from their ‚Äúexplicit‚Äù incarnations acting on fields: the morphisms in the action Lie algebroid whose Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra is the BRST complex (example 30 below).

Since the point of quantization of gauge field theory via causal perturbation theory is that it does not apply as long as there are non-trivial implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries present (prop. 19 below), but only applies once all implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries have been made explicit (by the BV-BRST complex) the distinction is important.

Proposition

(non-trivial implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries obstruct existence of Cauchy surfaces)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory.

If there exists a single implicit infinitesimal gauge transformation œµ\epsilon (def. 27) that does not vanish on-shell (not a trivial one, example 25) then there does not exist any Cauchy surface (def. 22) for the Euler-Lagrange equations of motion (def. 17) outside of supp Œ£(v)supp_\Sigma(v).

Proof

By prop. 10 the flow along œµ^\hat \epsilon preserves the on-shell space of field histories.

But if œµ^\hat \epsilon is non-trivial, in that it does not vanish on-shell, then the flow along œµ\epsilon continuously changes solutions away from the would-be Cauchy surface. This means that there are infinitely many solutions to the equations of motion that restrict to the same solution on the would-be Cauchy surface, which contradicts the defining property of an actual Cauchy surface.

After these generalities on implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries we turn attention to a more structured special class of them. To that end, recall that an evolutionary vector field (def. 11) is a bundle homomorphism of the form

J Œ£ ‚àû(E) ‚ü∂v V Œ£E jb ‚àû,0‚Üò ‚Üô E \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma(E) && \overset{v}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & {}_{\mathllap{jb_{\infty,0}}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathllap{}} \\ && E }

and that this is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13) if Œπ vŒ¥ ELL\iota_v \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} is horizontally exact.

We now parameterize such morphisms by another bundle:

Definition

(irreducible closed gauge parameters)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

Then a collection of irreducible closed gauge parameters for (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) is

  1. a vector bundle ùí¢‚ü∂gbŒ£\mathcal{G} \overset{gb}{\longrightarrow} \Sigma over spacetime Œ£\Sigma; the sections œµ\epsilon of which are to be called the gauge parameters;

  2. a bundle morphism RR from the jet bundle of the fiber product ùí¢√ó Œ£E\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E with the field bundle (def. 5) to the vertical tangent bundle of EE:

    J Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢√ó Œ£E) ‚ü∂R V Œ£E ‚Ü™i V Œ£(ùí¢√ó Œ£E) ‚Üò ‚Üô E \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E ) && \overset{R}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E & \overset{i}{\hookrightarrow} & V_\Sigma (\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E) \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && E }

such that

  1. RR is linear in the first argument;

  2. i‚àòRi \circ R is an evolutionary vector field on ùí¢√ó Œ£E\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E (def. 11);

  3. R(e,‚àí)R(e,-) is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian (def. 13) for every point in e‚ààJ Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢)e \in J^\infty_\Sigma(\mathcal{G}) (i.e. for every jet of a gauge parameter);

  4. ùí¢\mathcal{G} is closed under the Lie bracket of evolutionary vector fields (prop. 8) in that for e 1,e 2e_1, e_2 two points in the same fiber of J Œ£ ‚àû(E)J^\infty_\Sigma(E) then there exists a unique [e 1,e 2]‚ààJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)[e_1,e_2] \in J^\infty_\Sigma(E) in that fiber such that

    [R^(e 1,‚àí),R^(e 1,‚àí)]=R^([e 1,e 2],‚àí). \left[\widehat R(e_1,-), \widehat R(e_1,-)\right] = \widehat R([e_1, e_2],-) \,.

    We call this the corresponding irreducible closed gauge Lie algebra of the Lagrangian theory (if it exists).

In components this means that, if the field bundle EE is a trivial vector bundle with field fiber coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a) (example 2) and also ùí¢\mathcal{G} happens to be a trivial vector bundle

ùí¢=Œ£√óùî§ \mathcal{G} = \Sigma \times \mathfrak{g}

so that RR is a bundle morphism of the form

R:J Œ£ ‚àû(ùî§√óE)‚ü∂V Œ£E R \;\colon\; J^\infty_\Sigma(\mathfrak{g} \times E ) \longrightarrow V_\Sigma E

then for œµ‚ààŒì Œ£(ùí¢)=C ‚àû(Œ£,‚Ñä)\epsilon \in \Gamma_{\Sigma}(\mathcal{G}) = C^\infty(\Sigma,\mathcal{g}) a gauge parameter, v œµv_\epsilon is of the form

(40)v œµ=(œµ Œ±R Œ± a+dœµ Œ±dx ŒºR Œ± aŒº+d 2œµ Œ±dx Œº 1dx Œº 2R Œ± aŒº 1Œº 2+‚ãØ)‚àÇ œï a, v_\epsilon \;=\; \left( \epsilon^\alpha R^a_\alpha + \frac{d \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^\mu} R^{a \mu}_\alpha + \frac{d^2 \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^{\mu_1} d x^{\mu_2}} R^{a \mu_1 \mu_2}_\alpha + \cdots \right) \partial_{\phi^a} \,,

where the R Œ± aŒº 1‚ãØŒº kR^{a \mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}_\alpha are smooth functions on the jet bundle of EE, locally of finite order (prop. 2).

Proposition

(Noether identities)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9).

A gauge parameterized evolutionary vector field (40)

v œµ=(œµ Œ±R Œ± a+dœµ Œ±dx ŒºR Œ± aŒº+d 2œµ Œ±dx Œº 1dx Œº 2R Œ± aŒº 1Œº 2+‚ãØ)‚àÇ œï a v_\epsilon \;=\; \left( \epsilon^\alpha R^a_\alpha + \frac{d \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^\mu} R^{a \mu}_\alpha + \frac{d^2 \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^{\mu_1} d x^{\mu_2}} R^{a \mu_1 \mu_2}_\alpha + \cdots \right) \partial_{\phi^a}

is a gauge parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge transformation (def. 28) precisely if the Euler-Lagrange form Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} (prop. 4) satisfies the following relation:

(R Œ± aŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a‚àíR Œ± aŒºddx ŒºŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a+R Œ± aŒº 1Œº 2d 2dx Œº 1dx Œº 2Œ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a‚àí‚ãØ)=0. \left( R^{a}_\alpha \frac{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} - R^{a \mu}_\alpha \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} + R^{a \mu_1 \mu_2}_\alpha \frac{d^2}{d x^{\mu_1} d x^{\mu_2}} \frac{\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} - \cdots \right) \;=\; 0 \,.

These are called Noether identities of the Euler-Lagrange equations of motion (def 17).

Proof

We need to show that v œµv_\epsilon is a gauge symmetry as claimed precisely if

Œπ v œµŒ¥ ELL=d(‚ãØ) \iota_{v_\epsilon} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = d(\cdots)

vanishes for all choices of œµ\epsilon up to a horizontally exact term. From (40) this means that

Œπ v œµŒ¥ ELL =‚àëk‚àà‚Ñïd kœµ Œ±dx Œº 1‚ãÖdx Œº kR Œ± aŒº 1‚ãØŒº kŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a =œµ Œ±‚àëk‚àà‚Ñï(‚àí1) kR Œ± aŒº 1‚ãØŒº kd kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº kŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a+dJ v œµ \begin{aligned} \iota_{v_\epsilon} \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} & = \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} \frac{d^k \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdot d x^{\mu_k}} R^{a \mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}_\alpha \frac{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} \\ & = \epsilon^\alpha \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} (-1)^k R^{a \mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}_\alpha \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \frac{\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}}{\delta \phi^a} + d J_{v_\epsilon} \end{aligned}
Example

(implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetry of electromagnetism)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime Œ£\Sigma from example 11.

Let ùí¢‚âîŒ£√ó‚Ñù\mathcal{G} \coloneqq \Sigma \times \mathbb{R} be the trivial line bundle, regarded as a gauge parameter bundle (def. 28). Then the gauge parametrized evolutionary vector field (40) given on a gauge parameter

œµ‚ààŒì Œ£(ùí¢)=C ‚àû(Œ£) \epsilon \in \Gamma_\Sigma(\mathcal{G}) = C^\infty(\Sigma)

by

(41)v œµ‚âîdœµdx Œº‚àÇ a Œº v_\epsilon \coloneqq \frac{d \epsilon}{d x^\mu} \partial_{a_\mu}

is a gauge paramterized implicit infinitesimal gauge transformation according to def. 28.

This is because the Euler-Lagrange form

Œ¥ ELL=ddx Œºf ŒºŒΩŒ¥ a ŒΩdvol Œ£ \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} \;=\; \frac{d}{d x^\mu }f^{\mu \nu} \delta_{a_\nu} dvol_\Sigma

of the theory (example 13), corresponding to the vacuum Maxwell equations (example 15), satisfies the following evident Noether identity (prop. 20):

ddx Œºddx ŒΩf ŒºŒΩ=0. \frac{d}{d x^\mu} \frac{d}{d x^\nu} f^{\mu \nu} = 0 \,.

This is simply because f ŒºŒΩ=‚àíf ŒΩŒºf^{\mu \nu} = -f^{\nu \mu} is skew-symmetric by definition (5), while partial derivatives commute with each other.

This is the archetypical infinitesimal gauge symmetry that gives gauge theory its name.

The prolongation (prop. 7) of the vector field v œµv_\epsilon (41) is

(42)v^ œµ=dœµdx Œº‚àÇ a Œº+d 2œµdx Œºdx ŒΩ‚àÇ a Œº,ŒΩ+d 3œµdx Œºdx ŒΩ 1dx ŒΩ 2‚àÇ a Œº,ŒΩ 1ŒΩ 2+‚ãØ \hat v_\epsilon \;=\; \frac{d \epsilon}{d x^\mu} \partial_{a_\mu} + \frac{d^2 \epsilon}{d x^\mu d x^\nu} \partial_{a_{\mu,\nu}} + \frac{d^3 \epsilon}{d x^\mu d x^{\nu_1} d x^{\nu_2}} \partial_{a_{\mu, \nu_1 \nu_2}} + \cdots

This shows that the Lagrangian density of free electromagnetism is in fact strictly gauge invariant (not just up to a horizontally exact piece)

‚Ñí v^ œµL EM=0 \mathcal{L}_{\hat v_\epsilon} \mathbf{L}_{EM} = 0

as is its Euler-Lagrange form

‚Ñí v^ œµŒ¥ ELL=0. \mathcal{L}_{\hat v_{\epsilon}} \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} = 0 \,.

Making the implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries explicit means to make explicit how they act on the fields. To this end consider the general concept of an action of a Lie algebra by infinitesimal diffeomorphisms:

Definition

(action of Lie algebra by infinitesimal diffeomorphism)

Let XX be a smooth manifold or more generally a locally pro-manifold (prop. 2), and let ùî§\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra.

An action of ùî§\mathfrak{g} on XX by infinitesimal diffeomorphisms, is a homomorphism of Lie algebras

œÅ:ùî§‚ü∂(Vect(X),[‚àí,‚àí]) \rho \;\colon \mathfrak{g} \longrightarrow ( Vect(X), [-,-] )

to the smooth vector fields on XX.

Equivalently ‚Äì to bring out the relation to the gauge parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations in def. 28 ‚Äì this is a ùî§\mathfrak{g}-parameterized section

ùî§√óX ‚ü∂œÅ TX pr 2‚Üò ‚Üô p X \array{ \mathfrak{g} \times X && \overset{\rho}{\longrightarrow} && T X \\ & {\mathllap{pr_2}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{p}} \\ && X }

of the tangent bundle, such that for all pairs of points e 1,e 2e_1, e_2 in ùî§\mathfrak{g} we have

[œÅ(e 1,‚àí),œÅ(e 2,‚àí)]=œÅ([e 1,e 2],‚àí) \left[\rho(e_1,-), \rho(e_2,-)\right] = \rho([e_1,e_2],-)

(with the Lie bracket of vector fields on the left).

Example

(action of irreducible closed gauge parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries on fields)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9), and let ùí¢=‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} = \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma be a bundle of irreducible closed gauge parameters for the theory (def. 28) with bundle morphism

J Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢√ó Œ£E) ‚ü∂R V Œ£E ‚Üò ‚Üô E \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E ) && \overset{R}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && E }

exhibiting the corresponding parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries.

By passing from these evolutionary vector fields R(e)R(e) (def. 11) to their prolongations R(e)^\widehat{R(e)} to actual vector fields on the jet bundle (prop. 7) we obtain a bundle morphism of the form

J Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢)√ó Œ£J Œ£ ‚àûE ‚ü∂R(e)^ V Œ£J Œ£ ‚àû(E) ‚Üò ‚Üô J Œ£ ‚àû(E). \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma(\mathcal{G}) \times_\Sigma J^\infty_\Sigma E && \overset{\widehat{R(e)}}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && J^\infty_\Sigma(E) } \,.

In the case that ùí¢=ùî§√óŒ£\mathcal{G} = \mathfrak{g} \times \Sigma is a trivial vector bundle, with fiber ùî§\mathfrak{g}, then so is its jet bundle J Œ£ ‚àû(ùî§√óŒ£)=ùî§ ‚àû√óŒ£J^\infty_\Sigma(\mathfrak{g} \times \Sigma) = \mathfrak{g}^\infty \times \Sigma, and so in this case the above becomes of the form

ùî§ ‚àû√óJ Œ£ ‚àûE ‚ü∂R(e)^ V Œ£J Œ£ ‚àû(E) ‚Üò ‚Üô J Œ£ ‚àû(E). \array{ \mathfrak{g}^\infty \times J^\infty_\Sigma E && \overset{\widehat{R(e)}}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && J^\infty_\Sigma(E) } \,.

By def. 28 and def. 29 this now exhibits an action

œÅ^:ùî§ ‚àû‚ü∂Œì J Œ£ ‚àû(E)(T(J Œ£ ‚àû(E))) \widehat{\rho} \;\colon\; \mathfrak{g}^\infty \longrightarrow \Gamma_{J^\infty_\Sigma(E)}\left( T(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)) \right)

of a Lie algebra ùî§ ‚àû\mathfrak{g}^\infty on the jet bundle of the field bundle by infinitesimal diffeomorphisms.

We have seen that the presence of non-trivial implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations (def. 27) in a Lagrangian field theory obstructs the existence of the covariant phase space of the theory (prop. 19). But these implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries become explicit by hard-wiring into the very geometry of the types of fields their equivalence under these symmetries: In physics this is called gauge equivalence.

Mathematically this means to pass to the infinitesimal homotopy quotient of the action of the gauge symmetries on the shell, represented by the action Lie algebroid (def. 31 below). This is called the local reduced phase space of the theory. Such ‚Äúhigher structures‚Äù exist in the unification of differential geometry with homotopy theory called higher differential geometry. The (‚ÄúChevalley-Eilenberg‚Äù-)algebra of functions on this ‚Äúfield bundle with infinitesimal gauge symmetries made explicit‚Äù is called the BRST complex. In this cochain complex the formerly implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries appear explicitly in the guise of field variables of positive (i.e. ‚Äúhigher‚Äù) degree in a differential graded-commutative algebra. These are called ghost fields.

\,

Definition

(Lie algebroid)

Let XX be an infinitesimally thickened point and write C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) for its algebra of functions. Then a connected Lie ‚àû-algebroid ùîû\mathfrak{a} over XX of finite type is a

  1. a sequence (ùîû k) k=1 ‚àû(\mathfrak{a}_k)_{ k = 1 }^\infty of free modules of finite rank over C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X), hence a graded module ùîû ‚Ä¢\mathfrak{a}_\bullet in degrees k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N}; k‚â•1k \geq 1

  2. a differential d CEd_{CE} that makes the graded-commutative algebra Sym C ‚àû(X)(ùîû ‚Ä¢ *)Sym_{C^\infty(X)}(\mathfrak{a}^\ast_\bullet) into a cochain differential graded-commutative algebra (hence with d CEd_{CE} of degree +1) over ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} (not necessarily over C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X)), to be called the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of ùîû\mathfrak{a}:

    (43)CE(ùîû)‚âî(Sym C ‚àû(X)(ùîû ‚Ä¢ *),d CE). CE(\mathfrak{a}) \;\coloneqq\; \left( Sym_{C^\infty(X)}(\mathfrak{a}^\ast_\bullet) \,,\, d_{CE} \right) \,.

If we allow ùîû ‚Ä¢\mathfrak{a}_\bullet to also have terms in non-positive degree, then we speak of a derived Lie algebroid. If ùîû ‚Ä¢\mathfrak{a}_\bullet is only concentrated in negative degrees, we also speak of a derived manifold.

With C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) canonically itself regarded as a dgc-algebra, there is a canonical dg-algebra homomorphism

CE(ùîû)‚ü∂C ‚àû(X) CE(\mathfrak{a}) \longrightarrow C^\infty(X)

which is the identity on C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) and zero on ùîû ‚â†0 *\mathfrak{a}^\ast_{\neq 0}.

Remark

(Lie algebroids as differential graded manifolds)

Definition 30 of derived Lie algebroids is an encoding in higher algebra (homological algebra, in this case) of a situation that is usefully thought of in terms of higher differential geometry.

To see this, recall the magic algebraic properties of ordinary differential geometry (prop. 1)

  1. embedding of smooth manifolds into formal duals of R-algebras;

  2. embedding of smooth vector bundles into formal duals of modules

Together these imply that we may think of the graded algebra underlying a Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra as being the algebra of functions on a graded manifold

‚ãØ√óùîû 2√óùîû 1√óX√óùîû ‚àí1√ó‚ãØ \cdots \times \mathfrak{a}_2 \times \mathfrak{a}_1 \times X \times \mathfrak{a}_{-1} \times \cdots

which is infinitesimal in non-vanishing degree.

The ‚Äúhigher‚Äù in higher differential geometry refers to the degrees higher than zero. See at Higher Structures for exposition. Specifically if ùîû ‚Ä¢\mathfrak{a}_\bullet has components in negative degrees, these are also called derived manifolds.

Example

(basic examples of Lie algebroids)

Two basic examples of Lie algebroids are:

  1. For XX any smooth manifold, then setting ùîû ‚â†0‚âî0\mathfrak{a}_{\neq 0 } \coloneqq 0 and d CE‚âî0d_{CE} \coloneqq 0 makes it a Lie algebroid. We will just still just write XX for the manifold trivially regarded as a Lie alebroid this way.

  2. For ùî§\mathfrak{g} a finite dimensional Lie algebra we obtain a Lie algebroid denoted */ùî§\ast/\mathfrak{g} or Bùî§B \mathfrak{g} by taking the base manifold to be the point, taking ùîû\mathfrak{a} to be concentrated in degree 1 on ùî§\mathfrak{g}, and taking the differential to be given by the linear dual of the Lie bracket

    d CE:ùî§ *‚ü∂[‚àí,‚àí] *ùî§ *‚àßùî§ *. d_{CE} \;\colon\; \mathfrak{g}^\ast \overset{[-,-]^\ast}{\longrightarrow} \mathfrak{g}^\ast \wedge \mathfrak{g}^\ast \,.

    If (t Œ±)(t_\alpha) is a linear basis for ùî§\mathfrak{g} and (t Œ±)(t^\alpha) a corresponding dual basis for ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^\ast, then this is given by

    d CEt Œ±‚àí12C Œ≤Œ≥ Œ±t Œ≤‚àßt Œ≥, d_{CE} t^\alpha -\tfrac{1}{2} C^\alpha_{\beta \gamma} t^\beta \wedge t^\gamma \,,

    where on the right we have the structure constants of the Lie bracket in this basis:

    [t Œ≤,t Œ≥]=t Œ±C Œ± Œ≤Œ≥. [t^\beta, t^\gamma] = t_\alpha C^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} \,.

    The resulting dgc-algebra

    (‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *,d CE=[‚àí,‚àí] *) \left( \wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^\ast, d_{CE} = [-,-]^\ast \right)

    is the standard Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra from basic Lie theory, whence the name of the general concept.

The two basic examples 28 are unified by the concept of action Lie algebroid (def. 31 below), which is the one of central relevance for the discussion of gauge theory: the local BRST complex (def. 30 below).

Definition

(action Lie algebroid)

Given an infinitesimal action of a Lie algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g} on a manifold XX (def. 29) the action Lie algebroid X/ùî§X/\mathfrak{g} is the Lie algebroid (def. 30) whose underlying space is XX; whose C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X)-module is concentrated in degree 1 on the free module C ‚àû(X)‚äó ‚Ñùùî§C^\infty(X) \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} \mathfrak{g} and whose CE-differential is given

  • on functions f‚ààC ‚àû(X)f \in C^\infty(X) by the Lie algebra action

    d CEf‚âîœÅ(‚àí)(f)‚ààC ‚àû(X)‚äóùî§ * d_{CE} f \coloneqq \rho(-)(f) \in C^\infty(X) \otimes \mathfrak{g}^\ast

  • on dual Lie algebra elements œâ‚ààùî§ *\omega \in \mathfrak{g}^\ast by the linear dual of the Lie bracket

    d CEœâ‚âîœâ([‚àí,‚àí])‚ààùî§ *‚àßùî§ *. d_{CE} \omega \coloneqq \omega([-,-]) \;\in \; \mathfrak{g}^\ast \wedge \mathfrak{g}^\ast \,.

In terms of coordinates this means the following. Assume that X=‚Ñù nX = \mathbb{R}^n is a Cartesian space with coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a) and let {t Œ±}\{t_\alpha\} be a linear basis for ùî§\mathfrak{g} with dual basis (c Œ±)(c^\alpha) for ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^\ast. Then the Lie action has components

d CEœï a=œÅ Œ± ac Œ± d_{CE} \phi^a = \rho^{a}_{\alpha} c^\alpha
d CEc Œ±=‚àí12Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥c Œ≤‚àßc Œ≥ d_{CE} c^\alpha = -\tfrac{1}{2} \gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} c^\beta \wedge c^\gamma

where on the right we have the structure constants of the Lie algebra in this basis:

[t Œ≤,t Œ≥]=Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥t Œ±. [t_\beta, t_\gamma] = \gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} t_\alpha \,.

That the differential d CEd_{CE} thus defined indeed squares to 0 is

  • in degree 0 the action property: œÅ([t,t‚Ä≤])=[œÅ(t),œÅ(t‚Ä≤)]\rho([t, t']) = [\rho(t), \rho(t')]

  • in degree 1 the Jacobi identity.

Example

(horizontal tangent Lie algebroid)

Let Œ£\Sigma be a smooth manifold or more generally a locally pro-manifold (prop. 2). Then we write Œ£/TŒ£\Sigma/T\Sigma for the Lie algebroid over XX and whose Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra is generated over C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) in degree 1 from the module

ùîû 1 *‚âî(Œì(TŒ£)) *‚âÉŒì(T *Œ£)=Œ© 1(Œ£) \mathfrak{a}_1^\ast \coloneqq (\Gamma(T \Sigma))^\ast \simeq\Gamma(T^\ast \Sigma) = \Omega^1(\Sigma)

of differential 1-forms and whose Chevalley-Eilenberg differential is the de Rham differential, so that the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra is the de Rham dg-algebra

CE(Œ£/TŒ£)‚âî(Œ© ‚Ä¢(Œ£),d dR). CE( \Sigma/T\Sigma ) \coloneqq (\Omega^\bullet(\Sigma), d_{dR}) \,.

This is called the tangent Lie algebroid of Œ£\Sigma. As a graded manifold (via remark 4) this is called the ‚Äúshifted tangent bundle‚Äù T[1]Œ£T[1] \Sigma of XX.

More generally, let E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma be a fiber bundle over Œ£\Sigma. Then there is a Lie algebroid J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma over the jet bundle of EE (def. 5) defined by its Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra being the horizontal part of the variational bicomplex (def. 8):

CE(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£)‚âî(Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢,0(E),d). CE\left( J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma \right) \;\coloneqq\; \left(\Omega^{\bullet,0}_\Sigma(E), d\right) \,.

The underlying graded manifold of J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma is the fiber product J Œ£ ‚àû(E)√ó Œ£T[1]Œ£J^\infty_\Sigma(E)\times_\Sigma T[1]\Sigma of the jet bundle of EE with the shifted tangent bundle of Œ£\Sigma.

There is then a canonical homomorphism of Lie algebroids (def. 32)

J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£ ‚Üì Œ£/TŒ£ \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma \\ \downarrow \\ \Sigma/T\Sigma }
Example

(local BRST complex and ghost fields for irreducible closed gauge parameters)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9), and let ùí¢=‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} = \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma be a bundle of irreducible closed gauge parameters for the theory (def. 28) with bundle morphism

J Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢√ó Œ£E) ‚ü∂R V Œ£E ‚Üò ‚Üô E. \array{ J^\infty_\Sigma( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma E ) && \overset{R}{\longrightarrow} && V_\Sigma E \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && E } \,.

Assuming that the gauge parameter bundle is trivial, ùí¢=ùî§√óŒ£\mathcal{G} = \mathfrak{g} \times \Sigma, then by example 27 this induces an action R^\hat R of a Lie algebra ùî§ ‚àû\mathfrak{g}^\infty on J Œ£ ‚àûEJ^\infty_\Sigma E by infinitesimal diffeomorphisms.

The corresponding action Lie algebroid J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/ùî§ ‚àûJ^\infty_\Sigma(E)/\mathfrak{g}^\infty (def. 31) has as underlying graded manifold (remark 4)

ùî§ ‚àû[1]√óJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)‚âÉJ Œ£ ‚àû(ùí¢[1]√ó Œ£E) \mathfrak{g}^\infty[1] \times J^\infty_\Sigma(E) \;\simeq\; J^\infty_\Sigma( \mathcal{G}[1] \times_\Sigma E )

the jet bundle of the graded field bundle

E BRST‚âîùí¢[1]√óE E_{BRST} \coloneqq \mathcal{G}[1] \times E

which regards the gauge parameters as fields in degree 1. As such these are called ghost fields:

{ghost field histories}‚âîŒì Œ£(ùí¢[1]). \left\{ \text{ghost field histories} \right\} \;\coloneqq\; \Gamma_\Sigma( \mathcal{G}[1] ) \,.

Therefore we write suggestively

E/ùí¢‚âîJ Œ£ ‚àû(E)/ùî§ ‚àû E/\mathcal{G} \;\coloneqq\; J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/\mathfrak{g}^\infty

for the action Lie algebroid of the gauge parameterized implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries on the jet bundle of the field bundle.

The Chevalley-Eilenberg differential of the BRST complex is traditionally denoted

s BRST‚âîd CE. s_{BRST} \coloneqq d_{CE} \,.

To express this in coordinates, assume that the field bundle EE as well as the gauge parameter bundle are trivial vector bundles (example 2) with (œï a)(\phi^a) the field coordinates on the fiber of EE with induced jet coordinates ((x Œº),(œï a),(œï Œº a),‚ãØ)((x^\mu), (\phi^a), (\phi^a_{\mu}), \cdots) and (c Œ±)(c^\alpha) are ghost field coordinates on the fiber of ùí¢[1]\mathcal{G}[1] with induced jet coordinates ((x Œº),(c Œ±),(c Œº Œ±),‚ãØ)((x^\mu), (c^\alpha), (c^\alpha_\mu), \cdots).

Then in terms of the corresponding coordinate expression for the gauge symmetries RR (40) the BRST differential is given on the fields by

s BRSTœï a=‚àëk‚àà‚ÑïR Œ± aŒº 1‚ãØŒº kc Œº 1‚ãØŒº k Œ± s_{BRST} \, \phi^a \;=\; \underset{k \in \mathbb{N}}{\sum} R^{a \mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}_{\alpha} c^\alpha_{\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}

and on the ghost fields by

s BRSTc Œ±=12Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥c Œ≤c Œ≥, s_{BRST} \, c^\alpha = \tfrac{1}{2}\gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} c^\beta c^\gamma \,,

and it extends from there, via prop. 7, to jets of fields and ghost fields by (anti-)commutativity with the total spacetime derivative.

Moreover, since the action of the infinitesimal gauge symmetries is by definition via prolongations (prop. 7) of evolutionary vector fields (def. 11) and hence compatible with the total spacetime derivative (20) this construction descends to the horizontal tangent Lie algebroid J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma (example 29) to yield

E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)‚âî(J Œ£ ‚àû(E)/TŒ£)/ùî§ ‚àû E/(\mathcal{G}\times_\Sigma T \Sigma) \;\coloneqq\; \left(J^\infty_\Sigma(E)/T\Sigma\right)/\mathfrak{g}^\infty

The Chevalley-Eilenberg differential on E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)E/(\mathcal{G}\times_\Sigma T \Sigma) is

d‚àís BRST d - s_{BRST}

The Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of functions on this differential graded manifold (43) is called the off-shell local BRST complex (Barnich-Brandt-Henneaux 94).

We may pass from the local BRST complex on the jet bundle to the ‚Äúglobal‚Äù BRST complex by transgression of variational differential forms (def. 16):

Write Obs Œ£(E√óŒ£ùí¢[1])Obs_\Sigma(E \times\Sigma \mathcal{G}[1]) for the induced graded algebra of observables (def. 18). For A‚ààŒ© Œ£ p+1,‚Ä¢(E√ó Œ£ùí¢[1])A \in \Omega^{p+1,\bullet}_\Sigma(E \times_\Sigma \mathcal{G}[1]) with corresponding local observable œÑ Œ£(A)‚ààLocObs Œ£(E√ó Œ£ùí¢[1])\tau_\Sigma(A) \in LocObs_\Sigma(E \times_\Sigma \mathcal{G}[1]) its BRST differential is defined by

s BRSTœÑ Œ£(A)‚âîœÑ Œ£(s BRSTA) s_{BRST} \tau_{\Sigma}(A) \;\coloneqq\; \tau_{\Sigma}(s_{BRST} A)

and extended from there to Obs Œ£(E√ó Œ£ùí¢[1])Obs_\Sigma(E \times_\Sigma \mathcal{G}[1]) as a graded derivation.

Example

(local BRST complex for free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime (example 11) with its gauge parameter bundle as in example 26.

By (42) the action of the BRST differential is the derivation

s BRST=c ,Œº‚àÇ‚àÇa Œº+c ,ŒºŒΩ‚àÇ‚àÇa Œº,ŒΩ+‚ãØ. s_{BRST} \;=\; c_{,\mu} \frac{\partial}{\partial a_\mu} + c_{, \mu \nu} \frac{\partial}{\partial a_{\mu, \nu}} + \cdots \,.

In particular the Lagrangian density is BRST-closed

s BRSTL =s BRSTf ŒºŒΩf ŒºŒΩdvol Œ£ =c ,ŒºŒΩf ŒºŒΩdvol Œ£ =0 \begin{aligned} s_{BRST} \mathbf{L} & = s_{BRST} f_{\mu \nu} f^{\mu \nu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = c_{,\mu \nu} f^{\mu \nu} dvol_\Sigma \\ & = 0 \end{aligned}

as is the Euler-Lagrange form (due to the symmetry c ,ŒºŒΩ=c ,ŒΩŒºc_{,\mu \nu} = c_{,\nu \mu} and in contrast to the skew-symmetry f ŒºŒΩ=‚àíf ŒΩŒºf_{\mu \nu} = - f_{\nu \mu}).

\,

Reduced phase space

We have seen above that the covariant phase space of a Lagrangian field theory is, if it exists, the ‚Äúcovariant transgression‚Äù of the shell (prop. 4) equipped with the local Poisson bracket (example 15). The local observables (def. 18) which operationally define the classical field theory (or rather prequantum field theory) are functions on the covariant phase space, and the local Poisson bracket on them operationally defines the corresponding quantum field theory (below). Therefore the existence of the covariant phase space is crucial for the construction of the field theory.

However, we have then seen in prop. 19 that there may be an obstruction to the existence of the covariant phase space, namely the presence of infinitesimal gauge symmetries of the Lagrangian which have been ‚Äúleft implicit‚Äù. We have then discussed how to make these infinitesimal gauge symmetries ‚Äúexplicit‚Äù by hard-wiring their action into the geometry of the fields by passing to the corresponding infinitesimal homotopy quotient (def. 30) of (the jet bundle of) the field bundle, given by the corresponding action Lie algebroid (def. 31). Its Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of functions is called the local BRST complex of the theory (example 30).

The corresponding covariant phase space with infinitesimal gauge symmetries made explicit is now correspondingly given by the shell (11) not inside the plain space of fields, but inside this homotopy quotient by the infinitesimal gauge symmetries. This homotopy quotient of the naive phase space by the infinitesimal gauge symmetries is called the reduced phase space. Refined to its local incarnation in the jet bundle we may call this the ‚Äúderived reduced prolonged shell‚Äù (def. 36 below). Its algebra of functions is called the local BV-BRST complex of the theory.

In the next section below we find that, at least in good situations, if all non-trivial implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries have been made explicit this way by hard-wiring their action into the geometry of the reduced phase space, then the obstruction to the existence of the covariant phase space vanishes. Hence in this case then the (perturbative) quantum field theory can exist (discussed further below). This is why we do need to pass to the reduced phase space.

In order to exhibit the key structure of the reduced phase space without getting distracted by the local jet bundle geometry, we first discuss now the simple form in which it would appear after transgression (def. 16) if spacetime were compact, so that, by the principle of extremal action (prop. 16), it would be the derived critical locus (dS=0d S = 0) of a globally defined action functional SS. This is example 33 below.

This serves as a warmup to the true construction of the derived shell in the action Lie algebroid of the jet bundle, where the action functional is ‚Äúde-transgressed‚Äù to the Lagrangian density, which is invariant under gauge transformations only up to horizontally exact terms. This culminates in example 24 below.

\,

The key to understanding the ‚Äúderived reduced prolonged shell‚Äù, and hence the reduced phase space, as a derived critical locus is first to exhibit the Euler-Lagrange variation of the action functional, or rather of the Lagrangian density, as a section of the analog of a cotangent bundle, but now in the realm of Lie ‚àû-algebroids (prop. 22 and prop. 23 below). To this end we need to first of all consider homomorphisms of Lie algebroids:

Definition

(homomorphism between Lie algebroids)

Given two derived Lie algebroids ùîû\mathfrak{a}, ùîû‚Ä≤\mathfrak{a}' (def. 30), then a homomorphism between them

f:ùîû‚ü∂ùîû‚Ä≤ f \;\colon\; \mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow \mathfrak{a}'

is a dg-algebra-homomorphism between their Chevalley-Eilenberg algebras going the other way around

CE(ùîû)‚üµCE(ùîû‚Ä≤):f * CE(\mathfrak{a}) \longleftarrow CE(\mathfrak{a}') \;\colon\; f^\ast

such that this covers an algebra homomorphism on the function algebras (a ‚Äúnon-curved sh-map‚Äù)

CE(ùîû) ‚üµf * CE(ùîû‚Ä≤) ‚Üì ‚Üì C ‚àû(X) ‚üµ(f| X) * C ‚àû(Y). \array{ CE(\mathfrak{a}) &\overset{f^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& CE(\mathfrak{a}') \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ C^\infty(X) &\underset{(f\vert_X)^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty(Y) } \,.
Example

(gauge invariant functions in terms of Lie algebroids)

Let X/ùî§X/\mathfrak{g} be an action Lie algebroid (example 31) and regard the real line ‚Ñù 1\mathbb{R}^1 as a Lie algebroid by example 28. Then homomorphisms of Lie algebroids (def. 32) of the form

f:X/ùî§‚ü∂‚Ñù 1, f \;\colon\; X/\mathfrak{g} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^1 \,,

hence smooth functions on the Lie algebroid, are equivalently

  • ordinary smooth functions f:X‚ü∂‚Ñù 1f \colon X \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^1 on the underlying smooth manifold,

  • which are invariant under the Lie action in that œÅ(‚àí)(f)=0\rho(-)(f) = 0.

Proof

An ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-algebra homomorphism

CE(X/ùî§)‚üµC ‚àû(‚Ñù 1) CE( X/\mathfrak{g} ) \longleftarrow C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^1)

is fixed by what it does to the canonical coordinate function on ‚Ñù 1\mathbb{R}^1, which is taken by f *f^\ast to f‚ààC ‚àû(X)‚Ü™CE(X/ùî§)f \in C^\infty(X) \hookrightarrow CE(X/\mathfrak{g}). For this to be a dg-algebra homomorphism it needs to respect the differentials on both sides. Since the differential on right right is trivial, the condition is that 0=d CEf=œÅ(‚àí)(f)0 = d_{CE} f = \rho(-)(f).

Given a gauge invariant function, hence a function S:X/ùî§‚Üí‚ÑùS \colon X/\mathfrak{g} \to \mathbb{R} on a Lie algebroid (example 31), its exterior derivative dSd S should be a section of the cotangent bundle of the Lie algebroid. Moreover, if all field variations are infinitesimal (as in def. 19) then it should in fact be a section of the infinitesimal neighbourhood (example 1) of the zero section inside the cotangent bundle, the infinitesimal cotangent bundle T *(X/ùî§)T^\ast(X/\mathfrak{g}) of the Lie algebroid (def. 33 ebelow).

To motivate the definition 33 below of infinitesimal cotangent bundle of a Lie algebroid recall from example 1 that the algebra of functions on the infinitesimal cotangent bundle should be fiberwise the formal power series algebra in the linear functions. But a fiberwise linear function on a cotangent bundle is by definition a vector field. Finally observe that vector fields are equivalently derivations of smooth functions (prop. 1). This leads to the following definition:

Definition

(infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid)

Let ùîû\mathfrak{a} be a Lie ‚àû-algebroid (def. 30) over some manifold XX. Then its infinitesimal cotangent bundle T *ùîûT^\ast \mathfrak{a} is the Lie ‚àû-algebroid over XX whose underlying graded module over C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) is the direct sum of the original module with the derivations of the graded algebra underlying CE(ùîû)CE(\mathfrak{a}):

(T *ùîû) ‚Ä¢ *‚âîùîû ‚Ä¢ *‚äïDer(CE(ùîû)) ‚Ä¢ (T^\ast \mathfrak{a})^\ast_\bullet \;\coloneqq\; \mathfrak{a}^\ast_\bullet \oplus Der(CE(\mathfrak{a}))_\bullet

with differential on the summand ùîû\mathfrak{a} being the original differential and on Der(CE(ùîû))Der(CE(\mathfrak{a})) being the commutator with the differential d CE(ùîû)d_{CE(\mathfrak{a})} on CE(ùîû)CE(\mathfrak{a}) (which is itself a graded derivation of degree +1):

d CE(T *ùîû)| ùîû *‚âîd CE(ùîû) d_{CE(T^\ast \mathfrak{a})}\vert_{\mathfrak{a}^\ast} \;\coloneqq\; d_{CE(\mathfrak{a})}
d CE(T *ùîû)| Der(ùîû)‚âî[d CE(ùîû),‚àí]. d_{CE(T^\ast \mathfrak{a})}\vert_{Der(\mathfrak{a})} \;\coloneqq\; [d_{CE(\mathfrak{a})},-] \,.

There is a canonical homomorphism of Lie algebroids (def. 32)

(44)T *ùîû‚ü∂ùîû T^\ast \mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow \mathfrak{a}

given dually by the identity on the original generators.

Example

(infinitesimal cotangent bundle of action Lie algebroid)

Let X/ùî§X/\mathfrak{g} be an action Lie algebroid (def. 31) where

  • X=‚Ñù nX = \mathbb{R}^n is a Cartesian space with coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a);

  • ùî§\mathfrak{g} is a Lie algebra with linear basis (c Œ±)(c_\alpha) and corresponding structure constants (Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥)(\gamma^{\alpha}{}_{\beta \gamma});

  • the infinitesimal action is given in components by

    d CEœï a=R Œ± ac Œ± d_{CE} \;\phi^a\; = R^a_\alpha c^\alpha

    for smooth functions R Œ± aR^a_\alpha on XX.

Then the infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid T *(X/ùî§)T^\ast (X/\mathfrak{g}) (def. 33) has as underlying cochain complex has generators

(‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ±) (œï a),(‚àÇ‚àÇœï a) (c Œ±) deg= ‚àí1 0 +1. \array{ & \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha} \right) & \left( \phi^a \right) , \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} \right) & \left( c^\alpha \right) \\ deg = & -1 & 0 & +1 } \,.

The CE-differential on the new derivation generators is given by

(45)d CE(T *(X/ùî§))(‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ±) ‚âî[d CE(X/ùî§),‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ±] =R Œ± a‚àÇ‚àÇœï a+Œ≥ Œ≤ Œ±Œ≥c Œ≥‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ≤ \begin{aligned} d_{CE(T^\ast(X/\mathfrak{g}))} \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha} \right) & \coloneqq \left[d_{CE(X/\mathfrak{g})}, \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha} \right] \\ & = R_\alpha^a \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} + \gamma^\beta{}_{\alpha \gamma} c^\gamma \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\beta} \end{aligned}

and

(46)d CE(T *(X/ùî§))(‚àÇ‚àÇœï a) ‚âî[d CE(X/ùî§),‚àÇ‚àÇœï a] =c Œ±‚àÇR Œ± b‚àÇœï a‚àÇ‚àÇœï b. \begin{aligned} d_{CE(T^\ast(X/\mathfrak{g}))} \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} \right) & \coloneqq \left[ d_{CE(X/\mathfrak{g})}, \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} \right] \\ & = c^\alpha \frac{\partial R_\alpha^b}{\partial \phi^a} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^b} \end{aligned} \,.

To ease the notation one abbreviates

(47)œï¬Ø a‚âî‚àÇ‚àÇœï aAAAAAc¬Ø Œ±‚âî‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ± \overline{\phi}_a \;\coloneqq\; \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} \phantom{AAAAA} \overline{c}_\alpha \;\coloneqq\; \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha}

so that the generator content then reads

(48) (c¬Ø Œ±) (œï a),(œï¬Ø a) (c Œ±) deg= ‚àí1 0 +1. \array{ & \left( \overline{c}_\alpha \right) & \left( \phi^a \right) , \left( \overline{\phi}_a \right) & \left( c^\alpha \right) \\ deg = & -1 & 0 & +1 } \,.

In this notation the full action of the CE-differential is therefore the following:

(49) d CE(T *(X/ùî§)) œï a ‚Ü¶ c Œ±R Œ± a c Œ± ‚Ü¶ 12Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥c Œ≤c Œ≥ œï¬Ø a ‚Ü¶ +c Œ±‚àÇR Œ± b‚àÇœï aœï¬Ø b c¬Ø Œ± ‚Ü¶ R Œ± aœï¬Ø a+Œ≥ Œ≤ Œ±Œ≥c Œ≥c¬Ø Œ≤ \array{ & d_{CE(T^\ast(X/\mathfrak{g}))} \\ \phi^a &\mapsto& c^\alpha R^a_\alpha \\ c^\alpha & \mapsto& \tfrac{1}{2} \gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} c^\beta c^\gamma \\ \overline{\phi}_a &\mapsto& + c^\alpha \frac{\partial R_\alpha^b}{\partial \phi^a} \overline{\phi}_b \\ \overline{c}_\alpha &\mapsto& R_\alpha^a \overline{\phi}_a + \gamma^\beta{}_{\alpha \gamma} c^\gamma \overline{c}_\beta }
Proposition

(exterior differential of gauge invariant function is section of infinitesimal cotangent bundle)

For ùîû\mathfrak{a} an Lie ‚àû-algebroid (def. 30) over some XX; and S:ùîû‚ü∂‚ÑùS \;\colon\;\mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} a gauge invariant smooth function on it (example 31); there is an induced section dSd S of the infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid (def. 33) bundle projection (44):

T *ùîû dS‚Üó ‚Üì ùîû = ùîû, \array{ && T^\ast \mathfrak{a} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{d S}}\nearrow & \downarrow \\ \mathfrak{a} &=& \mathfrak{a} } \,,

given dually

(dS) *:CE(T *ùîû)‚ü∂CE(ùîû) (d S)^\ast \;\colon\; CE(T^\ast \mathfrak{a}) \longrightarrow CE(\mathfrak{a})

by the map which sends

  1. the generators in ùîû *\mathfrak{a}^\ast to themselves;

  2. a vector field vv on XX, regarded as a degree-0 derivation to dS(v)=v(S)‚ààC ‚àû(X)d S(v) = v(S) \in C^\infty(X);

  3. all other derivations to zero.

Proof

We discuss the proof in the special case of example 32. The general case is directly analogous.

We need to check that (dS) *(d S)^\ast respects the CE-differentials.

On the original generators in ùîû *\mathfrak{a}^\ast this is immediate, since on these the CE-differential on both sides are by definition the same.

On the derivation ‚àÇ‚àÇœï a\frac{\partial}{ \partial \phi^a} we find from (46)

{‚àÇS‚àÇœï a} ‚üµ(dS) * {‚àÇ‚àÇœï a} d CE(ùîû)‚Üì ‚Üì d CE(T *ùîû) {c Œ±‚àÇR Œ± b‚àÇœï a‚àÇS‚àÇœï b} ‚üµ(dS) * {c Œ±‚àÇR Œ± b‚àÇœï a‚àÇ‚àÇœï b} \array{ \left\{ \frac{\partial S}{\partial \phi^a} \right\} &\overset{(d S)^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& \left\{ \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} \right\} \\ {}^{\mathllap{d_{CE(\mathfrak{a})}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{d_{CE(T^\ast \mathfrak{a})}}} \\ \left\{ c^\alpha \frac{\partial R_\alpha^b}{\partial \phi^a} \frac{\partial S}{\partial \phi^b} \right\} &\underset{(d S)^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& \left\{ c^\alpha \frac{\partial R_\alpha^b}{\partial \phi^a} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^b} \right\} }

and on the derivation ‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ±\frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha} we find from (45) and using the gauge invariance of SS

{0} ‚üµ(dS) * {‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ±} ‚Üì ‚Üì {0=R Œ± a‚àÇS‚àÇœï a} ‚üµ(dS) * {R Œ± a‚àÇ‚àÇœï a+Œ≥ Œ≤ Œ±Œ≥c Œ≥‚àÇ‚àÇc Œ≤}. \array{ \left\{ 0 \right\} &\overset{(d S)^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& \left\{ \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\alpha} \right\} \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \left\{ 0 = R_\alpha^a \frac{\partial S}{\partial \phi^a} \right\} &\overset{(d S)^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& \left\{ R_\alpha^a \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^a} + \gamma^\beta{}_{\alpha \gamma} c^\gamma \frac{\partial}{\partial c^\beta} \right\} } \,.
Definition

(derived critical locus of gauge invariant function on Lie ‚àû-algebroid)

Let ùîû\mathfrak{a} be a Lie ‚àû-algebroid (def. 30) over some XX, let

S:ùîû‚ü∂‚Ñù S \;\colon\; \mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}

be a gauge invariant function (example 31) and consider the section of its infinitesimal cotangent bundle T *ùîûT^\ast \mathfrak{a} (def. 32) corresponding to its exterior derivative via prop. 22.

ùîû ‚ü∂dS T *ùîû ‚Üò ‚Üô ùîû \array{ \mathfrak{a} && \overset{d S}{\longrightarrow} && T^\ast \mathfrak{a} \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \mathfrak{a} }

Then the derived critical locus of SS is the derived Lie algebroid (def. 30) to be denoted ùîû dS‚âÉ0\mathfrak{a}_{d S \simeq 0} which is the homotopy pullback of the section dSd S along the zero section:

ùîû dS‚âÉ0 ‚ü∂ ùîû ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì 0 ùîû ‚ü∂dS T *ùîû. \array{ \mathfrak{a}_{d S \simeq 0} &\longrightarrow& \mathfrak{a} \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{0}} \\ \mathfrak{a} &\underset{d S}{\longrightarrow}& T^\ast \mathfrak{a} } \,.

This means equivalently (details are at derived critical locus) that the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of ùîû dS‚âÉ0\mathfrak{a}_{d S \simeq 0} is like that of the infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid T *ùîûT^\ast \mathfrak{a} (def. 33) except for two changes:

  1. all derivations are shifted down in degree by one;

  2. the CE-differential on the derivations coming from vector fields vv on XX is that of the infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid T *ùîûT^\ast \mathfrak{a} plus dS(v)=v(S)d S(v) = v(S).

Example

(archetype of the BV-BRST complex)

Consider a gauge invariant function S:X/ùî§‚Üí‚ÑùS \colon X/\mathfrak{g} \to \mathbb{R} (def. 31) on an action Lie algebroid (def. 31) for the case that the underlying manifold is a Cartesian space with global coordinates as in example 32. Then the generators of the derived critical locus (X/ùî§) dS‚âÉ0(X/\mathfrak{g})_{d S \simeq 0} (def. 34) are as in (48), except for the degree shift:

(c¬Ø Œ±) (œï¬Ø a) (œï a) (c Œ±) deg= ‚àí2 ‚àí1 0 +1 \array{ & \left( \overline{c}^\alpha \right) & \left( \overline{\phi}^a \right) & \left( \phi^a \right) & \left( c^\alpha \right) \\ deg = & -2 & -1 & 0 & +1 }

and the CE-differential is given by

d CE(ùîû dS‚âÉ0) œï a ‚Ü¶ c Œ±R Œ± a c Œ± ‚Ü¶ 12Œ≥ Œ± Œ≤Œ≥c Œ≤c Œ≥ œï¬Ø a ‚Ü¶ ‚àÇS‚àÇœï a‚èünew+c Œ±‚àÇR Œ± b‚àÇœï aœï¬Ø b c¬Ø Œ± ‚Ü¶ R Œ± aœï¬Ø a+Œ≥ Œ≤ Œ±Œ≥c Œ≥c¬Ø Œ≤ \array{ & d_{CE(\mathfrak{a}_{d S \simeq 0})} \\ \phi^a &\mapsto& c^\alpha R^a_\alpha \\ c^\alpha & \mapsto& \tfrac{1}{2} \gamma^\alpha{}_{\beta \gamma} c^\beta c^\gamma \\ \overline{\phi}_a &\mapsto& \underset{ new }{ \underbrace{ \frac{\partial S}{\partial \phi^a} }} + c^\alpha \frac{\partial R_\alpha^b}{\partial \phi^a} \overline{\phi}_b \\ \overline{c}_\alpha &\mapsto& R_\alpha^a \overline{\phi}_a + \gamma^\beta{}_{\alpha \gamma} c^\gamma \overline{c}_\beta }

which is like the differential (49) of the cotangent Lie algebroid from example 32, except for the degree-shift by -1 of the derivation generators and except for the crucial new term indicated by the underbrace.

If we think of the function SS as being the action functional (example 17) of a Lagrangian field theory (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) (def. 9) over a compact spacetime Œ£\Sigma, with XX the space of field histories (or rather an infinitesimal neighbourhood therein), hence with ùî§\mathfrak{g} a Lie algebra of gauge symmetries acting on the field histories, then the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra CE(X/ùî§ dS‚âÉ0)CE(X/\mathfrak{g}_{d S \simeq 0}) of the derived critical locus of SS is called the BV-BRST complex of the theory.

In applications of interest, the spacetime Œ£\Sigma is not compact. In that case one may still appeal to a construction on the space of field histories as in example 33 by considering the action functional for all adiabatically switched bLb \mathbf{L} Lagrangians, with b‚ààC cp ‚àû(Œ£)b \in C_{cp}^\infty(\Sigma). This approach is taken in (Fredenhagen-Rejzner 11a).

Here we instead consider now the ‚Äúlocal lift‚Äù or ‚Äúde-transgression‚Äù of the above construction from the space of field histories to the jet bundle of the field bundle of the theory, refining the BV-BRST complex to the local BV-BRST complex, corresponding to the local BRST complex from example 30.

This requires a slight refinement of the construction that leads to example 33: In contrast to the action functional S=œÑ Œ£(L)S = \tau_\Sigma(\mathbf{L}), the Lagrangian density L\mathbf{L} is not strictly invariant under implicit infinitesimal gauge transformations, in general, rather it may change up to a horizontally exact term (by the very definition 27). The same is then true for its Euler-Lagrange variational derivative Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L}. This means that Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} is not a section of the infinitesimal cotangent bundle (def. 33) of the gauge action Lie algebroid on the jet bundle, but by a local version of it, which is twisted by horizontally exact terms.

The following definition 35 is the local refinement of def. 33:

Definition

(local infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) over some spacetime Œ£\Sigma, and let ùí¢‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma be a bundle of closed irreducible gauge parameters (def. 28), inducing via example 30 the Lie algebroid

E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)=(J Œ£ ‚àû(E√ó Œ£(ùí¢[1])),s BRST)) E / ( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma ) \;=\; \left( J^\infty_\Sigma( E \times_\Sigma (\mathcal{G}[1]) ) , s_{BRST} ) \right)

whose Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra is the local BRST complex of the field theory.

Consider the case that both the field bundle E‚ÜífbŒ£E \overset{fb}{\to} \Sigma (def. 1) as well as the gauge parameter bundle ùí¢‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma are trivial vector bundles (example 2) over Minkowski spacetime with field coordinates (œï a)(\phi^a) and gauge parameter coordinates (œµ Œ±)(\epsilon^\alpha).

Then the vertical infinitesimal cotangent Lie algebroid (def. 33) has coordinates as in (48) as well as all the corresponding jets and including also the horizontal differentials:

(c¬Ø Œ±,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k) (œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a),(œï¬Ø a,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k) (c ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k Œ±),(dx Œº) deg= ‚àí1 0 +1. \array{ & \left( \overline{c}_{\alpha,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right) & \left( \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right) , \left( \overline{\phi}_{a,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right) & \left( c^\alpha_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right), \left( d x^\mu \right) \\ deg = & -1 & 0 & +1 } \,.

Observe that in terms of these coordinates the ordinary commutator of graded derivations has the following succinct expression:

(‚Ä¶)

Now consider the modification of this formula to the formula

(50){fdvol Œ£,g} ‚âî+(‚àí1) |f|+(p+1)(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k(Œ¥ ELfŒ¥œï a))(‚àÇg‚àÇœï¬Ø a,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k)‚àí(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k(Œ¥ ELfŒ¥œï¬Ø a))(‚àÇg‚àÇœï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a) =+(‚àí1) |f|+(p+1)((d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k(Œ¥ ELfŒ¥c Œ±))(‚àÇg‚àÇc¬Ø Œ±,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k)‚àí(d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k(Œ¥ ELfŒ¥c¬Ø Œ±))(‚àÇg‚àÇc ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k Œ±)) \begin{aligned} \left\{ f dvol_\Sigma, g \right\} & \coloneqq \phantom{+ (-1)^{\vert f \vert + (p+1)}} \left( \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \left( \frac{\delta_{EL} f}{\delta \phi^a} \right) \right) \left( \frac{\partial g}{\partial \overline{\phi}_{a,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}} \right) - \left( \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \left( \frac{\delta_{EL} f}{\delta \overline{\phi}_a} \right) \right) \left( \frac{\partial g}{\partial \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}} \right) \\ & \phantom{=} + (-1)^{\vert f \vert + (p+1)} \left( \left( \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \left( \frac{\delta_{EL} f}{\delta c^\alpha} \right) \right) \left( \frac{\partial g}{\partial \overline{c}_{\alpha,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}} \right) - \left( \frac{d^k}{d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \left( \frac{\delta_{EL} f}{\delta \overline{c}_\alpha} \right) \right) \left( \frac{\partial g}{\partial c^\alpha_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k}} \right) \right) \end{aligned}

where Œ¥ EL\delta_{EL} denotes the Euler-Lagrange variational derivative.

We define the CE-differential on functions on T *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))T^\ast( E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) ) to be

d CE(T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)))‚âî{s BRSTdvol Œ£,‚àí} d_{CE(T^\ast_\Sigma( E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) ))} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ s_{BRST} dvol_\Sigma, - \right\}

This defines an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebroid to be denoted

T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)). T^\ast_\Sigma( E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) ) \,.

The local refinement of prop. 22 is now this:

Proposition

(Euler-Lagrange form is section of local cotangent bundle of jet bundle gauge-action Lie algebroid)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) over some spacetime Œ£\Sigma, and let ùí¢‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma be a bundle of closed irreducible gauge parameters (def. 28), inducing via example 30 the Lie algebroid E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)E / ( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma ) and via def. 35 its local cotangent Lie ‚àû-algebroid T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))T^\ast_\Sigma(E / ( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma )).

Then the Euler-Lagrange variational derivative (prop. 4) constitutes a section of the local cotangent Lie ‚àû-algebroid (def. 35)

T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)) Œ¥ ELL‚Üó ‚Üì E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£) = E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£) \array{ && T^\ast_\Sigma\left( E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) \right) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ \delta_{EL} \mathbf{L} }}\nearrow & \downarrow \\ E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) &=& E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) }

given dually

CE(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))‚üµ(Œ¥ ELL) *CE(T *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))) CE(E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T\Sigma)) \overset{(\delta_{EL}\mathbf{L})^\ast}{\longleftarrow} CE(T^\ast(E/(\mathcal{G}\times_\Sigma T \Sigma)))

by

{œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a} ‚üµ {œï ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k a} {c ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k Œ±} ‚üµ {c ,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k Œ±} {d kdx Œº 1‚ãØdx Œº k(Œ¥ ELLŒ¥œï a)} ‚üµ {œï¬Ø a,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k} {0} ‚üµ {c¬Ø Œ±,Œº 1‚ãØŒº k} \array{ \left\{ \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} &\longleftarrow& \left\{ \phi^a_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} \\ \left\{ c^\alpha_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} &\longleftarrow& \left\{ c^\alpha_{,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} \\ \left\{ \frac{d^k}{ d x^{\mu_1} \cdots d x^{\mu_k}} \left( \frac{\delta_{EL} L}{\delta \phi^a} \right) \right\} &\longleftarrow& \left\{ \overline{\phi}_{a,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} \\ \left\{ 0 \right\} &\longleftarrow& \left\{ \overline{c}_{\alpha,\mu_1 \cdots \mu_k} \right\} }
Proof

The proof of this proposition is a special case of the observation that the differentials involved are part of the local BV-BRST differential; this will be a direct consequence of the proof of prop. 24 below.

The local analog of def. 34 is now the following definition 36 of the ‚Äúderived prolonged shell‚Äù of the theory (recall the ordinary prolonged shell ‚Ñ∞ ‚àû‚Ü™J Œ£ ‚àû(E)\mathcal{E}^\infty \hookrightarrow J^\infty_\Sigma(E) from (12)):

Definition

(derived reduced prolonged shell)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) over some spacetime Œ£\Sigma, and let ùí¢‚ÜígbŒ£\mathcal{G} \overset{gb}{\to} \Sigma be a bundle of closed irreducible gauge parameters (def. 28), inducing via prop. 23 a section Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} L of the local cotangent Lie algebroid of the jet bundle gauge-action Lie algebroid.

Then the derived prolonged shell ‚Ñ∞ BV ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty_{BV} is the derived critical locus of Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} L, hence the homotopy pullback of Œ¥ ELL\delta_{EL} L along the zero section of the local cotangent Lie ‚àû\infty-algebroid:

‚Ñ∞ BV ‚àû ‚ü∂ E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£) ‚Üì ‚Üì 0 E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£) ‚ü∂Œ¥ ELL T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)) \array{ \mathcal{E}^\infty_{BV} &\longrightarrow& E/( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma ) \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{0}} \\ E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) &\underset{\delta_{EL} L}{\longrightarrow}& T^\ast_\Sigma\left( E/( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma ) \right) }

The local refinement of example 33 is now the following:

Proposition

(local BV-BRST complex)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory with bundle of closed irreducible gauge parameters ùí¢\mathcal{G}‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶. the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of the derived prolonged shell ‚Ñ∞ BV ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty_{BV} (def. 36) is the local BV-BRST complex‚Ä¶

Proof

By unwinding the definitions analogous to the proof of example 32, the CE-differential is given by the modified bracket of derivations (50) with the sum of the BRST-differential and the Lagrangian density:

d CE(T Œ£ *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)))={(L+L BRST)dvol Œ£,‚àí} d_{CE( T^\ast_\Sigma(E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T\Sigma)) )} \;=\; \left\{ \left(L + L_{BRST}\right) dvol_\Sigma \;,\; - \right\}

only that in the homotopy fiber ‚Ñ∞ BV ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty_{BV} the derivations receive a degree-shift by -1 compared to their degree in T *(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))T^\ast(E /( \mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma )).

This operation is the local BV-BRST differential by (Barnich-Henneaux 96 (2.12)-(2.13)).

Example

(derived prolonged shell in the absence of explicit gauge symmetry ‚Äì the local BV-complex)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) with no non-trivial infinitesimal gauge symmetries made explicit (possibly because there are none, as for the scalar field), hence with no ghost fields introduced. Then the local derived critical locus of its Lagrangian density (def. 36) is the local BV-complex of def. 20.

Example

(local BV-complex of vacuum electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime)

Consider the Lagrangian field theory of free electromagnetism on Minkowski spacetime (example 11) with gauge parameter as in example 26. With the field and gauge parameter coordinates as chosen in these examples

((a Œº),c) \left( (a_\mu), c \right)

then the local BV-BRST complex (prop. 24) has generators

c¬Ø a¬Ø Œº a Œº c deg= ‚àí2 ‚àí1 0 1 \array{ & \overline{c} & \overline{a}^\mu & a_\mu & c \\ deg = & -2 & -1 & 0 & 1 }

together with their total spacetime derivatives, and the local BV-BRST differential ss acts on these generators as follows:

s:{a¬Ø Œº ‚Ü¶ f ,ŒΩ ŒΩŒº (equations of Motion -- vacuum Maxwell equations) c¬Ø ‚Ü¶ a¬Ø ,Œº Œº (Noether identity) a Œº ‚Ü¶ c ,Œº (infinitesimal gauge transformation) s \;\colon\; \left\{ \array{ \overline{a}^\mu &\mapsto& f^{\nu \mu}_{,\nu} & \text{(equations of Motion -- vacuum Maxwell equations)} \\ \overline{c} &\mapsto& \overline{a}^\mu_{,\mu} & \text{(Noether identity)} \\ a_\mu &\mapsto& c_{,\mu} & \text{(infinitesimal gauge transformation)} } \right.

\,

So far the discussion yields just the algebra of functions on the derived reduced prolonged shell. We now discuss the derived analog of the full variational bicomplex (def. 8) to the derived reduced shell.

The analog of the de Rham complex of a derived Lie algebroid is called the Weil algebra:

Definition

(Weil algebra of a Lie algebroid)

Given a derived Lie algebroid ùîû\mathfrak{a} over some XX (def. 30), its Weil algebra is

W(ùîû)‚âî(Sym C ‚àû(X)(Œì(T *X)‚äïùîû ‚Ä¢‚äïùîû[1] ‚Ä¢),d W‚âîd+d CE), W(\mathfrak{a}) \;\coloneqq\; \left( Sym_{C^\infty(X)}( \Gamma(T^\ast X) \oplus \mathfrak{a}_\bullet \oplus \mathfrak{a}[1]_\bullet ) \;,\; \mathbf{d}_W \coloneqq \mathbf{d} + d_{CE} \right) \,,

where d\mathbf{d} acts as the de Rham differential d:C ‚àû(X)‚ÜíŒì(T *X)\mathbf{d} \colon C^\infty(X) \to \Gamma(T^\ast X) on functions, and as the degree shift operator d:ùîû ‚Ä¢‚Üíùîû[1] ‚Ä¢\mathbf{d} \colon \mathfrak{a}_\bullet \to \mathfrak{a}[1]_\bullet on the graded elements.

smooth manifoldsderived Lie algebroids
algebra of functionsChevalley-Eilenberg algebra
algebra of differential formsWeil algebra
Example

(classical Weil algebra)

Let ùî§\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra with corresponding Lie algebroid Bùî§B \mathfrak{g} (example 28). Then the Weil algebra (def. 37) of Bùî§B \mathfrak{g} is the traditional Weil algebra of ùî§\mathfrak{g} from classical Lie theory.

Definition

(variational BV-bicomplex?)

Let (E,L)(E,\mathbf{L}) be a Lagrangian field theory (def. 9) equipped with a closed irreducible gauge parameter bundle ùí¢\mathcal{G} (def. 28). Consider the Lie algebroid E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) from example 30, whose Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra is the local BRST complex of the theory.

Then its Weil algebra W(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£))W(E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma)) (def. 37) has as differential the variational derivative (def. 8) plus the BRST differential

d W =d‚àí(d‚àís BRST) =Œ¥+s BRST. \begin{aligned} d_{W} & = \mathbf{d} - (d - s_{BRST}) \\ & = \delta + s_{BRST} \end{aligned} \,.

Therefore we speak of the variational BRST-bicomplex? and write

Œ© Œ£ ‚Ä¢(E/(ùí¢√ó Œ£TŒ£)). \Omega^\bullet_\Sigma( E/(\mathcal{G} \times_\Sigma T \Sigma) ) \,.

Similarly, the Weil algebra of the derived prolonged shell ‚Ñ∞ BV ‚àû\mathcal{E}^\infty_{BV} (def. 36) has differential

d W =d‚àí(d‚àís) =Œ¥+s. \begin{aligned} d_W & = \mathbf{d} - (d - s) \\ & = \delta + s \end{aligned} \,.

Since ss is the BV-BRST differential (prop. 24) this defines the ‚Äúvariational BV-BRST-bicomplex‚Äù.

(‚Ä¶)

\,

It turns out that the local BV-BRST cohomology (prop. 24) of the ‚Äúderived reduced prolonged shell‚Äù very neatly captures all the aspects of Lagrangian field theory that we have been discussing so far:

Example

(Noether theorem I in terms of local BRST cohomology)

The d‚àísd-s-closed elements in degree (p,0)(p,0) are precisely pairs (v,J v)(v,J_v) consisting of an implicit infinitesimal local gauge symmetry vv and a conserved current J vJ_v for it.

The d Wd_W-exact elements in this degree are sums of

  1. dd-exact currents;

  2. on-shell vanishing implicit gauge transformations;

  3. on-shell vanishing currents with their horizontally exact gauge transformations

(‚Ä¶)

Proof

The d Wd_W-closed element are the implicit infinitesimal gauge symmetries vv regarded as an antifield v aœï¬Ø av^a \overline{\phi}_a multiplied with the volume form dvol Œ£dvol_\Sigma together with their Noether current J v‚ààŒ© Œ£ p,0(E)J_v \in \Omega^{p,0}_\Sigma(E) (prop. 9)

{J v} ‚ü∂d {dJ v‚àíŒπ vŒ¥ ELL‚èû=0} ‚Üës BV {v aœï¬Ø advol Œ£} \array{ \{J_v\} &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \{ \overset{= 0}{\overbrace{ d J_v - \iota_v \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} }} \} \\ && \uparrow\mathrlap{s_{BV}} \\ && \{ v^a \overline{\phi}_a dvol_\Sigma\} }

Such a pair is exact if

{K} ‚ü∂d {dK+v aŒºŒ¥ ELLŒ¥œï aŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£} ‚ü∂d {dJ v‚àíŒπ vŒ¥ ELL‚èû=0} s BV‚Üë ‚Üës BV v aŒºœï¬Ø aŒπ ‚àÇ Œºdvol Œ£ ‚ü∂‚àíd {v aœï¬Ø advol Œ£} ‚Üës BV Œ∫ abœï¬Ø aœï¬Ø bdvol Œ£ \array{ \{K\} &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \{ d K + v^{a \mu} \frac{\delta_{EL}L}{\delta \phi^a} \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma \} &\overset{d}{\longrightarrow}& \{ \overset{= 0}{\overbrace{ d J_v - \iota_v \delta_{EL}\mathbf{L} }} \} \\ && \mathllap{s_{BV}}\uparrow && \uparrow\mathrlap{s_{BV}} \\ && v^{a \mu} \overline{\phi}_a \iota_{\partial_\mu} dvol_\Sigma &\underset{-d}{\longrightarrow}& \{ v^a \overline{\phi}_a dvol_\Sigma\} \\ && && \uparrow\mathrlap{s_{BV}} \\ && && \kappa^{a b } \overline{\phi}_a \overline{\phi}_b dvol_\Sigma }

(‚Ä¶)

Example

(infinitesimal gauge symmetry via local BRST cohomology)

An infinitesimal gauge symmetry v œµv_\epsilon of gauge parameter (œµ Œ±)(\epsilon^\alpha) is a vector field on the jet bundle with components of the form

‚Ñí v œµœï a‚âîR Œ± aœµ Œ±+R Œ± aŒºdœµ Œ±dx Œº \mathcal{L}_{v_\epsilon} \phi^a \;\coloneqq\; R^a_\alpha \epsilon^\alpha + R^{a \mu}_\alpha \frac{d \epsilon^\alpha}{d x^\mu}

such that this is an infinitesimal symmetry of the Lagrangian in that
